.503-T. Repealed by Ordinance No. 3385.
.503-U. TRANSPORTATION DEMAND MANAGEMENT MEASURES.
Purpose and Intent. These regulations are established to encourage the efficient use of existing and planned transportation
infrastructures, the maintenance and improvement of traffic levels of service and the citywide reduction of motor vehicle emissions.
Goals and Strategies. To minimize the number of peak period vehicle trips generated by new development by setting development
standards that support the use of alternative transportation systems that also minimize fuel emissions into the atmosphere. Regionwide and
countrywide participation on transportation demand management is also strongly supported by the development standards.
A.

Definitions.
1.

"Alternative transportation" means the use of modes of transportation other than the single-passenger motor
vehicle, including but not limited to carpools, vanpools, buspools, public transit, walking and bicycling.

2.

"Applicable development" means any development project that is determined to meet or exceed the project size
threshold criteria contained in subdivision C of this subsection.

3.

"Buspool" means a vehicle carrying sixteen or more passengers commuting on a regular basis to and from work
with a fixed route, according to a fixed schedule.

4.

"Carpool" means a vehicle carrying two to six persons commuting together to and from work on a regular basis.

5.

"The California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA)" is a statute that requires all jurisdictions in the State of California
to evaluate the extent of environmental degradation posed by proposed development.

6.

"Developer" means the builder who is responsible for the planning, design and construction of an applicable
development project. A developer may be responsible for implementing the provisions of this subsection as
determined by the property owner.

7.

"Development" means the construction or addition of new building square footage. Additions to buildings which
180/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

existed prior to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this subsection and which exceed the thresholds defined
in subdivision C of this subsection shall comply with the applicable requirements but shall not be added
cumulatively with existing square footage; existing square footage shall be exempt from these requirements. All
calculations shall be based on gross square footage.
8.

"Employee parking area" means the portion of total required parking at a development used by on-site employees.
Unless specified in the zoning code, employee parking shall be calculated as follows:

Type of Use

Percent of Total Required Parking Devoted to Employees

Commercial

30%

O ce/Professional

85%

Industrial/Manufacturing

90%

9.

"Preferential parking" means parking spaces designated or assigned, through use of a sign or painted space
markings for carpool and vanpool vehicles carrying commute passengers on a regular basis that are provided in a
location more convenient to a place of employment than parking spaces provided for single-occupant vehicles.

10.

"Property owner" means the legal owner of a development who serves as the lessor to a tenant. The property
owner shall be responsible for complying with the provisions of this subsection either directly or by delegating such
responsibility as appropriate to a tenant and/or his agent.

11.

"South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD)" is the regional authority appointed by the California State
Legislature to meet federal standards and otherwise improve air quality in the South Coast Air Basin (the nondesert
portions of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside and San Bernardino Counties).

12.

"Tenant" means the lessee of facility space at an applicable development project.

13.

"Transportation demand management (TDM)" means the alteration of travel behavior, usually on the part of
commuters, through programs of incentives, services and policies. TDM addresses alternatives to single-occupant
vehicles such as carpooling and vanpooling, and changes in work schedules that move trips out of the peak period
or eliminate them altogether (as is the case in telecommuting or compressed work weeks).

14.

"Trip reduction" means reduction in the number of work-related trips made by single-occupant vehicles.

15.

"Vanpool" means a vehicle carrying seven or more persons commuting together to and from work on a regular
basis, usually in a vehicle with a seating arrangement designed to carry seven to fifteen adult passengers, and on a
prepaid subscription basis.

16.

"Vehicle" means any motorized form of transportation, including but not limited to automobiles, vans, buses and
motorcycles.

B.

Review of Transit Impacts.

Prior to approval of any development project for which an environmental impact report (EIR) will be prepared pursuant to the
requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) or based on local determination, regional and municipal fixed-route
transit operators providing service to the project shall be identified and consulted with. Projects for which a notice of preparation
(NOP) for a draft EIR has been circulated pursuant to the provisions of CEQA prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in
this subsection shall be exempted from its provisions. The "Transit Impact Review Worksheet," contained in the Los Angeles County
Congestion Management Program Manual, or similar worksheets, shall be used in assessing impacts. Pursuant to the provisions of
CEQA, transit operators shall be sent a NOP for all contemplated EIRs and shall, as part of the NOP process, be given opportunity to
comment on the impacts of the project, to identify recommended transit service or capital improvements which may be required as
a result of the project, and to recommend mitigation measures which minimize automobile trips on the CMP network. Impacts and
recommended mitigation measures identified by the transit operator shall be evaluated in the draft EIR prepared for the project.
Related mitigation measures adopted shall be monitored through the mitigation monitoring requirements of CEQA.

181/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Phased development projects, development projects subject to a development agreement, or development projects requiring
subsequent approvals, need not repeat this process as long as no significant changes are made to the project. It shall remain the
discretion of the lead agency to determine when a project is substantially the same and therefore covered by a previously certified
EIR.
C.

Transportation Demand and Trip Reduction Measures.
1.

Applicability of Requirements.

Prior to approval of any development project, the applicant shall make provisions for, as a minimum, all of the following
applicable transportation demand management and trip reduction measures.
This subsection shall not apply to projects for which a development application has been deemed "complete" by the city
pursuant to Government Code Section 65943, or for which a notice of preparation for an EIR has been circulated or for which an
application for a building permit has been received, prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this subsection.
All facilities and improvements constructed or otherwise required shall be maintained in a state of good repair.
2.

Development Standards.
a.

Nonresidential development of twenty-five thousand square feet or more shall provide the following to the
satisfaction of the city:
(1)

A bulletin board, display case, or kiosk displaying transportation information located where the greatest
number of employees are likely to see it. Information in the area shall including, but is not limited to, the
following:

(2)

Current maps, routes and schedules for public transit routes serving the site;

(3)

Telephone numbers for referrals on transportation information including numbers for the regional
ridesharing agency and local transit operators;

(4)

Ridesharing promotional material supplied by commuter-oriented organizations;

(5)

Bicycle route and facility information, including regional/ local bicycle maps and bicycle safety
information;

(6)

A listing of facilities available for carpoolers, vanpoolers, bicyclists, transit riders and pedestrians at the
site.

b.

Nonresidential development of fifty thousand square feet or more shall comply with subdivision (2)(a) above
and shall provide all of the following measures to the satisfaction of the city:
(1)

Not less than ten percent of the employee parking area shall be located as close as is practical to the
employee entrance(s), and shall be reserved for the use by potential carpool/vanpool vehicles, without
displacing handicapped and customer parking needs. This preferential carpool/vanpool parking area
shall be identified on the site plan upon application for building permit, to the satisfaction of the city. A
statement that preferential carpool/vanpool spaces for employees are available and a description of the
method for obtaining such spaces must be included in the required transportation information board.
Spaces will be signed/striped as demand warrants provided that at all times at least one space for
projects of fifty thousand square feet to one hundred thousand square feet and two spaces for projects
over one hundred thousand square feet shall be signed/striped for carpool/vanpool vehicles.

(2)

Preferential parking spaces reserved for vanpools must be accessible to vanpool vehicles. When located
within a parking structure, a minimum vertical interior clearance of seven feet, two inches shall be
provided for those spaces and access ways to be used by such vehicles. Adequate turning radius and
parking space dimensions shall also be included in vanpool parking areas.

(3)

Bicycle racks or other secure bicycle parking shall be provided to accommodate four bicycles per the first
fifty thousand square feet of nonresidential development and one bicycle per each additional fifty
thousand square feet of nonresidential development. Calculations which result in a fraction of 0.5 or
higher shall be rounded up to the nearest whole number. A bicycle parking facility may also be a fully

182/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

enclosed space or locker accessible only to the owner or operator of the bicycle, which protects the bike
from inclement weather. Specific facilities and location (e.g., provisions of racks, lockers, or locked rooms)
shall be to the satisfaction of the city.
c.

Nonresidential development of one hundred thousand square feet or more shall comply with subdivisions (2)
(a) and (2)(b) above, and shall provide all of the following measures to the satisfaction of the city:
(1)

A safe and convenient zone in which vanpool and carpool vehicles may deliver or board their passengers.

(2)

Sidewalks or other designated pathways following direct and safe routes from the external pedestrian
circulation system to each building in the development.

(3)

If determined necessary by the city to mitigate the project impact, bus stop improvements shall be
provided. The city shall consult with the local bus service providers in determining appropriate
improvements. When locating bus stops and/or planning building entrances, entrances shall be designed
to provide safe and efficient access to nearby transit stations/stops.

(4)
D.

Safe and convenient access from the external circulation system to bicycle parking facilities on-site.

Monitoring.

All applicable development standards in this section and all identified mitigation measures for development projects subject to
this subsection shall be monitored for appropriate compliance prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy or business license.
E.

Enforcement.

All applicable development standards in this section and all identified mitigation measures for development projects subject to
this subsection shall be properly in place and updated before any permit for tenant improvement work, remodeling, site work,
additional building square footage or landscaping work is permitted.
(Ord. No. 3690, § 1.)

Sec. .520. - Density bonus.
A.

Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide affordable housing pursuant to State Government Code Section 65915.

B.

Affordable Housing. State Government Code Section 65915 provides for the granting of a density bonus or other incentives of
equivalent financial value when a developer of housing agrees to construct at least one of the following:
1.

Twenty percent of the total units of a housing development for persons and families of lower income, as defined in
Section 50079.5 of the Health and Safety Code;

2.

Ten percent of the total units of a housing development for very low income households, as defined in Section 50105 of
the Health and Safety Code;

3.

Fifty percent of the total dwelling units of a housing development for qualifying residents, as defined in Section 51.2 of
the Civil Code.

C.

Incentives and Requirements. A request for a density bonus and regulatory concessions and/or incentives shall require
conditional use permit review and be subject to the following provisions:
1.

For the purpose of this section, "density bonus" shall mean a density increase of twenty-five percent over the otherwise
maximum allowable residential density under the zoning ordinance. When determining the number of housing units
which are to be affordable, the density bonus shall not be included.

2.

The procedures for implementing this section are as follows:
a)

The city shall within ninety days of receipt of a written proposal, notify the developer in writing of the procedures
governing these provisions.

b)

The council may approve the density bonus and regulatory concessions and/or incentives only if all of the following
findings are made:
1)

The developer has proven that the density bonus and adjustment of standards are necessary to make the
project economically feasible;

2)

That additional adjustment of standards is not required in order for the rents for the targeted units to be set
pursuant to Government Code Section 65915(c); and

3)
3.

The proposed project is compatible with the purpose and intent of the general plan and the zoning ordinance.

The density bonus shall only apply to housing developments consisting of five or more dwelling units which are owneroccupied.

4.

Prior to the issuance of a building permit for any dwelling unit in a development for which "density bonus units" have
been awarded or incentives have been received, the developer shall submit documentation which identifies the
restricted units and shall enter into a written agreement with the city to guarantee for thirty years their continued use
and availability to low and moderate income households. The agreement shall extend more than thirty years if required
by the Construction or Mortgage Financing Assistance Program, Mortgage Insurance Program or Rental Subsidy Program.
The terms and conditions of the agreement shall run with the land which is to be developed, shall be binding upon the
successor in interest of the developer, and shall be recorded in the office of the Los Angeles County recorder.

The agreement shall include the following provisions:
a)

The developer shall give the city the continuing right-of-first-refusal to purchase or lease any or all of the designated
units at the fair market value.
184/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

b)

The deeds to the designated units shall contain a covenant stating that the developer or his/her successor in interest s
lease, sublet, assign or otherwise transfer any interests for same without the written approval of the city confirming th
the units is consistent with the limits established for low and moderate-income households, which shall be related to t
Index.

c)

The city shall have the authority to enter into other agreements with the developer or purchasers of the dwelling
units, as may be necessary to assure that the required dwellings units are continuously occupied by eligible
households.

d)

Applicable deed restrictions, in a form satisfactory to the city attorney, shall contain provisions for enforcement of
owner or developer compliance. Any default or failure to comply may result in, but is not limited to, the following
section.

e)

1)

Withdrawal of certificate of occupancy;

2)

Foreclosure; or

3)

Specific performance.

In any action taken to enforce compliance with deed restrictions, the city attorney shall, if such compliance is
ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction, take all such action as may be permitted by law to recover all city's
costs of such action, including costs of legal services.

5.

"Density bonus units" shall be generally dispersed throughout a development project and shall not differ in appearance
from other units in the development.

6.

The city shall provide, in addition to a density bonus, at least one of the following regulatory concessions and/or
incentives to ensure that the multifamily residential project will be developed at a reduced cost:
a)

A reduction or modification of zoning ordinance requirements to allow a reduction in dwelling unit size and building
setback requirements that would otherwise be required;

b)

Approval of mixed use zoning in conjunction with the housing project if commercial, office, industrial or other land
uses will reduce the cost of the housing development and if the commercial, office, industrial or other land uses are
compatible with the housing project and the existing or planned development in the area where the proposed
housing project will be located;

c)
7.

Expedited processing of planning and building permits.

Following are those individuals who, by virtue of their position or relationship, shall be ineligible to purchase or rent a
unit provided pursuant to this program as their residence:
a)

All employees and officials of the city of Pomona or its agencies, authorities or commissions who have, by the
authority of their position, policy-making authority or influence affecting city housing programs.

b)

The immediate relative of employees of, and anyone gaining significant economic benefit from a direct business
association with such public employees or officials.

8.

In setting priorities among eligible households for a density bonus and other development incentives and/or
concessions, the first priority shall be given to residents of the city of Pomona.

9.

Maximum occupancy standards as set forth in the Uniform Housing Code shall be adhered to.

(Ord. No. 3724, § 3.)

Sec. .530. - Home occupations.
The following regulations shall apply to the conduct of a home occupation in any residential zone:
A.

Permit—Application.
1.

Permit. A home occupation permit shall be required prior to conducting any home occupation. The planning
division may issue a home occupation permit providing the following procedure is complied with.

2.

Application. The home occupation applicant shall file an application for his request as provided by the planning
division giving all the required information.

B.

Permit not Transferable. A Home Occupation Permit is not transferable. A permit for each new home occupation must be
185/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

applied for.
C.

Limitation on Type of Home Occupation. A home occupation shall be limited to an office.

D.

No Employment. No person shall be employed other than members of the resident family.

E.

Limitation on Number of Home Occupations. There shall be not more than one home occupation in any dwelling unit.

F.

Notwithstanding any provisions of this section to the contrary, any use not deemed detrimental to the subject area which
is conducted by physically handicapped persons or by persons for therapy, provided that in either case the applicant's
claim for handicap or therapy is supported by a written statement by a medical doctor or in the event that the applicant
is receiving services from an authorized rehabilitation agency by a written statement from this agency. In all cases it is
subject to a conditional use permit.

G.

Sales. No goods or products shall be sold or displayed on the premises.

H.

No Use of Commercial Delivery Vehicles. The use of commercial vehicles for the delivery of materials or equipment to or
from the premises is expressly prohibited.

I.

Storage. There shall be no storage of materials, supplies, and/or equipment in a garage, accessory buildings, or outdoors.
Stock-in-trade shall not change the residential use of any room.

J.
K.

Signs. No signs or other advertising of the premises shall be permitted.
Limitation on Area. A home occupation shall be confined entirely to one room in the dwelling and the entrance to such
space shall be within the dwelling. No garage or accessory building shall be used for a home occupation.

L.
M.

No Remodeling. No addition or remodeling is permitted in connection with the home occupation.
Clientele. No pedestrian or vehicular traffic shall be generated by the use. No customers, clients or other persons may
visit the premises for business purposes.

N.

Utilities. There shall be no utility connection added or established to serve the use.

O.

Appearance and Conduct. In no way shall the appearance of the structure be altered or the conduct of the home
occupation within the structure be such that the structure may be reasonably recognized as serving a nonresidential use,
either by color, lighting, signs, sounds, noises, vibrations, or any other similarity.

P.

Limitation on Equipment and Material. There shall be no use of material or mechanical equipment not recognized as
being part of reasonable household material and equipment.

(Ord. No. 2098, § 2; Ord. No. 2153, § 1; Ord. No. 2391, § 1 (part); Ord. No. 3131, § 1; Ord. No. 3623, § 7 (part).)

Sec. .530.1. - Termination of business license for home occupation.
When any home occupation results in an undesirable condition interfering with the general welfare and environment of the surrounding
residential area or any provisions of this section are violated, the home occupation shall be terminated by the planning director by giving
written notice thereof, and the business license of the particular home occupation shall be revoked and the fee forfeited by the city clerk. The
decision of the planning director is final, unless a written appeal is made to the planning commission within ten days after the giving of said
written notice. The planning commission may set a public hearing if deemed necessary. The decision of the planning commission is final, in
the absence of an appeal. Applicant or majority vote of city council may appeal planning commission decision to city council. City council
decision is final.
(Ord. No. 2098, § 3; Ord. No. 3623, § 7 (part).)

A.

Dressmaking, millinery, and other home sewing work.

B.

Handicraft, weaving and other arts and crafts.

C.

Laundering and ironing.

D.

Offices such as the following could be permitted provided all the other provisions and regulations of the home
occupation section are met:

1.

Professional;

2.

3.

Gardening service.

(Ord. No. 2098, § 4; Ord. No. 2455, § 2; Ord. No. 3623, § 7 (part).)

Sec. .530.3. - Uses expressly prohibited as home occupations.
The following uses are expressly prohibited as home occupations:
A.

Electrician shops;

Plumber shops;

C.

Repair or fix-it shops;

Uses which entail food handling, processing or packing other than specialized minor cooking and baking;

G.

Those which do not meet the provisions of the home occupation regulations;

H.

Those which, in the judgment of the city planner, would constitute an objectionable use of residentially zoned property
due to potential noise, increased pedestrian and vehicular traffic, or any other conditions which might interfere with the
general welfare and environment of the surrounding residential area.

(Ord. No. 2098, § 5; Ord. No. 2391, § 2; Ord. No. 2455, § 1; Ord. No. 3623, § 7 (part).)

Sec. .530.4. - Determination of home occupation uses allowed.
The city planner shall make the final determination when there is doubt or certainty as to whether or not a certain use should be allowed
as a home occupation. The decision of the city planner is final unless a written appeal is made to the planning commission within ten days
after the applicant has been notified of the city planner's decision.
(Ord. No. 2098, § 6; Ord. No. 3623, § 7 (part).)

Sec. .530.5. - Home occupation review.
The planning director may review any and/or all requests for a home occupation permit with the planning commission without prejudice
to the applicant. The planning commission may set a public hearing if deemed necessary.
(Ord. No. 2098, § 7.)

Sec. .531. - Prohibited home occupations.
Notwithstanding any of the provisions of Section .530 governing home occupations and notwithstanding any other provisions of this
ordinance, the following shall not be permitted as home occupations:
a.

The repair, reconditioning, servicing, or manufacture of any internal combustion or diesel engine.

b.

The repair, reconditioning, servicing, or manufacture of any motor vehicle, including automobiles, trucks, motorcycles or
motor bikes.

(Ord. No. 2069, § 1.)

Sec. .540. - Substandard lots of records.
If two or more adjoining and vacant platted lots with continuous frontage are in a single ownership at any time after the adoption of this
zoning ordinance and such platted lots individually are too small to meet the yard, width and area requirements of the district in which they
are located, such group of platted lots shall be considered as a single plot or several plots of minimum size and the plot or plots in one
ownership shall be subject to the requirements of this zoning ordinance, and all sections thereof.

Sec. .541. - Parking or storage of vehicles used primarily for commercial purposes; exemptions.
A.

It shall be unlawful to park or store a vehicle or trailer used primarily for commercial purposes in any residential zone or on
parcels of land used for residential purposes, except when such vehicles are present in the course of business.

A vehicle or trailer shall be deemed to be used primarily for commercial purposes:
(1)

If specialized equipment or material storage devices, or racks are visible on the vehicle; or

(2)

If a classification of operator's license other than a Class 3 classification is required to operate the vehicle on a public
street; or

(3)

If it is of a specialized nature that is commonly used for construction purposes, including but not limited to dump trucks,
cement trucks, backhoes, flatbed trucks; or

(4)

If the vehicle or trailer has been modified so as to serve as a portable self-contained sales or service oriented facility from
which a business activity/commercial transaction could occur. Acquisition of a Home Occupation Permit shall not serve to
exempt a vehicle or trailer from the provisions of this section.

B.

Exemptions—Scope, standards and procedure. It is recognized that the maintenance of the public health, safety and welfare
require that certain vehicles be available for prompt response and thus require such vehicles to be immediately accessible to
the operator. It is further recognized that the residential uses must, insofar as possible, be protected from unnecessary
disruption and intrusion of nonresidential activities. To accommodate these competing interests, the following exemption and
related restrictions have been developed:
1.

Qualifications for Exemption. No commercial vehicle shall be granted an exemption unless such vehicle is utilized in and
for the purpose of protecting and preserving the public health, safety and welfare. For the purposes of this section, the
public health, safety and welfare shall mean maintaining the operational and functional status of those facilities and
devices that benefit the public at large, such as roadways, pipelines, railway lines, communication lines, governmental
facilities and similar infrastructure elements. A presumption of such purpose shall apply to any commercial vehicle
owned and/or operated by either a governmental entity or a public utility. All other owners and operators of commercial
vehicles shall be required to submit an application for and obtain a permit which shall serve to authorize the vehicle to
be parked in an area of residential use subject to certain restrictions.

2.

Permit—Application Process.
(A)

The owner or operator of a commercial vehicle that seeks to have said vehicle qualified for and to receive a permit
shall apply for such permit in accordance with the following:
(1)

(2)

The applicant shall submit to the City Treasurer a written application setting forth:
(a)

Name, address, phone number and responsible party of the entity owning the vehicle;

(b)

Name and address of operator, including site where vehicle will be stored;

(c)

A description of the function or service the vehicle performs.

The Treasurer shall submit the application to the Fire and Police Departments for both a determination as to
whether the vehicle meets the requirement of being necessary to preserve and protect the public health,
safety and welfare, and a determination as to what restrictions on use are to be applied to the request.
(a)

Approved request: If the application is approved the Treasurer shall issue a permit, in the form of a decal
which shall be placed on either the lower left corner of the rear window or on the left side of the rear
bumper.

(b)

Denied request: If the request is denied, the applicant may appeal the denial pursuant to the process set
forth in Section 14-22.9 of the City Code.

(3)

Restrictions on usage: A permit shall be revoked if the following restrictions are violated:
(a)

The vehicle shall be parked on an approved surface, either on-street or off-street.

(b)

The vehicle's appearance shall be maintained in a clean and orderly manner.

(c)

The vehicle shall be operated in a reasonable manner that creates a minimum of visual and audible
disruption.

(d)

The departments set forth in paragraph (A)(2) of subdivision 2 of subsection B of this section may

establish additional specific restrictions that pertain to the site for which the permit is being sought.

Permit revocation process. Any person may file a written complaint with the Treasurer alleging that the

Sec. .550. - Nonconforming buildings and uses; intent and purpose.
Where buildings and/or the use of buildings and/or the use of land with or without structures are not in conformity with the provisions of
this zoning ordinance and where the uses of buildings and/or land are not compatible with the uses permitted in the zoning district in which
they are located or where such uses are specifically prohibited, it is the intent and purpose of this section, in part, to:
A.

Require, within a reasonable time, that said nonconforming uses be terminated; and

B.

Require nonconforming, incompatible buildings, to be, within a reasonable period of time, removed from the land upon
which they are located: and

C.

Prescribe a reasonable amortization period for said nonconforming buildings, which period will define the remaining
useful life of said buildings, after which the provisions set forth in subsection B of this section shall be applied; and also

D.

Prescribe a reasonable period of time for the termination of nonconforming uses of the land where no buildings are
involved.

Where buildings and/or the uses of buildings and/or the use of land with or without structures are not in conformity with the provisions
of this zoning ordinance and where said uses of buildings and/or land are compatible with the uses prescribed in the zoning district in which
they are located, it is the intent and purpose of this section, in part, to:
A.

Permit said uses to continue for an unspecified length of time.

B.

Prescribe limitations on the expansion of said nonconforming buildings and/or uses: and

C.

Prescribe the termination of said nonconforming buildings and/or uses when said buildings and/or uses have been
voluntarily discontinued for a specified period of time, and

D.

Define the amount of reconstruction or rebuilding that may be done if said nonconforming building is destroyed by fire
or act of God; and

E.

Provide for the improvement of nonconforming buildings and/or uses as may be required by law and/or where the
degree of nonconformity would be decreased.

All for the purpose of protecting the health, safety, welfare, convenience and prosperity of the persons residing or owning property in the
neighborhood and zoning district in which the nonconforming uses are found to exist.
Sec. .551. - Determination of compatibility of nonconforming buildings and uses.
The commission shall apply the following standards in determining the compatibility of a building or use in any residential, commercial
and industrial districts:
1.

All residential buildings, regardless of number of families provided for therein shall be deemed to be compatible unless:
(a)

Said building is structurally substandard as determined by the city buildings official; or

(b)

Said building deprives buildings and/or uses on abutting properties of light, air and privacy; or

(c)

Said building contains occupancies that are nonresidential in nature or classification in which cases said building
may be deemed to be not compatible.
189/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

2.

Any nonresidential building which has been converted to residential use which building meets all of the requirements for a
building set forth in subsection 1 of this section may be deemed compatible.

3.

Any nonresidential use of a residential building shall be deemed to be incompatible, excepting however, those home
occupation uses permitted by and subject to the conditions set forth in the Section .530 of the zoning ordinance.

4.

Any nonresidential use of land where said use is other than an open or agricultural use shall be deemed to be not
compatible.

(Ord. No. 3581, § 3 (part).)

Sec. .5512. - O -Site advertising abatement.
(A)

Removal of Nonconforming Billboards. Off-site advertising signage or billboards, as defined in Section .503-K, are permitted
only in an eligible display area, provided, the required conditional use permit and development agreement have been issued
and approved. All off-site advertising signage or billboards which were lawfully constructed at the time in which they were
erected which are outside an eligible display area, as defined by Section .503-K-G6, shall be deemed nonconforming. All offsite advertising signage which is erected within an eligible display area without obtaining the required conditional use permit
and development agreement shall be nonconforming, or which was erected outside an eligible display area with appropriate
building permits, conditional use permit or other requirements as set forth by law or this code abatement. Off-site advertising
or billboards which are nonconforming or become non-conforming through annexation, zone change, or other provisions of
this code, including approved amendments hereto, shall be removed within the following specified time period, whichever is
longer:
1.

On or before December 31, 1994; or

2.

The useful life adopted for such sign for the purpose of depreciation under Section 167 of the Internal Revenue Code of
1954.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, any sign owner or sponsor may allocate a sign area authorized by this code to a
noncommercial message.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, all signs deemed nonconforming must in all other respects be operated and
maintained so as not to create a nuisance or dangerous condition as set forth in the Pomona City Code and Zoning Code.
(B)

Request for Review.
1.

Filing of Application. A written application may be filed with the director of the community development department
requesting extension of the date a nonconforming off-site advertising sign must be abated. In addition to or in place of
the request for extension of the date for abatement, the applicant may request an alternate type or form of relief.
Applications must be filed with the director no later than sixty days prior to the date at which such sign must be
discontinued and removed.

2.

Administrative Hearing. Within fifteen days of the filing of the application with the director, the director shall cause to be
mailed to the applicant the day, time and location of an administrative hearing concerning the request for review. A
hearing officer shall be appointed by the city administrator to conduct, make findings and render a decision based upon
the application and relevant facts, both oral and written, submitted at the administrative hearing. The procedures for
conducting the hearing shall be the same as those found at Sections 5-18, 5-19, 5-20, and 5-21 of the Pomona City Code.

3.

Burden of Proof. In addition to the information required in the application, the applicant shall substantiate to the
satisfaction of the hearing officer the following facts:
a.

That to require discontinuation and removal of the sign in question would impair the property rights of any person
to such an extent as to be an unconstitutional taking of property; and

b.

That such sign does not now and will not during any extension period requested jeopardize, endanger or otherwise
constitute a menace to the public health, safety or general welfare.

4.

Findings and Decision. The hearing officer shall not approve an application for the extension of time from which to
discontinue and remove a nonconforming off-site sign or grant any other remedy requested by the applicant unless he
finds the burden of proof set forth in subsection B of this section has been met by the applicant. The hearing officer
190/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

shall, within fifteen days from the date the hearing is closed, file a written decision in the office of the city administrator.
Such decision shall contain a brief summary of the evidence considered and state the hearing officer's findings and
decision(s), and shall set forth that it is subject to California Code of Civil Procedure § 1094.6.
(Ord. No. 1983, § 3; Ord. No. 2115, § 1; Ord. No. 3685, § 3.)

All off-site advertising signs which lawfully existed at the time the land upon which they are situated had been annexed into the city after

alterations are made thereto; and further provided that such nonconforming off-site advertising signs shall be removed from the districts
where they are situated not longer than two years from July 23, 1975, unless ninety days prior to the expiration of the one-year period the
owner of the off-site advertising sign files a request for a hearing before the city planning commission pursuant to section .5513. If such
request is made substantially in the form provided in section .5513, a hearing shall be held by the commission under section .5513.

structural alterations are made thereto; and further provided that such nonconforming massage parlors shall be removed from the districts
where they are situated no longer than one year from the date of the ordinance codified in this section, unless within thirty days prior to the
expiration of the one-year period the owner of the massage parlor files a request for a hearing before the city planning commission pursuant
to Section .5513. If such request is made substantially in the form provided in Section .5513, a hearing shall be heard by the commission
under Section .5513.
(Ord. No. 2765, § 1; Ord. No. 3480, § 16.)

Sec. .55123 - Nonconforming rabbit and poultry ranches.
(a)

No person shall construct, conduct or maintain any poultry or rabbit ranch in any residential or commercial zone of the city.
Poultry and rabbit ranches now in lawful existence shall become a nonconforming use.

(b)

Where any buildings, structure or premises enjoying a nonconforming use are not conducted for such nonconforming use for
a continuous period of six months, such use shall cease.

(c)

No buildings, structures, or premises used in conjunction with any rabbit or poultry ranch and enjoying a nonconforming use
shall be extended or enlarged.

(Ord. No. 3224, § 2.)

Sec. .55125. - Nonconforming roominghouses.
All Roominghouses which lawfully exist, but are nonconforming to the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance, may continue; provided no
structural alterations are made thereto; and further provided that such nonconforming use shall be discontinued no longer than one year
from the date of adoption of the ordinance codified in this section, unless within thirty days prior to the expiration of the one-year period the
owner or operator of the Roominghouse files a request for a hearing before the Planning Commission pursuant to section .5513. If such
request is made substantially in the form provided in section .5513, a hearing shall be heard by the commission under section .5513.
(Ord. No. 4051, § 9.)

Sec. .5513. - Hearings to determine length of amortization periods.
The Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance may determine that certain uses and/or structures are nonconforming and require that the
nonconforming uses and/or structures be terminated within a time certain. In such event, the planning commission shall, upon the request
of an owner or lessee of the affected property, conduct a hearing to determine whether the termination date should be extended.
Such request shall be verified by the owner and shall set forth all facts and all contentions upon which the owner relies, including without
limitation:
191/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

(1)

The time which the owner contends is necessary to amortize the nonconforming use and/or structure;

(2)

If the nonconforming use and/or structure was purchased by the present owner, the date of purchase, the cost of the
purchase and all other facts of the purchase;

(3)

The date of construction and the cost of construction of the nonconforming use and/or structure;

(4)

The gross income for each year that the nonconforming use and/or structure was in existence;

(5)

All maintenance costs and taxes paid each year the nonconforming use and/or structure was in existence;

(6)

All contentions relating to the improper enactment of the ordinance codified in this section or any ordinance affecting
the owner declaring his use and/or structure nonconforming;

(7)

All facts known to the owner relating to any claim that the ordinance codified in this section or any ordinance affecting
the owner that declares his uses and/or structures nonconforming is unconstitutional under the state or federal
constitutions;

(8)

All contentions of the owner that the ordinance codified in this section or any ordinance affecting the owner that
declares his use and/or structure nonconforming that either such ordinance is vague or inapplicable to his use and/or
structure.

Said hearing shall be conducted within sixty days from the time said request is filed and evidence may be presented by the owner or
lessee or the city which might assist the planning commission in determining what additional period of time, if any, to permit the said use
and/or structure to remain and thereby relieve any undue hardship on the owner of said use.
At said hearing, the planning commission shall consider whether such use and/or structure is detrimental to the public health, safety and
general welfare, or is a nuisance. The planning commission shall find:
a.

That the condition of the improvements, if any, on the property is such that to require the property to be used only for
those uses permitted in the zone where it is located would not impair the constitutional rights of any person; and

b.

That the nature of the improvements is such that the improvements can be altered so as to be used in conformity with
the uses permitted in the zone in which such property is located or removed without impairing the constitutional rights
of any person.

Evidence at said hearing may be introduced to show the extent of private investment in said nonconforming use and/or structure; the
degree to which that investment would be jeopardized by a termination of the nonconforming use and/or structure; the age, condition and
physical characteristics, and nature of the nonconforming property, and the location of the nonconforming use and/or structure; and the
practical possibility that it may be relocated at a legally permissible site within or without the city without unreasonable expense, the range of
alternative but legally permissible uses to which the property could be put if the existing nonconforming use and/or structure were
terminated, and the salvage value of such use and/or structure; the value of such use and/or structure; the period of time required for
recovery of such value; depreciation timetables; cost of conversion or relocation; the effect of the nonconforming use on other property in
the area; and the monopoly or advantage, if any, resulting from the fact that similar new structures are prohibited in the same area; and any
other factors which might bear on the issues of the hardship to the owner or lessee of such nonconforming use and/or structure and the
removal of same without the impairing of the constitutional rights of any person; and as to whether said use is detrimental to the health,
safety and general welfare of the community, or is a nuisance.
The hearing will be informally conducted and the rules of evidence followed by the court shall not apply and hearsay evidence, otherwise
inadmissible in a court of law, shall be admissible, but the determination of the planning commission shall not be based solely on such
hearsay evidence. Any person requesting such hearing may be represented by counsel of his choice at all stages of the hearing.
At the conclusion of the said hearing, the planning commission shall, based upon the evidence, grant or deny the extension of time set
for the continued existence of the said nonconforming use and/or structure. The property owner or lessee may provide, at its own expense, a
certified shorthand reporter to transcribe the testimony at said hearing. In the event that such reporter is not provided, the minutes of the
secretary shall set forth the substance of the testimony of each witness. As a condition of granting such extension, the planning commission
may require the owner to consent in writing to the removal of the use at the end of such extension period and to post a cash bond to cover
the full cost of such removal.

192/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

The planning commission's decision shall be final ten days after notice thereof is sent by first class mail to the owner or lessee who
requested the hearing, unless said person requests within ten days after said notice was mailed in writing to the city clerk, that the city
council review the determination of the planning commission. The city council may decide within thirty days after the filing of such request,
whether or not to review the decision of the planning commission. In the event that the city council determines not to review the decision of
the planning commission (or takes no action), the decision of the commission shall be final thirty days after the request for the city council
review was filed with the city clerk. In the event that the council determines to review the decision of the planning commission, it shall
examine within a reasonable time after the decision to review was made, the verbatim transcript, or the secretary's minutes if a transcript is
not available including the documentary evidence introduced at such hearing. The council shall exercise its independent judgment on the
facts set forth in the transcript or minutes of the hearing and may affirm the decision of the planning commission or either extend or reduce
the amortization period determined by the planning commission. The council's decision shall be final upon the filing of its decision with the
city clerk. The clerk shall forthwith notify the owner or lessee who requested the planning commission hearing of the decision of the council.
(Ord. No. 2694, § 1.)

Sec. .552. - Repealed by Ordinance No. 3699.
Sec. .553. - Nonconforming buildings.
A nonconforming and noncompatible building may be continued, subject to the regulations set forth in this ordinance, provided no
additions or enlargements are made thereto and no structural alterations are made therein, excepting those required by law or ordinance. If
said nonconforming building is removed from the land, every future use of said premises shall be in conformity with the provisions of this
ordinance.
(Ord. No. 3581, § 3 (part).)

Sec. .554. - Nonconforming use of buildings and/or land.
A.

NONCONFORMING USE OF A NONCONFORMING BUILDING

Nonconforming uses in a nonconforming building may be expanded or extended throughout said building; provided, however, that
no structural alterations, except those required by law or ordinance shall be made therein; and provided, further, that the uses of said
building are not incompatible with the use of other property in the district. Further, if no structural alterations are made a
nonconforming use of a nonconforming building may be changed to permit a similar or more restricted type of nonconforming use;
provided, however, that said new use be determined by the commission to be more compatible with the uses permitted in the district.
B.

NONCONFORMING USE OF A CONFORMING BUILDING

The nonconforming use of a conforming building shall not be expanded or extended into any other portion of the conforming
building, and if such nonconforming use is discontinued for a period of two years, any future use of said building shall be in conformity
with the provisions of this ordinance; and further, that within five years after the notification by the city that an existing use is
nonconforming, and not compatible, said use shall be terminated. Conforming uses in said buildings may be expanded.
(Ord. No. 3699, § 3 (part).)

C.

NONCONFORMING USE OF THE LAND
1.

The nonconforming use of land, where no main buildings are involved, may be continued for a period not to exceed
three years after the effective date of this ordinance, subject to the following conditions:
(a)

No such nonconforming use of land shall be expanded or extended in any way either on the same or adjoining
property.

(b)

Where such nonconforming use of the land is discontinued for a period of two years any future use of the land shall
be in conformity with this ordinance.

(Ord. No. 3699, § 3 (part).)

(c)
2.

These provisions do not apply to land used for agricultural purposes.

Signs, billboards or commercial advertising structures which lawfully exist and where maintained at the time this
ordinance became effective may be continued, provided no structural alterations are made thereto; and further
193/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

provided, that all such nonconforming signs, billboards or commercial advertising structures shall be removed from the
district not later than five years from the effective date of this ordinance.
During the interim five year period, said nonconforming signs, billboards, or commercial advertising structures shall be maintained and
kept in good repair and good visual appearance.
D.

BUILDING SETBACKS MADE NONCONFORMING BECAUSE OF STREET WIDENING:

When because of street widening or other public works property is taken for public use or voluntarily dedicated to public use which
results in setbacks for an existing building less than that required within the zoning district where such building is located such as
resulting setback shall not be considered making such building nonconforming and shall not be considered incompatible with the
neighborhood on account of such reduced setbacks.
(Ord. No. 2325, § 1.)

E.

NONCONFORMING/COMPATIBLE ONE FAMILY DWELLING

Additions or enlargements may be allowed to nonconforming/ compatible one family dwellings if the following standards are met:
(a)

The new addition or enlargement does not exceed more than 25% of the existing gross square feet of the existing one
family dwelling unit.

(b)

The new addition or enlargement shall comply with all the R-1-10,000 zone Development Standards.

(Ord. No. 3581, § 3 (part).)

Sec. .554B-1. - Nonconforming use of theater in a conforming building.
In the case of nonconforming theater uses, all are declared to be incompatible. Nonconforming theater uses in conforming buildings
where structural alterations to the building or fixtures are in place which cannot physically be removed without severely damaging the
building specially designed for theater uses do not totally exceed in current market value the sum of three thousand dollars, shall be
discontinued within six months after such theater use becomes nonconforming and notice thereof given by the planning department staff to
the proprietor of the theater use and to the owner of the real property as shown on the last equalized assessment roll or as known by the
planning department staff; provided, however, that if the proprietor of the theater or owner of the property requests an additional six
month's period, such a hearing shall be granted and evidence may be presented showing the current value of such alterations and fixtures.
After such hearing, if the city council determines the current value of such alterations and fixtures are in excess of three thousand dollars,
then the ordinary amortization for nonconforming uses in a conforming building shall apply. The city council may, however, even if it finds
that the value of such alterations does not exceed three thousand dollars, grant up to an additional six month's extension if it determines
discontinuance at the end of the initial six months would work an extreme hardship upon the proprietor of the theater or the owner of the
real property upon which the theater use is located.
(Ord. No. 2518, § 1.)

Sec. .555. - Amortization period for nonconforming, incompatible buildings.
A.

FOR NONRESIDENTIAL USES IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.

Every nonconforming, incompatible use shall be completely removed or shall be so altered that it will be in conformity with the uses
permitted in the district and that nonconforming, incompatible building shall be completely removed from the land within the time set
forth in subsection B of this section.
B.

TIME SCHEDULE FOR REMOVAL OF NONCONFORMING, INCOMPATIBLE BUILDINGS
1.

Type 1 and 2 construction *—twenty years.

2.

Type 3 and 4 construction * (fire resistant)—fifteen years.

3.

Type 5 construction *—ten years. * as defined in the uniform building code. These time limits shall be applied to all
nonconforming, incompatible buildings beginning on the effective date of this ordinance. This time table shall be deemed
to provide for the amortization of the affected buildings.

C.

EXTENSION OF AMORTIZATION PERIOD
