7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Nonresidential uses in a residential district may be allowed to remain beyond the established amortization period defined in Section
.555 B; provided, that a petition be signed by a majority of the residents in the district whose properties are within a radius of five
hundred feet of the external boundaries of the subject use, and that the council, after a public hearing requiring all-public notifications
established in Section .560-E, and the presentation of the above petition and its verification, adopt a resolution granting an extension for
a specific period of time and with such conditions as may be deemed proper and necessary to protect the surrounding properties.
Sec. .556. - Reconstruction of nonconforming/compatible buildings.
The provisions of this ordinance shall not prevent the reconstruction, repair or rebuilding of any nonconforming/ noncompatible building
damaged by fire, explosion or act of God or the enemy, subsequent to effective date of this ordinance; provided, however, that the cost of
such reconstruction, repairing or rebuilding shall not exceed fifty percent of the reasonable replacement value of the building immediately
prior to damage.
A nonconforming/compatible one family dwelling unit in commercial and/or industrial zones shall be exempt from the provisions of this
section. If a nonconforming/compatible one family dwelling unit is damages by fire, explosion or act of God or the enemy subsequent to
effective date of this ordinance, it may be reconstructed if the following conditions are satisfied:
(a)

The rebuilt one family dwelling shall comply with all current R-1-10,000 Development Standards and shall not be
expanded more than 25% of the original size of the one family dwelling; and

(b)

The rebuilt one family dwelling shall comply with all current Off Street Parking Standards.

(Ord. No. 3581, § 3 (part).)

Sec. .558. - Reversion to nonconforming use.
Any portion of a nonconforming building or use, which is altered or changed to a conforming use, shall not thereafter be used for a
nonconforming use.
Sec. .559. - Elimination of temporary, nonconforming residential buildings.
If on the effective date of this ordinance, a temporary one family dwelling shall lawfully exist on the rear half of a lot in an "R-1" district,
and where said lot is of record, a dwelling or dwellings as permitted by the regulations of the district in which the subject lot is located, may
be erected on the front portion of said lot; provided, however, that within thirty days after the granting of an occupancy permit by the city for
the use of the newly constructed building, the temporary dwelling shall be made to conform with the requirements of the district in which it
is located.
Sec. .5595. - Poultry processing plants and animal slaughtering facilities—Amortization period.
Poultry processing plants and animal slaughtering facilities in existence on or before May 14, 1957 in any zoning district other than an
"M-1" or "M-2" zone are nonconforming uses. Such non- conforming uses shall be permitted to exist as nonconforming uses for three years
after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. In the event that an owner of a nonconforming poultry processing plant or
an animal slaughtering facility claims that such amortization period creates undue hardship he may request an additional period of time to
amortize such use under the provisions of Section .5513 comprehensive zoning ordinance. Such request shall be filed with the planning
commission ninety days prior to the expiration of the amortization period set forth in this section. The failure to request an extension of the
amortization period shall be a conclusive admission that the three-year period is legally and economically sufficient to amortize the
nonconforming use.
(Ord. No. 1685, § 2; Ord. No. 3428, § 1.)

Sec. .5596. - Non-conforming manufactured housing developments.
Any manufactured housing development that does not have Sections .480 through .487, the Residential-Manufactured Housing
Development Zone (R-MHD) applied to the development shall be considered a non-conforming use of the land.

195/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Any manufactured housing development that is determined to be a nonconforming use shall be allowed to continue and shall have
applicable all the rights described in the non-conforming use statutes.
Any manufactured housing development that is determined to be a non-conforming use shall also have applicable Sections .484, .485,
.486, and .487 contained in the Residential-Manufactured Housing Development Zone (R-MHD). These sections shall be applied whenever a
Change-of-Zone, Change-of-Use, or Conversion to Condominium Ownership application is submitted to the Planning Department. The
provisions contained in these sections shall be followed in their entirety in conjunction with the application.
(Ord. No. 3137, § 3.)

Sec. .560. - Variances.
Editor's note—
1. Prior ordinance history: Ordinances 1821, 2050, 2070, 2076, 2134, 2709, 3131, 3398 and 3427.
A.

GENERAL. When practical difficulties, unnecessary hardships, or results inconsistent with the general purpose of this
ordinance result through enforcement of the provisions hereof, the planning commission shall have authority, as an
administrative act, subject to the provisions of this ordinance, to grant upon such conditions as it may determine, such
variance from the provisions of this ordinance as may be in harmony with its general purpose and intent, so that the spirit of
this ordinance shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. No variance shall be granted
which would have the effect of granting a special privilege not shared by other property in the same vicinity and zone.

A variance shall not be granted for a parcel of property which authorizes a use or activity which is not otherwise expressly authorized
by the zoning regulations governing the property. Any variance granted shall be subject to such conditions as deemed necessary by the
planning commission to assure the adjustment thereby authorized allows all findings of fact.
B.

REQUIRED FINDINGS FOR VARIANCE. Prior to the granting of any variance, other than a variance of the off-street parking
requirements for nonresidential uses, the planning commission shall make all the following findings of fact:
1.

That there are special circumstances applicable to the property including but not limited to size, shape, location,
topography or surroundings that deprive such property of privileges enjoyed by other property in the vicinity and under
identical zoning classification.

2.

That the granting of the variance will not constitute a special privilege inconsistent with the limitations upon other
properties in the vicinity and zone in which the property is situated.

3.

That the granting of the variance will be consistent with the provisions of any Specific Plan, or the adopted General Plan.

4.

That the granting of the variance will not be materially detrimental or injurious to the surrounding properties nor to the
general development pattern of the neighborhood.

Prior to the granting of a variance of the off-street parking requirements for any nonresidential use, the planning commission
shall make the following findings of fact:
5.

That the amount of parking provided is adequate to accommodate the proposed use(s). The public works director, or
designee, shall prepare a report which evaluates the adequacy of the parking for such proposed use(s).

6.

That the granting of the variance will not create a safety hazard or interfere with the free flow of traffic both on and off
site.

(Ord. No. 3716, § 3.)

C.

APPLICATION PROCEDURE. Applications for variances shall be filed by the property owner or authorized agent upon forms
provided by the planning division. Before accepting an application for variance, the planning division shall charge and collect a
filing fee as established by resolution of the city council.

D.

PUBLIC NOTICE AND HEARINGS.
1.

Within thirty calendar days of receiving an application planning division shall determine completeness of application.

2.

The secretary of the planning commission shall place the item on a planning commission agenda for public hearing not
more than thirty days after the date of the application being deemed complete.

3.

Notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the community not less than ten days
196/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

before the date set by the commission for the hearing. The notice shall contain data pertinent to the case, including date,
time, place of hearing and location of documents for review.
4.

Written notice shall be mailed in the United States mail not less than ten days prior to the date of the meeting, to owners
of property within a radius of four hundred feet from the external boundaries of the property described in the
application, using for this purpose the last known name and address of such owners as are shown on the tax roll of the
county of Los Angeles. Such written notice shall contain pertinent data related to the case. No posting of any notice shall
be required, other than that required by State Law.

5.

The commission shall hold a public hearing upon the application and shall make a determination and announce its
decision at a regular meeting or special meeting. Said decision shall approve, approve with stated conditions, or deny the
application, and shall set forth findings in support of the decision.

6.

The decision shall, within twenty days, be filed with the commission secretary, and a copy thereof shall be mailed to the
applicant at the address shown on the application by the Secretary.

E.

CONDITIONS TO USE.
1.

The commission, in approving a variance, may set forth in its decision conditions deemed necessary to protect the public
health, safety and welfare, or to be in the interest of the community, such conditions may include but are not limited to
the following:

Regulation of use;
Special yards, spaces, and buffers;
Special fences, solid fences, and walls;
Surfacing of parking areas;
Street, parkway, sidewalk, service road, or alley dedications and improvement or appropriate bonds;
Regulation of signs;
Regulation of points of vehicular ingress and egress;
Requiring landscaping and maintenance thereof;
Requiring maintenance of the grounds;
Regulation of noise, vibration, odors;
Regulation of hours for certain activities;
Time period within which the proposed use shall be developed;
Hours of use;
Posting of a bond or bonds sufficient to guarantee the removal of any nonconforming structures or uses of the land upon the expiration of
the period of the conditional use permit;
Requiring the dedication of access rights;
Considering aesthetic concerns as they relate to land use and neighborhood compatibility; and
Such other conditions as will make possible the development of the city in an orderly and efficient manner.
2.

The acceptance of any of the benefits of such grant shall constitute acceptance of the burdens and the conditions
attached thereto.

3.

The attaching of conditions shall be construed as an integral part of the grant, without which the application would
otherwise be denied. The invalidation or failure to comply with any condition shall invalidate the entire grant.
197/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

F.

APPEAL OF PLANNING COMMISSION DECISION.
1.

Written appeals may be filed with the city clerk, by one or more city councilmembers, by the applicant, or by any person
owning property within four hundred feet of the exterior boundaries of the applicant's property.

2.

Four copies of an appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within twenty days from the date of action by the planning
commission.

(Ord. No. 3959, § 2.)

3.

Fee. Before accepting an appeal, the city clerk shall charge and collect a filing fee except of appeals instituted by city
council. Such fee shall be as established by a resolution of the city council.

4.

An appeal shall specifically state the specific nature of the appeal, grounds thereof and wherein the planning commission
erred or failed to conform to the requirements of this ordinance.

5.

The city clerk shall immediately transmit one copy of said appeal to the planning division and if the appeal has been
made by someone other than the applicant, one to the applicant.

6.

Said appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed until the determination of the appeal as provided
herein.

7.

The city clerk shall place the appeal on the agenda of the city council within thirty days of the date of appeal. The clerk
shall forward the appeal; planning commission staff report; planning commission minutes and planning commission
resolutions to the city council. At its discretion, the city council may set the matter for public hearing or uphold the
decision of the planning commission upon the facts presented.

8.

Upon majority vote of city council to hold a hearing on the appeal, the city clerk shall place the item on the agenda for
city council not less than fourteen days nor more than forty-five days from the date of the decision to hear. The city
council shall hold a hearing of the facts as presented to planning commission on the matter. The city clerk shall give
notice of such hearing in the manner prescribed in Section .560-D.

9.

The city council may approve, approve with conditions or deny the project application. In doing so the city council must
make written findings of fact setting forth findings wherein the property or particular use involved meets or fails to meet
the qualifications set forth in this ordinance.

10.
G.

An appeal may be withdrawn at any time prior to the date and time of the public hearing by the appellant.

MODIFICATION. Any condition imposed upon the granting of a variance, including such granted prior to the adoption of these
regulations, may be modified or eliminated, or new conditions may be added, providing that the granting body shall first
conduct a public hearing thereon, in the same manner as is required for the granting of the same. A modification may be
initiated by the community development director, granting body or property owner. If the modification is initiated by the
applicant, the applicant shall pay the same filing fee as required by the original application. The applicable expiration period
shall be extended for a period equal to that required for processing the modification. No such modification shall be made
unless the granting body finds that such modification is necessary to protect the public peace, health and safety, or in case of
deletion of such a condition, that such action is necessary to permit reasonable operation under the variance as granted. If the
modification hearing is conducted by the commission, its decision shall be subject to review on appeal, taken in the time and
manner set forth in Section .560-F.

H.

REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
1.

Revocation proceedings may be initiated by a majority vote of the granting body, or majority vote of city council or the
community development director.

2.

The body which granted a variance shall conduct a noticed public hearing to determine whether such variance should be
revoked. This revocation procedure shall apply to permits or variances granted prior to as well as after the adoption of
these regulations. If the granting body finds any of the following facts to be present, it may revoke the variance:
a.

That the variance or permit was obtained by fraud; or

b.

That the permit or variance granted is being, or has been, exercised contrary to any conditions imposed upon such
permit or variance, or in violation of any law; or

c.

That the use for which the approval was granted is being exercised so as to be detrimental to the public health or
safety, or as to constitute a nuisance; or
198/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

d.

That the neighborhood has changed substantially since the permit or variance was granted so that the use is no longe
surrounding neighborhood.
(1)

If the granting body determines that facts of either b. or c. are present, and that such facts can be corrected
and are not likely to recur, it may suspend, rather than revoke, a variance for a period of time that it deems
appropriate for the implementation of corrective measures.

(2)

If the revocation hearing is conducted by the commission, its decision shall be subject to review on appeal,
taken in the time and manner set forth in this chapter.

3.
I.

Effect of Revocation. The revocation of a variance shall have the effect of denying the privileges granted by the variance.

LAPSE.
1.

A variance shall lapse and shall become void at the time specified in the resolution approving such variance or if no time
is so specified one year following the date on which the approval became effective unless prior to the expiration of one
year, a building permit is issued and work is commenced and diligently pursued toward completion on the site which was
the subject of the application, or a permit is issued authorizing occupancy of improvements to the site or structure which
was the subject of the application, or the site is occupied if no building permit or certificate of occupancy is required;
provided that if litigation is filed prior to the exercise of such rights attaching the validity of such variance or permit, the
time for exercising such rights shall be automatically extended pending a final determination of such litigation.

2.

A variance may be extended twice for an additional period of one year provided that prior to the expiration of one year
from the date when the approval or the renewal became effective, an application for renewal of the variance is filed with
the planning division.
a.

Application for extension must be received prior to the date of expiration.

b.

The variance shall remain valid from the time of application for extension until the matter is heard by the granting
body.

c.

Prior to granting the second extension of such a variance, the approving authority must find, based upon
substantial evidence submitted by the applicant, that all of the following exist:
(1)

The applicant has made a consistent, progressive, good-faith effort to exercise his variance within the one-year
period following its initial extension;

(2)

The applicant has been prevented or otherwise inhibited in his efforts to exercise such variance by
unreasonable conditions beyond his control. Such conditions may include, but not necessarily be limited to,
requirements imposed by other governmental agencies;

(3)

Substantial evidence does not currently exist which would justify revocation of the variance. Such evidence
must not have existed at the time of approval of the original variance, or if such evidence did exist, it must not
have been capable of production at that time with the exercise of reasonable diligence;

(4)

The variance will not be contrary to or in violation of any currently adopted policy, ordinance, rule or
regulation;

(5)

Only the applicant (owner or developer) who originally received approval for the variance may be granted a
second extension.

(Ord. No. 3673, § 2.)

3.

A variance shall remain in effect during operation of the same use or business for which it was granted within substantial
conformance. A termination or cessation of use shall not terminate the variance unless or until a new and distinct use is
established.

(Ord. No. 3699, § 4.)

J.

MINOR DEVIATION VARIANCES.
1.

Purpose. The purpose of this section is to grant authority to the city planner to take action on requests for minor
deviations to certain requirements of this ordinance when such requests constitute a reasonable use of property not
permissible under the regulations herein. For the purpose of administering this section, a minor deviation variance is any
deviation to the terms or requirements of this ordinance which, if granted, would allow the following:
a.

A decrease of not more than twenty percent of the required width or depth of a lot when total lot area
199/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

requirements are met.
b.

A decrease of not more than twenty percent of the required width of a front, rear or side yard or the required yard
between buildings.

c.

An increase of not more than two feet in the permitted height of a fence or wall, subject to the review and
conditions of the public works director.

d.

A decrease in the number of required parking spaces of not more than twenty percent when total required spaces
are at least thirty spaces.

e.

An increase of not more than ten percent in the maximum allowable lot coverage.

f.

A decrease in parking aisle or space width of not more than ten percent.

g.

A decrease of ten percent in the minimum floor area of residential units.

h.

A decrease of ten percent in landscaping islands size or total landscaping requirements within parking areas.

i.

An increase of not more than twenty percent of the maximum allowable sign area and an increase of not more than
ten percent of the maximum allowable sign height.

(Ord. No. 3731, § 3.)

j.

Properties which are unable to provide trash facilities for multi-family residential developments pursuant to Section
.5809-17-D-1 due to property constraints (e.g., size, shape and topography). A site plan shall be prepared and
submitted by the applicant demonstrating that the subject property is unable to provide the required trash
facilities.

(Ord. No. 3878, § 6.)

k.

For arbors located in the front yard setback area and in street facing side and rear yards setback areas, an increase
of not more than two feet in the maximum width between the inside edges of the posts provided that shall not
increase the roof square footage by more than ten square feet of the maximum square footage of the roof area.
(Ord. No. 4118, § 21.)

2.

Upon the filing of an application and payment of fee as set by resolution of city council for a minor deviation variance,
the city planner, without publishing, posting of notice, or public hearing, shall consider and render decisions on said
applications. If he finds that facts exist justifying the granting of the minor deviation variance requested, he shall grant
the same in writing stating the reasons therefor subject to such conditions as it may find to be necessary to protect the
public peace, health, safety, morals or general welfare, he shall transmit a copy of said decision to the applicant within
thirty days. If the city planner does not find that such facts exist, he shall deny the application in writing with findings and
transmit a copy of such denial to the applicant.

If the city planner denies an application for a minor deviation variance, or if the applicant disagrees with the conditions imposed
on the granting of a minor deviation variance, if any, the applicant may file for a variance in accordance with Section .560-C.
(Ord. No. 3633, § 4.)

Sec. .570. - Amendment of Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance—Exception.
Any amendment of the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance of the city of Pomona, except for the application of a zoning district to
individual parcels of property within the city, shall be made in the same manner as the adoption of ordinances pursuant to Article V of the
Charter of the City of Pomona.
(Ord. No. 3308, § 3.)

Sec. .571. - Changes of zone for individual parcels of property.
Any change of zone for any one or more parcels of property shall be made in the following manner:
A.

INITIATION OF PROCEEDINGS

Such changes may be initiated by the council, commission or owner or bona fide agent of the owner of any land or building. A
petition for change of zone shall be filed on forms provided by the city for this purpose, and shall be duly signed and verified by the
petitioner. (The petitioner shall also furnish the commission a list of the names and addresses of the owners required to be notified
200/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

as provided by subsection D-2(a) of this section.) Upon receipt of such petition and list of names, the commission shall fix the time
and place of public hearing thereon not less than fifteen days or more than forty days thereafter.
(Ord. No. 1821, § 1.)

C.

HEARINGS ON PETITION
1.

The commission shall hold one public hearing upon the matters referred to in such petition and thereupon within
forty days of said hearing shall make a determination and report thereon to the council.

2.

The council, after receipt of the report and recommendation, or on its own initiative, shall after one public hearing,
either approve, modify or reject the same.

D.

NOTICING FOR PUBLIC HEARING
1.

Legal notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than ten
days before the date of the hearing. The notice shall contain data pertinent to the case, including date, time, place
of hearing and location of documents for review.

2.

In addition to the item No. 1 of this subsection, written notice shall be mailed in the United States mail not less than
ten days prior to the date of the hearing, to the affected property owners and owners of property within a radius of
four hundred feet from the external boundaries of the property described in the application, using for this purpose
the last known name and address of such owners as are shown on the tax roll of the county of Los Angeles. Such
written notice shall contain pertinent data related to the case.

3.

If the properties in an area proposed for change of zone exceeds one thousand in number, written notice shall be
mailed in the United States mail not less than ten days prior to the date of the hearing, to only those property
owners in the area affected by the proposed change of zone. Such written notice shall contain pertinent data
related to the case. In addition, notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in
the city, as described in item No. 1 of this subsection.

(Ord. No. 2199, § 1; Ord. No. 3766, § 2.)

E.

LIMITATION ON TIME FOR ADOPTION OF ZONE CHANGE ORDINANCE AFTER HEARING.

No ordinance making an amendment for a change of zone shall be adopted any later than one year after the conclusion of the
hearing concerning said proposed change of zone; however, as soon as possible after a hearing at which the city council indicates its
approval, and in any event not later than sixty days after the hearing, the staff shall present to the city council the zone change
ordinance amendment for action. If conditions are imposed for such zone change at the conclusion of the hearing of the city council,
such conditions imposed shall either be met before the zone change amendment ordinance is finally adopted or the zoning
amendment ordinance when adopted shall provide that such zone change shall not become effective until such conditions are met.
A new application must be made or initiated and a new hearing conducted if the formal ordinance making such change of zone is
not adopted within one year after city council approval.
(Ord. No. 2389, § 1; Ord. No. 3131, § 5; Ord. No. 3308, § 2.)

Sec. .580. - Conditional Use Permits.
A.

GENERAL. Certain uses, and all matters directly related to such uses, are declared to be uses possessing such unique and
special characteristics as to make it impractical for them to be automatically included within some or any of the zoning
districts defined in this ordinance. The location and operation of any of these uses shall be subject to the review and issuance
of a conditional use permit (CUP).

The purpose of such review shall be to determine whether the characteristics of any such use are compatible with the types of uses
generally permitted in the surrounding area, and further, to stipulate such reasonable conditions as may be deemed necessary to assure
that the basic purposes of this ordinance are being served.
B.

REQUIRED FINDINGS FOR CONDITIONAL USE PERMITS. Prior to the granting of a conditional use permit, the planning
commission shall make the following findings of fact:
1.

That the proposed use at the particular location will contribute to the general wellbeing of the neighborhood or
community;
201/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

2.

That such use will not, under the circumstances of the particular case, be detrimental to the health, safety, peace, or genera
persons residing or working in the vicinity or detrimental to the use, valuation or enjoyment of property or improvements in

3.

That the site for the proposed use is of adequate topography, size and shaped to accommodate said use, as well as all
yards, spaces, walls, fences, parking, loading, landscaping, and any other features necessary to allow said use with the
land and uses in the neighborhood and make it compatible thereto;

4.

That the site abuts streets and highways adequate in width and improvements to carry traffic generations typical of the
proposed use;

5.

That the granting of such conditional use permit will not adversely affect the General Plan of the city, or any other
adopted plan of the city and conforms to the provisions of the zoning ordinance.

C.

APPLICATION. Applications for conditional use permits shall be filed by the property owner or authorized agent upon forms
provided by the planning division. If the project requires phasing, then the application shall contain a precise description of
each proposed phase and the timing thereof. In all other respects the public hearing procedure shall be the same as Section
.560-D. (variances). Before accepting an application for conditional use permit, the planning division shall charge and collect a
filing fee as established by resolution of the city council.

D.

PUBLIC NOTICE AND HEARINGS.
1.

Within thirty calendar days of receiving an application planning division shall determine completeness of application.

2.

The secretary of the planning commission shall place the item on a planning commission agenda for public hearing not
more than thirty days after the date of the application being deemed complete.

3.

Notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the community not less than ten days
before the date set by the commission for the hearing. The notice shall contain data pertinent to the case, including date,
time, place of hearing and location of documents for review.

4.

Written notice shall be mailed in the United States mail not less than ten days prior to the date of the meeting, to owners
of property within a radius of four hundred feet from the external boundaries of the property described in the
application, using for this purpose the last known name and address of such owners as are shown on the tax roll of the
county of Los Angeles. Such written notice shall contain pertinent data related to the case. No posting of any notice shall
be required, other than that required by State Law.

5.

The commission shall hold a public hearing upon the application and shall make a determination and announce its
decision at a regular meeting or special meeting. Said decision shall approve, approve with stated conditions, or deny the
application, and shall set forth findings in support of the decision.

6.

The decision shall, within twenty days, be filed with the commission secretary, and a copy thereof shall be mailed to the
applicant at the address shown on the application by the secretary.

E.

CONDITIONS TO USE. 1. The commission, in approving a conditional use permit, may set forth in its decision conditions
deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare, or to be in the interest of the community, such conditions
may include but are not limited to the following:

Regulation of use;
Special yards, spaces, and buffers;
Special fences, solid fences, and walls;
Surfacing of parking areas;
Street, parkway, sidewalk, service road, or alley dedications and improvement or appropriate bonds;
Regulation of signs;
Regulation of points of vehicular ingress and egress;
Requiring landscaping and maintenance thereof;

202/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Requiring maintenance of the grounds;
Regulation of noise, vibration, odors;
Regulation of hours for certain activities;
Time period within which the proposed use shall be developed;
Hours of use;
Posting of a bond or bonds sufficient to guarantee the removal of any nonconforming structures or uses of the land upon the expiration of
the period of the conditional use permit;
Requiring the dedication of access rights; and
Such other conditions as will make possible the development of the city in an orderly and efficient manner.
2.

The acceptance of any of the benefits of such grant shall constitute acceptance of the burdens and the conditions
attached thereto.

3.

The attaching of conditions shall be construed as an integral part of the grant, without which the application would
otherwise be denied. The invalidation or failure to comply with any condition shall invalidate the entire grant.

F.

APPEAL OF PLANNING COMMISSION DECISION.
1.

Written appeals may be filed with the city clerk, by one or more city councilmembers, by the applicant, or by any person
owning property within four hundred feet of the exterior boundaries of the applicant's property.

2.

Four copies of an appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within twenty days from the date of action by the planning
commission.

(Ord. No. 3959, § 3.)

3.

Fee. Before accepting an appeal, the city clerk shall charge and collect a filing fee except for appeals instituted by city
council. Such fee shall be as established by a resolution of the city council.

4.

An appeal shall specifically state the specific nature of the appeal, grounds thereof and wherein the planning commission
erred or failed to conform to the requirements of this ordinance.

5.

The city clerk shall immediately transmit one copy of said appeal to the planning division and if the appeal has been
made by someone other than the applicant, one to the applicant.

6.

Said appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed until the determination of the appeal as provided
herein.

7.

The city clerk shall place the appeal on the agenda of the city council within thirty days of the date of appeal. The clerk
shall forward the appeal; planning commission staff report; planning commission minutes and planning commission
resolutions to the city council. At its discretion, the city council may set the matter for public hearing or uphold the
decision of the planning commission upon the facts presented.

8.

Upon majority vote of city council to hold a hearing on the appeal, the city clerk shall place the item on the agenda for
city council not less than fourteen days nor more than forty-five days from the date of the decision to hear. The city
council shall hold a hearing of the facts as presented to planning commission on the matter. The city clerk shall give
notice of such hearing in the manner prescribed in Section .560-D.

9.

The city council may approve, approve with conditions or deny the project application. In doing so the city council must
make written findings of fact setting forth findings wherein the property or particular use involved meets or fails to meet
the qualifications set forth in this ordinance.

10.
G.

An appeal may be withdrawn at any time prior to the date and time of the public hearing by the appellant.

MODIFICATION. Any condition imposed upon the granting of a conditional use permit, including such granted prior to the
adoption of these regulations, may be modified or eliminated, or new conditions may be added, providing that the granting
body shall first conduct a public hearing thereon, in the same manner as is required for the granting of the same. A
modification may be initiated by the community development director, granting body or property owner. If the modification is
initiated by the applicant, the applicant shall pay the same filing fee as required by the original application. The applicable
203/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

expiration period shall be extended for a period equal to that required for processing the modification. No such modification
shall be made unless the granting body finds that such modification is necessary to protect the public peace, health and
safety, or in case of deletion of such a condition, that such action is necessary to permit reasonable operation under the
conditional use permit as granted. If the modification hearing is conducted by the commission, its decision shall be subject to
review on appeal, taken in the time and manner set forth in Section .560-F.
H.

REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT.
1.

Revocation proceedings may be initiated by a majority vote of the granting body, or majority vote of city council or the
community development director.

2.

The body which granted the conditional use permit shall conduct a noticed public hearing to determine whether such
conditional use permit should be revoked. This revocation procedure shall apply to permits granted prior to as well as
after the adoption of these regulations. If the granting body finds any of the following facts to be present, it may revoke
the conditional use permit:
a.

That the permit was obtained by fraud; or

b.

That the permit granted is being, or has been, exercised contrary to any conditions imposed upon such permit, or in
violation of any law; or

c.

That the use for which the approval was granted is being exercised so as to be detrimental to the public health or
safety, or as to constitute a nuisance; or

d.

That the neighborhood has changed substantially since the permit was granted so that the use is no longer
compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.
(1)

If the granting body determines that facts of either b. or c. are present, and that such facts can be corrected
and are not likely to recur, it may suspend, rather than revoke, a permit for a period of time that it deems
appropriate for the implementation of corrective measures.

(2)

If the revocation hearing is conducted by the commission, its decision shall be subject to review on appeal,
taken in the time and manner set forth in this chapter.

3.

Effect of Revocation. The revocation of a conditional use permit shall have the effect of denying the privileges granted by
the permit.

I.

LAPSE.
1.

A conditional use permit shall lapse and shall become void at the time specified in the resolution approving such
conditional use permit or if no time is so specified one year following the date on which the approval became effective
unless prior to the expiration of one year, a building permit is issued and work is commenced and diligently pursued
toward completion on the site which was the subject of the application, or a permit is issued authorizing occupancy of
improvements to the site or structure which was the subject of the application, or the site is occupied if no building
permit or certificate of occupancy is required; provided that if litigation is filed prior to the exercise of such rights
attaching the validity of such variance or permit, the time for exercising such rights shall be automatically extended
pending a final determination of such litigation.

2.

A conditional use permit may be extended twice for an additional period of one year provided that prior to the expiration
of one year from the date when the approval or the renewal became effective, an application for renewal of the
conditional use permit is filed with the planning division.
a.

Application for extension must be received prior to the date of expiration.

b.

The conditional use permit shall remain valid from the time of application for extension until the matter is heard by
the granting body.

c.

Prior to granting the second extension of such a conditional use permit, the approving authority must find, based
upon substantial evidence submitted by the applicant, that all of the following exist:
(1)

The applicant has made a consistent, progressive, good-faith effort to exercise his conditional use permit
within the one-year period following its initial extension;

(2)

The applicant has been prevented or otherwise inhibited in his efforts to exercise such conditional use permit
by unreasonable conditions beyond his control. Such conditions may include, but not necessarily be limited to,
204/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

requirements imposed by other governmental agencies;
(3)

Substantial evidence does not currently exist which would justify revocation of the conditional use permit.
Such evidence must not have existed at the time of approval of the original conditional use permit or, if such
evidence did exist, it must not have been capable of production at that time with the exercise of reasonable
diligence;

(4)

The conditional use permit will not be contrary to or in violation of any currently adopted policy, ordinance,
rule or regulation;

(5)

Only the applicant (owner or developer) who originally received approval for the conditional use permit may
be granted a second extension.

(Ord. No. 3673, § 3.)

3.

A conditional use permit for all uses excluding auto service stations, dance halls, auto repair and on- and off-sale alcohol
licenses shall remain in effect during operation of the same use or business for which it was granted within substantial
conformance, except as provided otherwise. A termination or cessation of such use shall not terminate the conditional
use permit unless or until a new and distinct use is established.

(Ord. No. 3699, § 5.)

J.

The following uses shall be permitted in the zones indicated, provided that a conditional use permit shall first be obtained
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter:

Sec. .5801. - Conditional use permit required for use of minibikes, motor-bikes, trail-bikes, motorcycles, and other similar vehicles.
(a)

DEFINITIONS: As used in this section, "mini-bike, motor-bike, trail-bike, motorcycle, or other similar vehicle" mean, in addition
to the ordinary accepted meaning and usage of these terms, any two-wheel, gasoline-propelled engine vehicle, excepting lawn
mowers, or any vehicle having more than two wheels as defined in Section 415 of the California Vehicle Code.

(b)

No mini-bike, motor-bike, trail-bike, motorcycle, or other similar vehicle shall be ridden, driven or used upon land in any
zoning district which has not been approved by a conditional use permit. This prohibition shall not, however, apply to:
(1)

Authorized emergency vehicles as defined in California Vehicle Code 165; or

(2)

Those operated upon paved parking lots or structures open to the public; or

(3)

Those operated upon property primarily used for motorcycle or motor driven cycle retail or wholesale, service or repair,
manufacture, or distribution, but operated in a manner not to be offensive and which shall not disturb the peace and
quiet of the general neighborhood; or

(4)

Those generally used in conjunction with construction, agricultural or industrial uses and used solely in conjunction with
said uses in a manner not to be offensive and which shall not disturb the peace and quiet of the general neighborhood;
or

(5)

Those operated upon private roadways or easements necessary for ingress to and egress from property used for those
purposes designated in Subsections (2), (3) and (4) above; or

(6)

The owner or lessee of the property or any other person having in his possession written permission signed by the
owner or lessee of the property providing such use is at least one hundred feet from the property line of any residential
use unless written permission is given by the residents or persons in possession of such residential use and further
providing such permission is not given for any valuable consideration or such use is not commercial in nature.

The enforcement of this section shall be by the Pomona police department's police officers which may issue citations to anyone who
rides, drives, or uses a mini-bike, motor-bike, trail-bike, motorcycle, or other similar vehicle upon property contrary to the provisions of this
section, and police officers are further authorized to enter vacant land when such prohibited use is clearly visible to them and they may issue
citations or make arrests providing they have made themselves aware of all places in the city where conditional use permits for such uses
have been granted and they thereby know that the land upon which such mini-bikes, motor-bikes, trail-bikes, motorcycles, or vehicles are
being ridden, driven, or used has not been granted a conditional use permit for such use. Furthermore, the planning department shall by
written memorandum keep the police department informed of all land in the city for which conditional use permits have been granted for
the riding, driving, and use of mini-bikes, motor-bikes, trail-bikes, motorcycles, or other similar vehicles.
(c)

STANDARDS: In addition to any other standards appropriate and determined necessary for the granting of a conditional use
permit for land to be used for riding, driving, and use of mini-bikes, motor-bikes, trail-bikes, motorcycles, or other similar
vehicles, the following minimum standards shall be applicable to all such conditional use permits:
(1)

The location shall be a sufficient distance from any residential uses so the noise generated shall not be offensive to the
residential uses;

(2)

Competent supervision shall be provided at all times to insure that such use is conducted in an inoffensive manner to the
neighborhood and to insure that the use does not extend beyond the premises for which the conditional use permit is
issued;

(3)

The land for which the conditional use permit is issued shall be fenced in such a manner which will adequately contain
such use within the premises granted the permit;

(4)

A plan for dust control shall be submitted and approved in connection with the conditional use permit, and shall be
enforced in the operation of such use;
219/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

(5)

Such other conditions in addition to the above standards may be imposed to insure that such use shall not be detrimental t
surrounding neighborhood;

(d)

A conditional use permit issued pursuant to this section may be issued for a specified and limited period of time and
terminate at the end of such period. If renewal is sought, it shall be done through the same procedure for an original
conditional use permit. Any conditional use permit granted pursuant to this section may be terminated by the city council at
any time if the conditions imposed upon its granting are violated or if such use is determined by the city council after ten days'
notice to the person holding the conditional use permit and a hearing held and findings made that such conditions have been
violated or that such use, despite the conditions, has, nevertheless, become a nuisance and no additional conditions can be
imposed that would prevent it from continuing to be a nuisance.

(e)

DEDICATED PUBLIC STREETS EXCLUDED: Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the use of mini-bikes, motorbikes, trail-bikes, motorcycles, or other similar vehicles on publicly dedicated streets in accordance with provisions of the
Vehicle Code of the state of California.

(Ord. No. 2424, § 1.)

Sec. .5804. - Standards of development, conditions, and restrictions upon automobile service stations and super service stations.
All automatic service stations, automobile service stations, super service stations, trucking stations and service stations shall be allowed
in designated zoning districts by conditional use permit. Before granting the planning commission or the city council, if on appeal, shall make
the following findings:
A.

That the proposed business is compatible with existing commercial development in the area.

B.

That the proposed location is sufficiently removed from any existing or proposed residential development or zoning so
as not to be detrimental to the residential area. However, in the case of any district which has been designated as
freeway oriented, it shall be presumed that such use shall not be detrimental to the surrounding residential
neighborhood unless such presumption is rebutted by clear and substantial evidence to the contrary.

C.

That the proposed building and site are adequate to accommodate the proposed use and that the design of the facility is
such that a minimum of conflict will occur with adjoining uses.

The planning commission or city council, if on appeal, shall also find that the following development standards, conditions and
restrictions have been complied with:
A.

AUTO-RELATED AND NON-RELATED RETAIL ITEMS:
1.

Open racks or unenclosed stacks of merchandise shall be prohibited on a pump island.

2.

Other retail products may be displayed outside of the station building. However, these products shall not be
allowed at random, but must be enclosed in a movable display rack or structure that can be opened for public view.
These displays shall be confined to an area within five feet of the main station building.

B.

REPAIR WORK:
1.

All repair work shall be performed in an enclosed area or building except that usual driveway services such as
changing of a battery, replacing a fan belt, installing a window wiper blade and so forth may be permitted outside of
an enclosed area.

2.

Major repair shall be limited to service stations (with the facilities required by building regulation contained in the
Uniform Building Code of the city of Pomona for this activity), in the "C-3," "C-4," "C-IND.," "M-l" and "M-2" districts.
"Major repair" is defined as any extensive disassembly of components of the engine, clutch, transmission and
differential. Open flame welding, use of flammable liquids, body, frame and fender repair, painting, tire recapping,
or upholstery work shall also be considered major repair work. Where major repair work is performed, it shall be
conducted according to the standards for repair garages as set forth in the Uniform Building Code of the city of
Pomona.

3.

All repair work shall be conducted in such a manner that it shall not create a disturbance or become a nuisance to
the surrounding properties.

C.

SITE LOCATIONS:
220/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

1.

When zoned for such use, service stations, shall be permitted only when the site is situated at the intersection of arter
collector streets, and abutting freeway ramps as defined in the circulation element of the city's master plan. However,
is proposed to be located on a service road or abutting freeway ramps catering to freeway traffic or located in an "H-R,
and "M-2" zones catering to the highway traffic, automobile service stations may be located on an interior lot.

D.

DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS:
1.

Automobile and Automatic Service Stations:
(a)

Corner site. The minimum area of a corner site for an automobile service station shall be twenty thousand
square feet with a minimum frontage of one hundred forty-five linear feet on each street. *

(b)

Interior site. Where an interior lot is allowed for automobile service stations, the minimum area for this type of
site shall be fifteen thousand square feet, with a minimum frontage of one hundred fifty linear feet on one
street and a minimum depth of one hundred feet.*

2.

Super service station site. The minimum area for all super station sites shall be thirty-size thousand square feet,
with a minimum frontage of three hundred linear feet on one street and a minimum depth of one hundred feet.*

* Corner cut-off areas and areas for required future street-widening can be deducted from the required minimum site areas.
3.

Existing service stations. The rebuilding of a service station on an existing site with less dimensions as outlined in
this section will not be prohibited by the provisions of this ordinance. A conditional use permit is required for the
conversion of an existing service station to an automatic service station.

4.

Minimum size of building. The minimum building size of the main building on the site shall be one thousand square
feet.

5.

Architectural treatment. Architectural treatment of the "precise plan of development" shall be approved by the
planning commission subject to appeal to the city council. Building design shall be compatible with the
neighborhood or surrounding area of the site and shall not be of such a nature to be detrimental to property values
in the area. When the site is adjacent to a residential area, a building of residential character (such as a low-profile,
ranch-type) shall be required. In a planned industrial or commercial area, the service station building shall conform
to the exterior architectural design of other structures in the planned development. The "precise plan of
development" to be submitted for review shall include the following:

6.

(a)

Plot plan and floor plan.

(b)

Landscape and parking plan.

(c)

Elevation plans of buildings, signs, walls, lighting, and all other structures on the site.

Setbacks. Building setback shall be no less than twenty feet from any street property line and fifteen feet from any
interior property line. Canopies shall have the following setbacks unless the zoning district requires a greater
setback.
(a)

Detached canopies shall project to no less than five feet from any property line.

(b)

Canopies attached to the station building shall project to no less than eight feet from any property line.

(c)

Pump islands for all service stations shall have the following setbacks:

Gasoline pumps, or other facilities upon which they are placed shall be set back a minimum of twelve feet from the property
line; however, if the pumps or the island upon which the pumps are located are set in a perpendicular position to any street or
property line, or if the pumps or islands are at any other position than parallel to a property line, the setback shall be a
minimum of twenty feet, so that all vehicular traffic by the pumps shall be far enough away from the property line so that there
will be no hazard to pedestrians walking or traveling upon the sidewalk adjacent to the subject property. For automatic service
stations, the distance between dispensing units on the same pump is and shall be a minimum of twenty feet.
8.

Curb cuts and driveways. No curb cut shall be closer than two feet from an interior property line or be closer than
thirty-five feet from the projected intersection of the two curb lines along the street frontages, providing however
no drive approach shall encroach in the curb return area. The curb distance around the corner between the two
corner driveways shall be painted red by the city to prevent on-street parking in this area. Driveways shall have a

221/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

width of thirty feet at the sidewalk plus four feet transitions on each side. Entrance to a service station side from an
abutting alley or shopping center may be allowed. (Existing stations would not be required to meet these curb cut
requirements.)
9.

Access standards. The city traffic engineer shall review and make recommendations regarding proper and safe
circulation for the patrons and the traveling public which may include, but not limited to: Number of automobile
storage spaces in waiting line; limiting on-street parking; visibility for safe sight distance for ingress and egress;
design of parking lot, etc.

10.

Paving and drainage. The entire ground area of the site, except for building and planting areas, shall be paved with
asphaltic concrete to standards set by the engineering and building departments. Drainage flow lines shall be
shown on the plot plan and if drainage is to street, water must be carried under sidewalks in a manner approved by
the city engineer.

11.

Gasoline fill pipes. Fill pipes for underground gasoline storage tanks shall be located no less than fifteen feet from
any property line, or further if so required by the fire and safety code.

12.

Screening of restrooms. All restroom entrances shall be screened from view of adjacent property of public right-ofway by solid or louvered material or landscaping.

13.

Storage facilities:d
(a)

Storage and rentals of trailers, trucks and other equipment shall be allowed only in the "C-3," "C-4" and "CIND.", "H-R", "M-1" and "M-2" zoning districts. However, such storage uses being conducted on the effective
date of the enactment of this section in the "C-l ," "C-C" and "C-2" zones shall not be determined incompatible
and may be continued as prior existing nonconforming uses.

(b)

Trucking stations shall be permitted as super service stations in the "C-3," "C-4," "C-IND.," "M-l" and "M-2"
zoning districts. Outdoor storage of cars not capable of moving under their own power (junk cars) shall not be
allowed on any service station site for longer than forty-eight hours.

14.

Trash areas. All outside trash areas shall have a minimum area of seven feet by ten feet (inside dimensions) and
shall be surrounded by a six-foot high solid wall which is constructed of noncombustible materials compatible with
the main building. All trash, debris, old parts, junk and similar material shall be stored within this designated trash
area. The enclosure may be designed to accommodate metal refuse containers (dumpsters) on wheels and shall
have an opening with a minimum width of five feet clearance. A solid, double swinging gate, such as a chain-link
gate with metal strips woven to form an opaque screen, is required for the opening for the trash enclosure, and the
opening shall not be visible to the usual pedestrian and vehicular traffic. The gate shall be the height of the wall and
shall have a maximum clearance of two inches from ground level.

15.

Walls. A decorative masonry wall shall be required separating any service station* use from a residential use and/or
a residential district. It shall be constructed at the time the service station main building is constructed. The height
of the wall shall be six feet, except immediately adjacent to the front yard setback of any residential use next to the
service station, and in such event the height shall be thirty-six inches. No wall shall be required separating a service
station use from another commercial use; however, in the case of a service station being located adjacent to a
shopping center area or an alley, a planter shall be required separating the service station from such shopping
center area or alley. The planter as herein specified shall comply with Subdivision 19 hereof. Openings in such
planter may be made to allow access to and from said adjacent shopping center area. However, such openings may
only be permitted upon approval by the city engineer to insure that no traffic hazard may be created thereby.

*For automatic service stations, a six foot-high decorative masonry wall on all interior property lines is required, except
where an existing building is situated on a property line of the site. (Ord. No. 4118, § 17.)
16.

Utilities. All utilities, including electric and telephone, shall be placed underground.

17.

Parking. Permanent parking of vehicles on any service station site is required to provide off-street parking spaces
for and is limited to the following: Vehicles which are in the process of being serviced, vehicles belonging to
employees of the station, and no more than two trucks, other than rental trucks, when used by the business except

222/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

when permitted by the police department for tow truck service to the city. Regular parking of up to four tow trucks
and temporary overnight parking for customers' trucks or towed-in vehicles may only be allowed in super service
stations, and additional landscaping shall be required because of the increased parking area on the site.
Parking is prohibited where it will impede the view of traffic in the public streets. A "diagonal" shall be drawn from the inside
edge of the two-corner curb cuts, and no parking or commercial activities shall be allowed in the area between the "diagonal"
and the intersection. Any vehicle or equipment waiting for service or repair shall not be permitted to be parked for longer than
forty-eight hours on the station site. Notwithstanding any provisions of this section, the site shall be provided with the minimum
amount of parking space as required by the zoning district in which it is located. All required parking shall conform to the
standards of Section .503-H.
18.

Lighting. For stations adjacent to residential areas, all lighting exterior of a building shall be of an indirect nature. It
shall be so arranged and shielded that there shall be no glare or reflection onto adjacent properties or public rightof-way. For all other locations (other than when adjacent to a residential area) the lighting shall be reviewed and
approved by the planning commission to insure that such lighting is compatible with the surrounding area and does
not create a nuisance.

19.

Landscaping. Final details of landscaping shall be approved through review of the precise plan of development by
the planning commission subject to the following standards: A minimum of five percent of the service station's lot
area shall be provided with landscaping. Planters of not less than four feet net inside dimension width shall be
located along street frontages, except for driveway areas. A planter of not less than one hundred fifty square feet
shall be located at the corner of the intersection of the street property lines where corner sites are required. ln
reverse station design, the entire area between the back of the station building and street intersection corner shall
be provided in planters of not less than four feet net inside dimension in width to be placed along interior property
lines and around perimeter of building. Planters around the building perimeter shall not be less than two feet net
inside dimension. However, the landscaping may be provided in such a manner so that it will not be located to the
rear of the station building unless it abuts a residential zone, in which case additional trees shall be planted to serve
as a buffer behind the station building. Planters shall be protected by a masonry curb not less than six inches in
height. All planters shall be equipped with a permanent irrigation system as specified by the city parks department.
All plantings shall be maintained by the operator of the station. Planting materials with low heights such as shrubs
and ground covers shall be such that will not achieve a height of more than thirty inches, not be of a spiked or
thorny type, and be maintained not to droop over the perimeters of the planter when in locations abutting the
public right-of-way. Plants achieving a greater height shall be required along interior property lines, but shall be
reduced in height where access is permitted to an abutting alley or shopping center area twenty feet on each side
of such entrance. Trees subject to parks department approval shall be planted in all planters except in the planter
at the corner intersection. Trees shall be planted at a maximum distance of thirty feet apart unless an alternate plan
which yields a similar effect is approved by the parks department.

20.

Limitation of service equipment. Automobile, super or trucking service stations may be constructed in conjunction
with a restaurant, providing parking is provided for the customers in an area separate from the area required for
that particular type of service station and that access to the restaurant is safe and not in conflict with the service
station.

21.

Abandoned service stations. The property owner shall remove at his expense any gasoline dispensing devices, signs
and storage tanks that are situated at a facility that has been vacant for a continuous period of one hundred eighty
days or more.

22.

No person shall convert any building or facility of a service station or car wash to a different use unless such
conversion shall have been approved by a conditional use permit.

23.

The planning commission may require any other standards or criteria it finds necessary to protect the safety and
welfare of the surrounding property owners or the public.

Uses allowed within the Los Angeles County fairgrounds.

permit for a specified time period during construction or remodeling of permanent buildings.

home park or residential uses as listed in the uses permitted section.

approved commercial (trailer) coach.

C.

Uses in commercial coaches not listed above, shall be allowed only by an approved conditional use permit on a six-month basis. Before
approving the conditional use permit, the planning commission shall find that the requested commercial coach is not detrimental to the
surrounding area and that all requirements of the code of the city of Pomona are met. The planning commission may extend the allowable
time period up to an additional six-month period upon written request by the applicant at least thirty days prior to the expiration date.
(Ord. No. 2470, § 1.)

5.

SKILL GAME CENTERS.
A.

Definitions:
1.

Skill Game Machine shall mean any machine, apparatus, contrivance, appliance, or device which may be operated
or played upon the placing or depositing therein of any coin, check, slug, ball, or any other article, and involving in
its use either skill or chance for the purpose of game, entertainment or amusement, the object of which is to
achieve either a high or low score, which by comparison to the score of other players, whether currently playing or
not, demonstrates relative skill or competence, or indicates in any other way competitive advantages of player or
team over another. It shall include all electronic, mechanical, and video games, or any other similar machine or
device.

2.

Amusement Machine shall mean any machine, apparatus, or device which may be operated by depositing a coin,
token or similar device, which is used for amusement, and shall include such items as a juke box, children's rides, or
225/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

other equipment, where no competition, score, skill, or chance is involved.
3.

Skill Game Center shall mean a group of ten or more skill game machines in the same place, location, or premises
for use by and to the amusement of the public. This does not include facilities storing or displaying skill game
machines strictly for the purpose of manufacture, retail sales, rentals, or service, or where the use of such machines
is not made available to the general public; or where the skill game machines can be classified as an accessory use
as defined below. Skill game centers shall be permitted by conditional use permit procedures.

4.

Accessory Use. The placement and operation of the skill games shall be considered as an accessory use to the
primary business activity if the following criteria is applicable:
a.

If the gross floor area of the business is less than six thousand square feet, then no more than five percent of
this G.F.A. shall be allocated to the skill games.

b.

If the gross floor area of the business is equal to or greater than six thousand square feet, then no more than
two percent of this G.F.A. shall be allocated to the skill games. Skill game machines placed and operated as an
accessory use, regardless of numbers, shall be subject to the provisions of subsection F of this section only.

B.

Application: For any nonresidential zone the provisions of this section regulating the installation and operation of skill
game machines shall be applied according to the total number of machines made available for use based on the
following schedule:
(1)

1-4 skill games—No development requirements.

(2)

5 or more skill games—Shall conform to standards of development pursuant to subsection F of this section.

(3)

10 or more—When defined as a skill game center, pursuant to subsection A(3) of this section, shall be allowed by
conditional use permit, pursuant to subsection E of this section.

C.

Intent and Purpose: The purpose of this section is to provide a minimum standard of development to be applied to the
installation of skill game machines to insure that the public health, safety, and welfare is maintained, and that their use
will be functionally related and compatible with adjacent commercial uses, and will not be a detriment to surrounding
land uses.

D.

Business Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any business proprietor to install or operate any skill game machine
without first having obtained a business permit from the city clerk in accordance with the provisions of and pursuant to
Chapter 14 of Ordinance No. 1673, as amended pursuant to Ordinance No. 3121 and any further amendments thereto.

E.

Skill Game Center Requirements: Skill game centers shall be permitted in the C-3, C-C, and C-4 zoning districts and shall
be allowed by conditional use permit, subject to all restrictions of each zoning district, the standards of development
contained in subjection F of this section, and the following criteria:
1.

Skill game centers located within one thousand three hundred twenty feet of any public or private primary or
secondary school shall not operate during normal school hours (seven a.m. to three p.m.). except on weekends and
school holidays. This distance shall be measured from the entrance of the commercial facility to the nearest school
property line.

2.

Skill game centers shall not be located within five hundred feet of any residential zone located along the same
street frontage. This distance shall be measured from the entrance of the commercial facility to the nearest
boundary of the adjacent residential zone.

3.

Business operating hours shall be limited to between the hours of nine a.m. to twelve midnight.

4.

The possession, consumption, or sale of alcoholic beverages and/or tobacco or other similarly smoked products
within the premises of a skill game center is prohibited. Readily visible signs indicating this prohibition of drinking
and smoking within the premises are to be prominently displayed throughout the skill game center and shall be
enforced by supervisory personnel on the site.

5.

This permit is nontransferable. Any change in tenants or operators of the premises shall require a new conditional
use permit

6.

The installation of skill game machines in excess of the number approved per the conditional use permit shall
require planning commission approval of a modification to the conditional use permit.

(Ord. No. 3385, § 38.)

226/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

F.

Standards of Development: These standards apply to the installation of five or more skill game machines in any nonresiden
1.

Adequate space shall be provided for each machine so as to allow its use without overcrowding. The floor area
devoted to the placement of skill game machines shall be a minimum of one machine for every twenty-five square
feet of game floor area. Where machines are located along one side of an aisle, said aisle shall be a minimum of six
feet in width and shall be unobstructed. When machines are located on both sides of any aisle, the aisle shall be a
minimum of nine feet in width and shall be unobstructed.

2.

In skill game centers, or if the skill games are operated as a single use business, the game area shall be located
entirely within an enclosed building open to public view. All exterior windows are to be left unobstructed to
facilitate outside surveillance of the premises. When the skill game machines are not operated as a single use
business, they shall be located in a separate room, or within a single concentrated space, separated from other
uses on the premises and from pedestrian circulation to and from such other uses.

3.

At least one adult supervisor, twenty-one years of age or older, shall be provided and be present on the premises
during all hours of operation. Additional adult supervisors may be required.

4.

The layout of the building interior shall be designed in a manner such that surveillance of the entire game room is
possible from the employee's primary work position.

5.

Interior lighting of the game room shall be maintained at or above the minimum standard of one watt per square
foot of game floor area.

6.

Exterior lighting of the premises shall be maintained at or above the minimum level of one and one-half footcandles
per square foot of paved surface adjacent to all exterior walls of the building or portion thereof where the games
are located. The lighting shall be properly directed and shielded to prevent stray light from falling on adjacent
properties.

7.

If the premises are used primarily for the serving or consumption of alcohol, the use of skill game machines by
persons under the age of twenty-one is prohibited at all times. Readily visible signs indicating this prohibition shall
be prominently displayed throughout the premises. This restriction shall be enforced by supervisory personnel on
the site.

8.

Persons under the age of sixteen not accompanied by and under the supervision of a responsible adult shall be
prohibited from using the games during the normal academic year for Pomona public schools before the hour of
three p.m., except during school holidays and on Saturdays and Sundays, nor after the hour of ten p.m. on all days
preceding school days. Readily visible signs indicating this prohibition shall be prominently displayed throughout
the premises. This restriction shall be enforced by supervisory personnel on the site.

9.

Public restroom facilities for both men and women shall be provided and made available on-site within the same
premises where the games are located.

10.

Adequate change and/or tokens used to operate the games shall be maintained and made available on the
premises where the games are located.

11.

A designated bicycle parking area shall be provided near the entrance to the skill game facility.

12.

Waiting area shall be provided within the premises where the games are located to prevent waiting clientele from
interfering with adjacent and off-site uses.

(Ord. No. 2731, § 5; Ord. No. 3173, § 1.)

6.

The establishment or expansion of trucking facilities as defined in Section .062, shall be allowed by conditional use permit only
in the M-l, M-2, light and general industrial zone districts, subject to all the restrictions of those zones, and in compliance with
the following special standards and criteria:
A.

Findings: Before granting a conditional use permit for a trucking facility the planning commission shall make the
following findings:
1.

That the proposed trucking facility development is compatible with and will not be detrimental to any existing use
or business in the area;

2.

That the proposed location is sufficiently removed from any existing or proposed residential development or zoning
so as not to be detrimental to the residential area;

227/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

3.

That the proposed buildings and site improvements are adequate to accommodate the proposed use and that the ove
facility is such that a minimum of conflict will occur with adjoining uses;

4.

That the surrounding streets and their abutting uses are adequate and will not be adversely impacted by the
proposed use.

B.

Special Standards: Because of the extensive effects of trucking facilities on surrounding properties, on city streets and
highways, and on the economic well-being and physical growth of the community, the following special standards shall
apply to these facilities:
1.

The total area of the premises utilized as trucking facilities shall not exceed five acres or be less than one acre.

2.

Expansion of an existing trucking facility may be permitted, provided that the total area of the facility (after
expansion) does not exceed five acres.

3.

The required twenty-five-foot front yard may be used for the parking of employees' and customers' passenger
vehicles, but shall not be used for the parking or storage of trucks, truck trailers, or truck tractors or other
specialized equipment associated with the trucking facility.

4.

All areas used for parking or storage of trucks or truck trailers shall be surfaced with an all-weather surfacing
material. Areas where trucks are serviced or parked for short periods of time shall be paved with asphalt, asphalticconcrete, or concrete. Areas used for the storage or parking of trailers may be surfaced with a minimum of five
inches of slag or crushed rock. All paving and surfacing shall be reviewed by the building and planning divisions for
compliance.

5.

All trucking facilities shall have a building or buildings containing offices, restrooms, and changing rooms for the
truckers. Minimum floor area used for these purposes shall be one thousand square feet.

6.

All major repair of engines or other components shall be done inside a totally enclosed building. Other work on
vehicles may be conducted outside of a totally enclosed building provided such area is paved and covered by a
canopy or other structure built in conformance with the Uniform Building Code. Such area shall be immediately
available to a totally enclose building or repair garage where tools and parts are stored.

7.

All areas behind the twenty-five-foot front yard setback shall be completely enclosed by a six-foot high fence. A sixfoot high solid masonry wall with opaque gates shall be erected at or behind the twenty-five-foot front yard setback
where visible from a public street.

8.

Property owners displaced by action of the city of Pomona redevelopment agency would be allowed to relocate on
a parcel of like size provided that all other development standards conform to the standards herein contained
except that a conditional use permit shall not be required. Such relocation shall occur on or before eighteen
months from the date of the redevelopment agency action. However, in emergency situations, an additional
eighteen months may be granted at the discretion of the city administrator and/or the director of community
development.

(Ord. No. 3226, § 1.)

BILLIARD OR POOL HALL.

Defined. A public poolroom is a commercial establishment, open to the public, where fifty percent or more of the floor

Sec. .5809-4(B). - Repealed by Ordinance No. 3335.
Sec. .5809-5. - Adult-oriented businesses.
A.

Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the City by
regulating Adult-Oriented Businesses. The provisions of this section have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a
limitation or restriction on the content of any communicative materials, including adult-oriented materials. Similarly, it is not
the intent nor effect of this section to restrict or deny access by adults to adult-oriented materials protected by the First
Amendment of the United States Constitution, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of adult-oriented
entertainment to their intended market. Neither is it the intent nor effect of this ordinance to condone or legitimize the
distribution of obscene material.

B.

Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them by this subsection:
1.

Adult-Oriented Businesses. "Adult-oriented businesses" means any one of the following:
a.

Adult Arcade. The term "adult arcade" as used in this section, is an establishment where, for any form of
consideration, one or more still or motion picture projectors, or similar machines, for viewing by one (1) person per
machine, that are used to show films, computer-generated images, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or other
photographic reproductions that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon the depiction or
