Unless otherwise indicated, all appeals shall be made in writing stating the reason(s) for appeal. Such appeals shall be filed with the
planning division within twenty (20) days of the decision on the application for a certificate of appropriateness. The receipt of a written
appeal shall stay all actions, or put in abeyance all permits or other discretionary approvals which may have been granted, pending the
effective date of the decision on the appeal.
Appeals shall be scheduled for the earliest regular meeting of the hearing body, not less than fifteen (15) days or more than fortyfive (45) days after the date of filing an appeal, consistent with the agenda preparation procedures and scheduling of the commission
and city council meetings as the case may be.
H.

Economic Hardship. The commission shall not issue certificates of appropriateness which are not in compliance with
subsection F-6 unless the findings for economic hardship are met. Application for economic hardship shall be made on a
form(s) provided by the planning division and may be filed concurrent with the application for a certificate of appropriateness.
1.

The commission shall schedule a public hearing concerning the application and provide notice in the same manner as in
subsection F of this section and any person may testify at the hearing concerning economic hardship in the same
manner as provided in subsection H-3.

2.

The commission shall review all evidence and information required of an applicant for economic hardship and make a
determination within fifty (50) days of receipt of the application whether the denial of a certificate of appropriateness has
deprived, or will deprive, the owner of the property of the reasonable use of, or economic return on the property.
Written notice of the determination shall be provided in the same manner required by subsection F of this section.

3.

If the applicant presents facts and clear evidence demonstrating to the commission that failure to approve the
application for certificate of appropriateness will cause immediate and substantial economic hardship, the commission
may then approve in part or in whole the application based upon economic hardship. Economic hardship is defined as a
substantial cost to the owner of the property which is patently unreasonable in comparison to the benefit conferred to
the community should the owner be limited to following guidelines for preserving or protecting the property. The
commission shall hold a public hearing in order to determine whether a certificate of appropriateness shall be approved
or denied when economic hardship is involved. If the certificate of appropriateness is approved in such a case a written
determination shall state that economic hardship is the reason for its findings.

4.

The commission shall weigh the following factors as appropriate, in evaluating applications for economic hardship:
247/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

a.

Denial of the application will affect the value of the subject property so as to diminish substantially its value;

b.

The sale or rental of the property is impractical when compared to the cost of holding such property for uses
permitted in this zone;

c.

An adaptive reuse study has been conducted and found that utilization of the property for lawful purposes is
prohibited or impractical;

d.

Rental at a reasonable rate is not feasible;

e.

Denial of the certificate of appropriateness would damage the owner of the property unreasonably in comparison
to the benefit conferred on the community; and

f.

All means involving city sponsored incentives such as tax abatements, financial assistance, building code
modifications, amendments to the zoning ordinance, loans, grants, and reimbursements have been explored to
relieve possible economic hardship.

5.

The commission shall be authorized to request the applicant to furnish material evidence supporting his request for a
finding of economic hardship. Evidence shall consist of any of the following as deemed necessary by the commission:
a.

Cost estimates of the proposed work and estimate of the additional cost(s) that would be incurred to comply with
the recommendations of the commission.

b.

A report from a licensed engineer or architect with experience in rehabilitation as to the structural soundness of
any structures on the property and their suitability for rehabilitation.

c.

Fair market value of the property from an appraiser in its current condition, estimated market value after
completion of the proposed construction, exterior alteration, demolition, or removal; after any changes
recommended by the commission; and in the case of a proposed demolition, after renovation of the existing
property for continued use.

d.

In the case of a proposed demolition, an estimate from an architect, an appraiser, or other professional
experienced in rehabilitation as to the economic feasibility of rehabilitation, relocation, or reuse of the existing
structure on the property.

e.

For income-producing properties, information on the annual gross income, operating and maintenance expenses,
depreciation deductions, and annual cash flow after debt service, and current property taxes.

f.

Remaining balance on any mortgage or other financing secured by the property and annual debt service, if any, for
the previous two years and any appraisals obtained within the previous two years by the owner or applicant.

g.

Amount paid for the property, the date of purchase, and the party from whom purchased, including a description of
the relationship between the owner of record or applicant and the person from whom the property was purchased;
any listing of the property for sale or rent, price asked, and offers received, if any, within the previous two years.

h.

Assessed value of the property according to the most recent assessments and property taxes for the two previous
years.

i.

Form of ownership or operation of the property, whether sole proprietorship, limited partnership, joint venture or
other.

j.

Any other information considered necessary by the commission to make a determination of economic hardship,
and to determine whether the property does yield or may yield a reasonable return to the owners.

6.

In considering an application for economic hardship, the commission shall make a finding that without approval of the
proposed demolition, exterior alteration, remodeling, removal, or construction, the reasonable use of or return from a
designated landmark or property within an historic district will be denied a property owner. In this context, personal
financial difficulties or loss of quantifiable anticipated profits may be considered, but are not alone justifiable hardships.
In the case of a proposed demolition, the commission must make a finding that the designated landmark cannot be
remodeled or rehabilitated in a manner which would allow a reasonable use of or return from the property to the
property owner.

7.

In the case of a finding of economic hardship, this finding shall be accompanied by a plan developed by the city of
Pomona and/or applicant to relieve economic hardship. This plan may include, but is not limited to, property tax relief,
loans, or grants from the city of Pomona and other sources, acquisition by fee purchase or eminent domain,
248/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

redevelopment funds, development fees for historic preservation, changes in applicable zoning regulations, transfer of
unused development rights or relaxation of the provisions of this section sufficient to allow reasonable beneficial use or
return from the property. The commission shall within sixty (60) days, from the date of receipt of a completed
application, make recommendations to develop and adopt a plan in order to relieve economic hardship and to allow the
applicant a reasonable use of and economic return from, the property or otherwise preserve the subject property.
Inaction by the commission on the request within the sixty (60) day period shall result in the request for economic
hardship being deemed automatically approved.
8.

If, by the end of the aforementioned sixty (60) day period, the commission finds that without approval of the proposed
work the property cannot generate a reasonable economic return, then the commission shall issue a finding of economic
hardship approving the proposed work.

9.

If the commission finds otherwise, it shall deny the application for a finding of economic hardship and notify the
applicant by mail of the final denial.

10.

If approval of a finding of economic hardship will result in the demolition of a nominated or designated historic
landmark, the applicant shall be required to provide documentation of the resource proposed for demolition to the
standards of the Historic American Buildings Survey. Such documentation may include photographs, floor plans,
measured drawings, archaeological survey, or other documentation stipulated by the commission and shall be submitted
prior to issuance of a demolition permit.

I.

Historic Preservation Participation Incentives. In order to foster the preservation of Pomona's historic built environment, the
following incentives for participation are only available to historic landmarks and contributors to historic districts:
1.

State Historic Building Code. Any exterior alteration made for preservation, rehabilitation, restoration, or relocation of
such properties shall be made according to the standards of the State Historical Building Code pursuant to the California
Health and Safety Code Section 18950 et seq.

2.

Mills Act Contracts. The city council authorizes the use of California Government Code Section 50280 et seq., alternately
known as the Historical Property Contracts or Mills Act. Such contracts, which shall be administered by the economic
development department, may be entered into at the sole discretion of the city council based on the recommendations
of the commission in a form to be approved by the city attorney. The intent of such contracts shall be the continued
preservation of historical properties. The subject property must be on the Pomona historic register or located within a
designated historic district to which it is a contributor.

3.

Recognition. The commission shall establish a program to recognize historic properties with special plaques, signage etc.

4.

Financial Benefits. Owners of such properties are eligible to apply for local, state and federal financial benefits as
available.

J.

Duty to Keep in Good Repair. The owner, occupant, or other person in actual charge of an historic landmark or an
improvement, building, or structure in an historic district shall keep it in good repair at all times. All exterior portions of such
improvement, building, or structure shall be properly maintained. All of the interior portions thereof of certain public
buildings, when such control is specifically designated, shall be properly maintained, when such maintenance is necessary to
prevent deterioration and decay of any exterior architectural feature.

K.

Unlawful Demolition.
a.

The owner of any structure which is demolished without obtaining a required certificate of appropriateness shall be
subject to a fine not exceeding the amount of five dollars ($5.00) per square foot up to the maximum fine allowable
by law of structure or portion of structure which was demolished.

b.

The amount of penalty to be imposed shall be reviewed for potential adjustment every five (5) years, and if not
reviewed shall remain at the level last determined.

(Ord. No. 3789, § 2; Ord. No. 3871, § 2.)

Sec. .5809-14. - Group care facilities.
Group care facilities, as defined in Subsection A, serving six (6) or fewer persons shall be considered a residential use of property for the
purposes of this section. Group care facilities are permitted according to the provisions of Table 1 in Subsection B. All group care facilities
serving six (6) or fewer persons shall be in compliance with Subsection C. All group care facilities serving seven (7) or more persons shall be in
249/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

compliance with Subsection D.
A.

Group Care Facility Types.

Group care facilities shall include both residential and nonresidential facilities that provide care and services to children and
adults, according to the following definitions:
1.

Day care home - any residential unit that regularly provides care, protection, and supervision to fourteen (14) or
fewer children or adults, as incidental to the use of the unit as a residence, for periods of less than twenty-four (24)
hours per day

2.

Day care center - any day care facility, other than a day care home, that provides nonmedical care, protection, and
supervision to children or adults for periods of less than twenty-four (24) hours per day

3.

Residential care facility - a facility licensed by the State of California at which care, services, or treatment is provided
to children or adults living in a community residential setting

4.

Residential service facility - a residential facility, other than a residential care facility or a single housekeeping unit,
at which the operator receives compensation for the provision of personal services in addition to housing including,
but not limited to, protection, supervision, assistance, guidance, training, therapy, or other non-medical care

B.

Applicability.

Group care facilities shall be permitted in various land use districts throughout the City. Table 1 below specifies the zones in
which group care facilities are allowed and the applicable permit requirements.

C.

Development Standards for Group Care Facilities Serving Six (6) or Fewer Persons.

Each group care facility shall conform to all property development standards of the zoning district in which it is located.
D.

Development Standards for Group Care Facilities Serving Seven (7) or More Persons.
1.

Each group care facility shall conform to all property development standards of the zoning district in which it is
located.

2.

Group care facilities shall not be located within three hundred (300) feet of another such facility.

3.

Day care homes, as defined in Subsection A of this section, serving nine to fourteen (9-14) children shall be required
to provide an on-site outdoor play area of not less than seventy-five (75) square feet per child, but in no case shall
less than four hundred and fifty (450) square feet of on-site play area be provided. The outdoor play area shall not
be located in the front yard.

4.

Day care centers shall provide passenger loading areas at the rate of one (1) on-site passenger loading space per
each twenty-five (25) parking spaces, with a minimum of one (1) loading space required. In addition, any day care
center serving adults shall provide at least one (1) parking space for vans.

5.

All group care facilities shall provide a six (6) foot high solid decorative block wall along all property lines, except in
the front yard. Walls shall provide for safety with controlled points of entry and shall incorporate decorative
materials and features including, but not limited to, "split-face " block, cobblestone, or slumpstone.
251/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

6.

On-site landscaping shall be consistent with that prevailing in the neighborhood and shall be regularly maintained, inc
irrigation.

7.

All on-site lighting shall be stationary and shall be directed away from adjacent properties and public rights-of-way.
Intensity shall be no greater than one footcandle of illumination.

8.

No signs for group care facilities within any residential zones shall be permitted. Signs for group care facilities
within nonresidential zones shall comply with Section .503-K of the Zoning Ordinance.

9.

Each group care facility shall provide fire extinguisher and smoke detector devices, and shall meet all standards
established by the Los Angeles County fire marshal.

10.

Outdoor activities shall be conducted only between the hours of seven a.m. and ten p.m. per Section 14.9-5 of the
Pomona City Code.

11.

All group care facilities shall be operated according to all applicable state and local health and safety regulations.

12.

No indoor furniture shall be allowed outdoors.

13.

All group care facilities shall be in conformance with the Uniform Building Code. A certificate of occupancy shall be
obtained from the Building Division prior to occupancy of group care facilities.

14.
E.

Group care facilities shall obtain a business license.

Requests for Reasonable Accommodation.
1.

Policy:

The City of Pomona recognizes that disabled individuals may benefit from the ability to live in group care facilities and that
strict adherence to provisions of the Zoning Ordinance could result in the exclusion of such a facility from a location particularly
suitable to meeting the needs of certain disabled persons. Therefore, it is the policy of the City of Pomona to provide reasonable
accommodation for persons with disabilities seeking fair access to housing in the application of regulations, policies, and
processes set forth in Zoning Ordinance Section .5809-14, Subsections A-D. A person with disabilities is someone who has a
physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of such person's major life activities. Laws that protect
persons with disabilities against discrimination include within their protection persons who are recovering from addictions to
alcohol or narcotics so long as such persons are not currently using the substances.
2.

Procedures
a.

Application
i.

The owner of a proposed group care facility serving persons who, because of disabilities, require
reasonable accommodation in the application of a zoning law that may be acting as a barrier to fair
housing opportunities may submit a request for such accommodation on a form provided by the
Planning Division.

ii.

If the project for which the request is being made also requires other planning permits or approval, then
the applicant shall file the request along with the application for such other permit or approval.

b.

Notice of Request for Accommodation

Written notice of a request for reasonable accommodation will be given as follows:
i.

If no other entitlement is being sought, notice of the request for reasonable accommodation will be
mailed to the owners of all properties located along both sides of the street, within the same block as the
subject property.

ii.

If the request is being made in conjunction with another process, the notice will be mailed along with the
notice of the other proceeding.

c.

Grounds for Accommodation

The following factors will be considered regarding the reasonableness of the requested accommodation:
i.

Special need created by the disabilities

ii.

Benefits that may result from the requested adjustment of a regulation or policy

iii.

Potential impacts on surrounding uses
252/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

iv.

Physical attributes of the subject property and structures

v.

Alternative accommodations that may provide equivalent benefits

vi.

Whether the requested accommodation would impose an undue financial or administrative burden on
the City

vii.

Whether the requested accommodation would require a fundamental alteration of the nature of a
program

d.

Decision Process
i.

The Planning Manager shall review each application for completeness within 5 days of its having been
submitted.

ii.

Within 10 days after a letter of completeness has been mailed, notice of the Planning Manager's
proposed decision will be mailed in the same manner described above under Notice of Request for
Accommodation.

iii.

Within 10 days of the date that the notice was mailed, any person may request a Planning Manager's
hearing regarding the proposed decision. If no request for a hearing is made, the proposed decision will
become final.

iv.

If a request for a hearing is made, the Planning Manager will conduct a hearing within 20 days of the
request at which all reasonable evidence and credible testimony will be considered.

v.

Within 10 days of the hearing, the Planning Manager will issue a decision granting the request, granting
the request with conditions, or denying the request. A notice of decision containing the Planning
Manager's findings, conclusions, and reasons for the decision will be mailed in the same manner as
described above.

vi.

Within 20 days after the Planning Manager's notice of decision is mailed, any person may file an appeal in
writing to the Planning Commission. The application will contain a statement of the grounds for the
appeal. After mailing notice as described above, the Planning Commission will hold a public hearing to
consider the appeal at the next available regularly scheduled meeting.

vii.

Any person may appeal the Planning Commission's decision to the City Council in accordance with the
appeal process provided for in Zoning Ordinance Subsection .580-F.

(Ord. No. 3787, § 7: Ord. No. 3971, § 2.)

Sec. .5809-15. - Wireless communication facilities.
A.

Purpose and Intent. The purpose of these requirements is to regulate the location and design of wireless communication
facilities (WCF) to promote the public health, safety, and community aesthetics consistent with the goals and objectives of the
city of Pomona General Plan. The regulations are also intended to minimize visibility and the number of freestanding
structures in the city, while establishing minimum guidelines and expedited processing for well-designed proposals in
appropriate locations. These regulations also take into account the rapid pace of technological advances and establish
guidelines for the timely removal of abandoned facilities.

B.

Definitions.

Abandonment—Wireless communication facility shall be considered abandoned if the use is discontinued for ninety days or more,
notification to the city by permittee of abandonment, or presentation to the city of evidence demonstrating abandonment.
Administrative wireless communication facility permit—A wireless communication facility permit that can be approved by staff and
requires no public hearing.
Antenna—Equipment used to transmit and receive radio waves carrying conversation, signals, and/or data.
Co-location—The location of more than one wireless communication facility antenna on a single support structure. Subcategories of
co-location include approved facility, non-conforming facility, and multiple users.

253/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Co-location, approved facility—Support structure designed to accommodate more than one facility. Facilities approved must be
consistent with this title. An approved facility is constructed by a single provider but may become a "multiple user" facility if a second
permittee is installed on the site.
Co-location, non-conforming facility—Location on a wireless communication facility constructed before current section. Project must
be designed to use existing support structure and area for support equipment.
Concealed antenna—A wireless communication facility that is designed to resemble part of a building structure or landscape feature.
Subcategories of concealed antenna include: building mounted, freestanding structure.
Concealed antenna, building mounted—Architecturally screened roof-mounted wireless communication facility or attached to the
building. Bell tower, clock tower, steeples, parapets, false windows, and other types of architectural features that are designed to
camouflage the wireless communication facility and are completely connected to the architectural building.
Concealed antenna, existing freestanding structure—Wireless communication facility that is to be located on an existing freestanding
structure such as monopole, freestanding sign, clock tower, water tower and other types of existing structures that are not buildings or
utility support structures.
Concealed antenna, new freestanding structure—Wireless communication facility that is camouflaged as part of a sign or other
freestanding structure. Examples include "tree" monopoles, which may appear to be palms or pines ("monopalms" and "monopines");
bell tower, clock tower; freestanding signage; flagpoles, light poles and other types of concealed freestanding structures.
Equipment shelter—A room, cabinet, or building used to house support equipment for utility or service providers.
Major wireless communication facility permit—Any wireless communication facility that requires public hearing by the planning
commission.
Micro WCF—Communication antenna and support equipment, such as "microcells," "micropanels," and "shoebox" installations, that
are not greater than sixteen by twenty-two by eight inches.
Minor wireless communication facility permit—Any wireless communication facility permit that requires public noticing, but does not
require discretionary review.
Monopole—A freestanding structure composed of a single spire, pole, or tower used to support antennas or related equipment.
Property owner—Means the individual or institution who owns the real property on which a WCF is located or proposed.
Slim line, unipole—A freestanding structure composed of a pole where the support antenna is mounted onto the pole and concealed
by a circular metal ring that is no greater than ten inches in diameter.
Support equipment—Communications equipment installed within an equipment shelter installed on the ground or on a building or
other structure.
Utility mounted—Means an antenna attached to a public utility structure.
Wireless communication facility (WCF)—A facility which serves to provide wireless telecommunication service, including but not
limited to, cellular, ESMR, PCS, paging, e-mail, and data transmission.
Wireless communication facility permittee—means the individual or entity that is licensed to install and operate a wireless
communication facility. Subsequently referred to as permittee.
C.

Wireless Communication Facility Permit Required. A wireless communication facility permit is required for all WCFs or wireless
communications facilities in the city and must be obtained prior to operation of the facility.

D.

Applicability. Wireless Communication facilities shall be pemiitted in various land use districts throughout the city. The
following table specifies the zones in which wireless communication facilities are allowed, and the applicable permit
processing for each.
Table D-1. WCF as a Permitted Use and Required Processing.

E.

F.

Operational Standards.
1.

Maintenance Requirements.
a.

Property Maintenance. All wireless communication facilities including landscaping and surface areas shall be
continuously maintained free of weeds, debris, litter or temporary signage.

b.
2.

Graffiti. All graffiti shall be removed from the premises within twenty-four hours of discovery.

Business License Required.
a.

All wireless communication facility permittees shall demonstrate to the planning division that they have a business
license for operating a wireless communication facility site prior to finalization of building permits.

b.

All property owners shall demonstrate to the planning division that they have a business license for property rental
before finalization of building permits.

3.

Business License Renewal and Certification. Certification of continued use of each approved facility shall be submitted on
a yearly basis at the time of the facility operator's business license renewal for as long as the facility remains in
operation. The certification shall indicate that the facility is operating as approved and that the facility complies with the
most current Federal Communication Commission (FCC) safety standards. Facilities, which are no longer in operation,
shall be removed within ninety days after the date of discontinuation.
257/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

4.

Cash Bond Requirement.
a.

Prior to the finalizing of building permit for the construction or modification of a wireless communication facility,
the applicant shall be required to provide to the city a cash bond or for the removal of the facility and any accessory
equipment, and rehabilitate the site if that facility is abandoned. The bond amount shall be determined by the chief
building official and shall be no less than fifteen percent of construction cost.

b.

The bond shall be deposited in an interest bearing account with the city named as co-depositor.

c.

No more than once a year, the permittee may petition to the chief building official for release of a portion of the
funds. The petition must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the chief building official that the value of the account
exceeds the amount required to remove the WCF and rehabilitate the site. The amount remaining in the account,
after release of funds, must be equal to or greater than the amount required to remove the WCF and rehabilitate
the site.

d.

Prior to release of funds, the permittee must demonstrate that the WCF is operating in compliance with the WCF
prdinance and the WCF permit.

G.

Wireless Communication Permit Review Process.
1.

Required Findings. All antennas permitted by this section shall be subject to the following findings.
a.

The wireless communication facility permittee has located on an approved co-location facility or has demonstrated
to the city a good faith effort to locate on an approved facility or has demonstrated that co-location is not
technically feasible due to coverage needs, potential interference, or other technical issues.

b.

There is adequate space on the property for the antenna and support equipment without conflicting with existing
buildings or other structures on the property, or reducing required parking, landscaping setbacks or other
development standards.

c.

The design and placement of the antenna and support equipment will not adversely impact the use of the property,
other buildings and structures located on the property, or the surrounding area or neighborhood.

d.

The antenna and support equipment as proposed are consistent with the intent of this part and comply with the
operational standards and any applicable special standards as noted above.

e.

The applicant has demonstrated that the wireless communication facility will have the least possible visual impact
on the environment taking into account technical, engineering, economic and other relevant factors.

2.

Types of Permits and Review Process. The following table summarizes the types of WCF permits, with respect to the
various review processes for each:

Conditions of Approval. Conditions of approval shall be imposed on any permit granted pursuant to this section to

ensure compliance with the intent of this part, the required standards and findings of this section, and the protection of

4

Appeal Process. All written appeals shall be subject to the procedures set forth in Section .580-F of the city of Pomona
Zoning Ordinance.

H.

Environmental Review. The California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) requires the city to consider potential environmental
effects from each new project. CEQA provides for varying degrees of review depending on the project's potential for
environment impacts. An environmental review may include a categorical exemption, negative declaration or an
environmental impact report.
1.

Aesthetic, visual and safety. Applicants must demonstrate that potential environmental impacts from the project will be
reduced to a level of insignificance through project design and placement.

2.

Radio Frequency Emissions.1 Applicants should provide evidence showing the proposed wireless telecommunications
facility complies with Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rules, regulations and standards governing
environmental effects of radio frequency emissions.

Editor's note—
1

Section 704 of Title 7 of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 (effective February 8, 1996), contains the following language: "(iv) No

state or local government or instrumentality thereof may regulate the placement, construction, and modification of personal wireless service
facilities on the basis of the environmental effects of radio frequency emission to the extent that such facilities comply with the Commission's
regulations concerning such emmissions."
I.

Removal of Abandoned Wireless Communication Facilities
1.

Written Notice of Abandonment. A written notice of the determination of abandonment shall be sent by first class mail,
to the permittee of the wireless communication facility at said operator's business address on file with the city business
license division.

2.

Response of Permittee. The operator shall remove all facilities within thirty days of the date of such notice, unless within
ten days of the date of said notice, the permittee appeals such determination, in writing, to the planning commission.

3.

Planning Commission Review of Abandonment. If the permittee appeals the notice of abandonment, the planning
manager shall schedule a hearing on the matter to be conducted before the planning commission at which time the
commission may affirm, reverse, or modify with or without conditions the original determination of abandonment and
shall make written findings in support of its decision.

4.

Appeal of Planning Commission Decision. The decision of the planning commission may be appealed to city council per
Section .580-F.

5.

Removal by City.
a.

At any time after the thirty-day period from the date of notice or determination by planning commission or city
council of abandonment, the city may remove the abandoned facility, repair any and all damage to the premises
caused by such removal, and otherwise restore the premises as is appropriate to be in compliance with applicable
code.

b.

In removing the wireless communication facility, the city shall exercise the easement to enter the property and use
the bond proceeds to rehabilitate the site. At conclusion of the rehabilitation, the city shall remove the easement
and return the remaining bond money to the permittee or property owner as designated.

c.

The city may, but shall not be required to, store the removed facility (or any part thereof). The city may, in lieu of
storing the removed facility, convert it to the city's use, sell it, or dispose of it in any manner deemed by the city to
be appropriate.

6.

Thirty days from the date of notice of abandonment or determination by planning commission or city council of
abandonment, the WCF permit for the subject facility will be terminated.

7.

Violations and Penalty. Violations of this chapter shall be unlawful and shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by fine
259/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

or imprisonment or both. Each day the violation continues is punishable as a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 3931, § 3.)

Sec. .5809-16 - Used car sales lots.
A.

Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to serve the locational needs of used car sales lots while guaranteeing
protection of major commercial corridors, surrounding properties and their values through the implementation of
development and operational standards which will serve to minimize the impact of such uses on the community.

B.

Conditional Use Permit. A conditional use permit is required for used car sales lots in the C-4 (highway commercial) and C-IND
(commercial industrial) zone. No used car lots shall be operated in the aforementioned zoning districts unless a conditional
use permit is granted by the planning commission pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section .580. Such uses shall also be
subject to operational and development standards contained in this section.

C.

Nonconforming Uses. Legally existing used car lots at the time of adoption of the ordinance codified in this section, including
but not limited to those located in commercial, commercial-industrial, industrial or specific plan areas, shall be deemed
nonconforming if they fail to meet any of the development and operational standards contained herein and/or any other
applicable development requirements or design policy of the city including but not limited to those criteria contained in the
zoning ordinance and/or specific plans.

D.

Development/Operational Standards.
1.

3.

Request for Correction. With the exception of graffiti, all city requests for corrections to violations of the development
operational standards listed above shall be completed within thirty (30) days of notification.

E.

Compliance Program for Nonconforming Uses.
1.

Where used car lot uses were legally existing uses on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, and are
not in conformity with the development and operational standards of this section, it is the intent and purpose of this
section to declare such use to be nonconforming (including existing used car lot uses which are located in zones or
specific plan areas which do not allow such uses), for the purpose of protecting the public health, safety and general
welfare of the community.

2.

All uses rendered nonconforming with the development and operational standards shall be in compliance with the
provisions of this section by January 1, 2001, unless an extension, minor deviation variance or variance is requested and
granted by the planning division, planning commission or on appeal by the city council prior to that date.

3.

The owner or occupant of property per city business license records that is determined to be a nonconforming use under
this section shall receive a notice and order, in writing, of that determination. The notice and order shall identify specific
areas of noncompliance and shall require the nonconforming use to be in compliance with the provisions of this
ordinance by January 1, 2001. The notice and order shall furthermore provide that any person having any record, title or
legal interest in the nonconforming use may request a meeting with planning staff prior to January 1, 2001, to discuss
specific development standards and other issues of concern related to the subject business, provided the request is
made in writing.

4.

The notice and order, and any amended or supplemental notice and order shall be served upon the record owner. One
copy thereof shall be served on each of the following persons or entities, if known to the city or disclosed for public
records.
a.

The holder of any mortgage or deed of trust or person or entity that has a lien or encumbrance of record;

b.

The owner or holder of any lease of record (business owner);

c.

The holder of any other estate or legal interest of record in or to any building or land which is employed in the
nonconforming use;

d.

The failure of the city to serve any person required under this subsection to be served shall not invalidate any
proceeding under this section as to any other person duly served or relieve any such person from any duty or
obligation imposed on him or her by the provisions of this section.

5.

Service of the notice and order shall be made upon all persons entitled thereto by first-class mail, a copy of such notice
and order, to each such person at the address as it appears on the last equalized assessment roll of the county or as
known to the city from business license records. If no address of any such person so appears, or is known to the city,
then a copy of the notice and order shall be so mailed, addressed to such person at the address of the lot or building
involved in the proceeding. The failure of any such person to receive such notice and order shall not affect the validity of
any proceeding under this section.

263/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

6.

Proof of service of the notice and order shall be certified to at the time of service by written declaration, under penalty of pe
by persons effecting such service, declaring time, date and manner in which service was made. The declaration shall be affix
the notice and order and retained by city staff.

7.

Any person entitled to notice and order herein, may before December 1, 2000, request an extension of the compliance
program date. Request for extension shall be in writing to the economic development director or designee, and shall
contain the following information:
a.

A brief statement setting forth the legal interest of each of the persons requesting the hearing ("applicant") in the
nonconforming use;

8.

b.

A brief statement in ordinary and concise language of the grounds for an extension of the compliance date;

c.

The signatures of all appellants and their official mailing addresses.

The economic development director or designee shall consider requests for extensions of the compliance program
pursuant to this chapter. The city shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the person requesting the extension,
with a copy to be retained by the city. If approved, the length of such extensions shall be at the discretion of the
economic development director or designee but shall not exceed six months.

9.

A variance or minor deviation variance if applicable, may be applied for to deviate from any of the development
standards contained in this section pursuant to Section .590 of the zoning ordinance. The planning commission and/or
economic development director or designee shall consider each application on a case-by-case basis.

10.

All used car lot uses deemed to be in compliance with this section shall continue to conform with the governing
development and operational standards.

F.

City Action for Noncompliance. If any applicant or property owner fails to comply with the compliance program and
development and operational standards set forth in this section, they shall be subject to enforcement action, including but not
limited to, revocation of business license, citations and court action.

G.

Infraction or Misdemeanor. A violation of any provision(s) of Section .5809-16 shall be an infraction or misdemeanor in
compliance with enforcement of the zoning ordinance.

H.

Partial Invalidity. In the event that any part or provision of this section shall be determined to be invalid, the remaining
portions which can be separated from the invalid unenforceable provisions shall continue in full force and effect.

(Ord. No. 3878, § 10.)

Sec. .5809-17. - Multi-family residential property standards.
A.

Purpose and Intent. The purpose of this section is to enhance multiple-family residential units and improving the quality of life
for all citizens of Pomona by protecting surrounding properties and their values through consideration of aesthetics, property
maintenance, security, safety and compatibility.

B.

Applicability. This section shall apply to all multiple-family residential complexes including conforming and nonconforming
uses unless otherwise stated. Multiple-family residential complexes shall include all projects in which two or more attached
dwelling units are located. Multiple-family residential projects may be rental units or owner-occupied.

C.

Nonconforming Uses. Multiple-family residential complexes shall be deemed nonconforming if they fail to meet any of the
development and operational standards contained herein and/or any other applicable development requirements or design
policy of the city including but not limited to those criteria contained in the zoning ordinance and/or applicable specific plans.

D.

Development Standards. The following development standards shall apply to all multiple-family residential development of 4
or more units:
1.

Trash Facilities. Multiple-family residential developments shall comply with trash and recycling storage areas pursuant to
Section .503-C of the zoning ordinance. Properties which are unable to provide trash facilities due to property constraints
(e.g., size, shape and topography) may apply for a minor deviation variance pursuant to Section .560-J or a determination
of infeasibility pursuant to Subsection F-11 of this section. A site plan shall be prepared and submitted by the applicant
demonstrating that the subject property is unable to provide the required trash facilities.

2.

Security Lighting. All parking lot areas and walkways shall have a minimum lighting standard of 1 foot-candle power. All
exterior lighting shall be shielded to minimize the impact across property lines or into habitable portions of individual
units wherever possible. A site plan and photometric plan shall be submitted to the planning division for approval. Bare
264/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

bulbs shall not be permitted.
3.

Parking Lot Areas. All parking lot areas shall be maintained free of significant cracks and other similar damage. Parking
lots, drive aisles and driveways shall be constructed of an improved surface (asphalt, concrete, etc.) consistent with the
requirements of the governing Uniform Building Code. Vehicle parking on unimproved surfaces shall be prohibited.

4.

Circulation.
a.

Unless otherwise determined to be infeasible, each site shall control public access to and from the site by providing
safety gates or limiting the flow of traffic to one way subject to the approval of the planning division.

b.

Within the complex wherever feasible posting speed limits, speed bumps or other traffic calming measures shall be
employed to reduce vehicle speed.

5.

Mailboxes. Property owners shall be required to provide mailboxes with individual locks to prevent theft of mail or
located in a secure area as determined by the economic development director or designee.

E.

Operational Standards. The following operational standards shall apply to all multiple-family residential development unless
stated otherwise:
1.

Occupancy Limits.
a.

The following occupancy limits shall apply to prevent overcrowding conditions: Two (2) persons per each living or
sleeping roam, consistent with Pomona housing authority occupancy standards.

b.

When a manager's unit is provided, a sign shall be posted on the premises, within a rental office or in close
proximity to the manager's unit which states these occupancy limits. Tenants which exceed the permitted
occupancy in excess of 14 days within a 6 month period shall be subject to eviction.

2.

Condition of Existing Buildings/Fences/Walls/Garages and Accessory Structures. The following situations shall be
corrected immediately:
a.

Damage to structures including but not limited to, cracked stucco, wood siding, window framing, and other
conditions related to the physical condition of the building.

b.

Broken windows, screens, doors, railings, stairs, porches and balconies.

c.

Any condition which the chief building official could deem a structure(s) to be a threat to the health, safety and
general welfare of the community.

d.

Damage to existing roofing or wall materials which could cause leaks.

e.

Deteriorated/damaged fences including but not limited to, block walls, wrought iron and chain link fencing in
disrepair.

f.
3.

All graffiti shall be removed within 24 hours of notification.

Property Maintenance.
a.

Prohibited Conditions. The type and nature of prohibited conditions include (e.g., keeping or depositing on,
scattering over, or allowing to exist on the premises any of the following:
(1)

Neglected or improperly maintained landscaping and site improvements (e.g., grass, ground cover, hedges,
shrubs, and trees) in conflict with the provisions of Section .503-L (Landscape/Irrigation). This shall include
dead, overgrown, or weed infested vegetation, or vegetation dying as a result of physical damage, disease,
insect infestation, or lack of water, and any required landscaping removed without proper city approval;

(2)

Debris, junk, lumber, trash, shopping carts, or salvaged materials visible at ground level from a public street,
alley, or adjoining property;

(3)

Garbage, trash, or refuse bins, boxes, cans or other containers stored for more than 24 hours on the public
right-of-way or within the required front or side yards;

(4)

Abandoned, discarded, or unused cabinets, freezers, furniture, refrigerators, sinks, stoves, toilets, or other
household structures or equipment on the subject site;

(5)

Construction equipment or machinery of any type or description, parked or stored on a residential property
when the equipment is visible to the general public, except while construction, demolition, or excavation
operations covered by an active building permit are in effect on the subject, or immediately adjoining,
property;
265/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

(6)

Clothing, laundry, linens, rugs, towels, tarps, and other similar materials hung on bushes, fences, railings,
ropes, trees, structures, or walls in the front or side yards or visible from the front or side property lines;

b.

Public Nuisance. All structures, and the land upon which the structures are located in the city that is maintained in a
condition that results in the following, shall be deemed a public nuisance and a violation of the zoning ordinance. A
public nuisance:

c.

(1)

Is detrimental to the property of others;

(2)

Is a hazardous, inappropriate, and/or unsightly condition; and/or

(3)

Causes a reduction in the value of adjoining properties.

Nuisance Prohibited. A person who owns, maintains, or possesses a structure or land in a condition identified
above, shall not allow the nuisance condition to exist.

d.

Maintenance of Laundry Facilities. The property owner shall maintain existing laundry facilities in good working
order.

4.

On-Site Manager Required.
a.

All multiple-family residential complexes of eight (8) or more units shall have an on-site residential manager
appointed by the property owner.

b.

An on-site manager shall be an individual(s) who occupies a dwelling unit at the subject multi-family residential
development. It is strongly recommended that property owners/management companies hire on-site managers
with basic maintenance skills.

c.

Within a condominium development, a homeowners association (HOA) may appoint an individual to act as the onsite manager requirement. An officer or representative from the HOA shall be designated as the responsible party
for emergency purposes.

d.

The manager's unit shall be clearly designated with a sign on his/her front door (for apartments only).

e.

The manager or representative (for HOAs) shall meet with and receive training from the Pomona police department
abatement coordinator relating to his/her responsibility to screen prospective tenants, reporting crimes to the
police department, eviction process etc.

f.

As part of the business license process, the landlord and manager shall acknowledge the reading of this section and
other related materials by signing a statement reflecting this fact.

g.
5.

Encourage the property manager to provide tenants with a copy of the multi-family housing ordinance.

Contact Person. All property owners of multiple-family residential units shall provide, on a yearly basis at the time of the
business license renewal, the Pomona police department with an emergency contact person (preferably an on-site
manager). Property owners, managers and residents are encouraged to participate in local and regional crime
prevention programs.

6.

Crime Free and Drug Free Environment. Property owners/landlords should contribute to the goal of maintaining their
multiple-family residential complexes in a drug and crime free state as determined by the Pomona police department. If
multiple-family residential complexes are deemed not in compliance with this provision, the city may, with reasonable
notice to property owner suggest corrective action including but not limited to providing additional lighting, posting of no
loitering signs, eviction of tenants and as a last resort, requiring security guards.

7.

Tenant Screening and Agreement.
a.

All property owners/landlords shall be strongly encouraged to screen tenants through credit checks, public court
records for criminal convictions and evictions and verification of prior occupancy.

b.

In addition, all property owners/landlords shall be strongly encouraged to have tenants sign, an addendum to their
lease/rental agreement stating that tenants will contribute to the goal of making the property drug and crime free
and shall not commit crime or use/manufacture/sell drugs on the premises. The original addendum shall be
maintained with the manager's file and a copy shall be provided to the tenant.

8.

Public Telephones Prohibited. Public pay telephones shall be prohibited at all multi-family residential complexes except
within the manager's unit or rental office.

9.

Trash Pick-Up. Adequate trash pick-up shall be provided for each multi-family residential complex. If the economic
266/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

development director or designee determines that service is inadequate, the property management shall be informed
and required to correct any deficiencies which may include but not be limited to, providing additional trash receptacles
and increasing the number of times per week that trash is picked-up and removed from the premises.
10.

Property Management. If the economic development director or designee determines that the management of a
property is inadequate in any respect, the property owner may be notified of specific inadequacies and provided a list of
corrective measures to rectify the condition, including if necessary, changing the management company. All corrective
actions shall be completed within thirty (30) days of notification.

11.

Physical Security Design.
a.

Garages. To ensure that garages are not used by unauthorized individuals, all garages shall be able to be secured.
Doors and locks shall be operable at all times.

b.

Alleys. To orient police and fire personnel when responding to emergency situations, apartment complexes that are
located adjacent to an alley shall have the addresses of the units permanently displayed on garages, walls or fences
that border the alley per approval of the city. The addresses shall be in typeface no less than six inches high.

c.

Wall Landscaping. To discourage easy access for graffiti vandals, if the economic development director or designee
determines that a primary or accessory structure, fence or wall is a high risk area for graffiti, he/she may require
corrective action to reduce the potential for future graffiti including but not limited to, the addition of trees, shrubs,
climbing vines or other graffiti reduction measures.

d.

Landscape Pruning. To permit residents and emergency personnel a clear view of the site and eliminate potential
hiding spaces, low landscaping, groundcover and shrubbery, within the site shall be pruned so that it does not
exceed thirty (30) inches in height. Trees shall be pruned so that the lower branches are a minimum of seven feet
above the ground. Perimeter landscaping, vines, and landscaping located directly adjacent to a wall shall not be
subject to these requirements.

12.

Request for Correction. All city requests for corrections to violations of the development and operational standards shall
be completed within thirty (30) days of notification unless stated otherwise.

F.

Compliance Program for Nonconforming Uses.
1.

Where uses were legally existing uses on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, and are not in
conformity with the development and operational standards contained in this section, it is the intent and purpose of this
section to declare such use to be nonconforming, for the purpose of protecting the public health, safety and general
welfare of the community.

2.

All uses rendered nonconforming by this section shall be in compliance with the provisions of this section by January 1,
2001, unless an extension, minor deviation variance or variance is requested and granted by the planning division,
planning commission or city council.

3.

The owner of property and management company (per city business license records) that is determined to be a
nonconforming use under this section shall receive a notice and order, in writing, of that determination. The notice and
order shall state the grounds for the decision and shall require the nonconforming use to be in compliance with the
provisions of this section by January 1, 2001. The notice and order shall furthermore provide that any person having any
record, title or legal interest in the nonconforming use may request a meeting with planning staff prior to January 1, 2001
to discuss specific development and operational standards and other issues of concern related to the subject property or
use, provided the request is made in writing.

4.

The notice and order, and any amended or supplemental notice and order shall be served upon the record owner as
shown on business license records. One copy thereof shall be served to each of the following persons, if known to the
city or disclosed for public records.
a.

The holder of any mortgage or deed of trust or has a lien or encumbrance of record;

b.

The failure of the city to serve such notice and order to any person required under this subsection shall not
invalidate any proceeding under this section as to any other person duly mailed or relieve any such person from
any duty or obligation imposed on him or her by the provisions of this section.

5.

Service of the notice and order shall be made upon all persons entitled thereto by first-class mail, a copy of such notice
and order, to each such person at the address as it appears on the last equalized assessment roll of the county or as
267/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

known to the city from business license records. If no address of any such person so appears, or is known to the city,
then a copy of the notice and order shall be so mailed, addressed to such person at the address of the lot or building
involved in the proceeding. The failure of any such person to receive such notice and order shall not affect the validity of
any proceeding under this section.
6.

Proof of service of the notice and order shall be certified to at the time of service by written declaration, under penalty of
perjury, executed by persons effecting such service, declaring time, date and manner in which service was made. The
declaration shall be affixed to a copy of the notice and order and retained by city staff.

7.

Any person entitled to notice and order herein may, before December 1, 2000, request an extension of the compliance
program date. Request for extension shall be in writing to the economic development director or designee, and shall
contain the following information.
a.

A brief statement setting forth the legal interest of each of the persons requesting the hearing ("applicant") in the
nonconforming use;

8.

b.

A brief statement in ordinary and concise language of the grounds for an extension of the compliance date;

c.

The signatures of all appellants and their official mailing addresses.

The economic development director or designee shall consider requests for extensions of the compliance program
pursuant to this chapter. The city shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for conducting business, and shall render
all decisions and findings in writing to the person requesting the extension, with a copy to be retained by the city. If
approved, the length of such extension shall be at the discretion of the economic development director or designee but
shall not exceed six months.

9.

A variance or minor deviation variance if applicable, may be applied for to deviate from any of the development
standards contained in this section pursuant to Section .590 of the zoning ordinance. The planning commission and/or
economic development director or designee shall consider each application on a case-by-case basis.

10.

All applicable uses deemed to be in compliance with this section shall continue to conform with the governing
development and operational standards and shall demonstrate such compliance on an annual basis via a letter of
compliance.

11.

A property owner or designated representative of a legally existing multi-family residential development as of January 1,
2001, may apply for a determination of infeasibility if a development standard contained in this section cannot be met.
The determination of infeasibility shall be applicable to development standards only and shall be subject to the
procedure described below:
a.

The economic development director or designee may approve a determination of infeasibility if findings can be
made to justify deviation or elimination of the development standard due to the physical characteristics of the
subject property.

b.

The economic development director or designee shall have the discretion to either eliminate the development
standard, allow a deviation from the development standard or deny the request.

c.

The decision of the economic development director or designee may be appealed to the planning commission
within 5 days of the decision.

d.

An appeal of the decision made by the economic development director or designee shall be subject to the
governing appeal fee.

e.
G.

An application for a determination of infeasibility shall not be approved based on economic hardship.

Infraction or Misdemeanor. A violation of any provision(s) of Section .5809-17 shall be an infraction or misdemeanor in
compliance with enforcement of the zoning ordinance.

H.

City Action for Noncompliance. If any applicant or property owner fails to comply with the compliance program and
development and operational standards set forth in this section, they shall be subject to enforcement action, including but not
limited to, revocation of business license, citations and court action.

I.

Partial Invalidity. In the event that any part or provision of this section shall be determined to be invalid, the remaining
portions which can be separated from the invalid unenforceable provisions shall continue in full force and effect.

(Ord. No. 3879, § 7.)

Sec. .5809-18. - Senior citizen housing overlay district.
A.

Purpose and Intent. The purpose of the section is to facilitate the development of quality affordable housing for senior citizens
while at the same time enhancing the appearance and value of the property that is to be developed. The provisions of the
section are intended as follows:
1)

To provide various incentives that are consistent with the State of California Density Bonus, to developers of senior
citizen housing projects;

2)

To ensure that adequate affordable housing is provided to very low and moderate income senior citizens consistent with
the Regional Housing Needs Assessment (RHNA) dictated by the State of California, Department of Housing and
Community Development;

3)

That the senior citizen housing projects are superior in functional design, quality of construction, appearance, and
operational standards;

4)

That senior citizen housing developments are compatible with the surrounding community and complementary to the
surrounding land uses.

B.

Establishment—The Senior Citizen Housing Overlay District may be applied in Combination with underlying zoning districts via
the Change of Zone Application Process. A Senior Citizen Housing Overlay District shall be indicated in the Zoning Map by the
letters "SH" after the reference letters identifying the base district.

C.

Target Population—The target population group served by the units constructed in the Senior Housing Overlay District are
senior citizens who meet the following criteria:

For tenants, residents or occupants who are married or registered domestic partners, one shall be 55 years or older.

D.

1.

In single person households, the occupant must be 55 or older;

2.

In multiple household all residents must be 55 or older except as provided above;

3.

For married or domestic partners at least one member must be 55 or older.

Applicability—The Senior Citizen Housing Overlay District requires the presence of certain conditions before it can be attached
to a specific parcel of land. In order to adequately and satisfactorily serve the target population that this district has been
created to serve, any proposed project must meet the following conditions and features.
1.

Appropriate commercial or residential base district.

2.

Size - The minimum size lot for a senior citizen housing project shall be two acres

3.

Surrounding area - Land uses in the immediate area, current and projected must be compatible with the living
environment required by senior citizens and must be free of health safety and noise problems.

E.

Development Incentives.

F.

Standards.
1.

Site character.
a.

Existing amenities (e.g., views, mature trees, etc.) that are unique to the site should be preserved and incorporated
into the project's design whenever possible.

b.

Structures that are historic or are otherwise distinctive because of their age, cultural significance, or unique
architectural style, as determined by the Council, should be preserved and incorporated into development
proposals.

c.

When a senior housing project adjoining residential and commercial uses can mutually benefit from connection
rather than separation, appropriate connective elements (e.g., walkways) should be provided.

2.

Site planning.
a.

Site access. Developments with more than 200 parking stalls that are located on arterial highways should
coordinate access points with median openings and existing driveways on the opposite side of the roadway. Final
locations shall be subject to approval by the Planning and Development Services Manager. Developments with
more than 200 parking stalls, that are located on arterial highways maybe required to provide deceleration lanes
adjacent to their major entry.

b.

Building setbacks.
270/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

1.

Frontage - The building setback for property line adjacent to street frontage shall be 20 feet.

2.

All other property lines—all other setbacks shall be ½ the height of the building wall which fronts the subject
property line.

c.

Building design layout.
i.

The Minimum Dwelling Size for each unit shall be as follows:

studios—475 square feet
1 Bedroom—525 square feet
Bedroom—700 square feet
ii.

Multiple buildings in a single project should provide a functional relationship with one another to achieve a
"village" scale by use of the following techniques:

3.

(a)

Cluster buildings around open plaza areas or courtyards, not parking lots.

(b)

Provide open plaza areas and courtyards with landscaping and other pedestrian amenities.

(c)

Provide convenient pedestrian circulation between buildings, and open parking areas.

(d)

Link buildings together visually using trellis structures, arcades, and enhanced paving.

Architectural style. No specific architectural style or design theme is required. A variety of architectural characteristics
should be considered to add to the City's overall image. However, while variety in design is generally encouraged,
compatibility of new projects with their surroundings should also be a priority.

4.

Design consistency.
a.

Building design should demonstrate a consistent use of colors, materials, and detailing throughout all elevations of
the building. Piecemeal embellishment should be avoided.

b.

Elevations that do not directly face a street should not be ignored or receive only minimal architectural treatment.
Each facade should be designed for public view and should be appropriately landscaped.

5.

Form and mass. Designs should provide a sense of human scale and proportion. Structures should be designed to avoid
a "box-like," impersonal appearance by use of the following techniques:
a.

Facade and roof articulation. Separations, changes in plane and height, and the inclusion of elements including
balconies, porches, arcades, dormers, and cross gables mitigate the barracks-like quality of flat walls and roofs of
excessive length. Secondary hipped or gabled roofs covering the entire mass of a building are preferable to flat
roofs, mansard roofs, or pitched roof segments applied on only some portions of the building.

b.

Provide architectural detail through the use of columns, three-dimensional decorative cornice bands, recessed
entries and windows, and awnings and canopies.

c.

Provide full roofs with substantial overhangs.

d.

Incorporate decorative parapets where roof overhangs are not provided

e.

Structures containing 3 or more attached dwellings in a row should incorporate at least one of the following:
(i)

For each dwelling unit, at least one architectural projection not less than 2 feet from the wall plane and not
less than 4 feet wide should be provided.

(ii)
6.

A change in wall plane of at least 3 feet for a distance of at least 12 feet for each 2 units.

Materials. Exterior materials should be very durable and require low maintenance. Piecemeal embellishment and
frequent changes in materials should be avoided. Exterior wall colors should harmonize with the site and surrounding
buildings.

7.

Colors.
a.

Facade colors should be neutral or earth tone colors. The use of high-intensity colors, metallic colors, black, or
fluorescent colors is prohibited.

b.

Building trim and accent areas may feature brighter colors, including primary colors.

c.

The transition between base and accent colors should relate to changes in building materials or the change of
building surface planes. Colors should not meet or change without some physical change or definition to the
271/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

surface plane.
d.

The blending of compatible colors in a single facade or composition is a good way to add character and variety,
while reducing, or breaking up the lines of a building.

e.

Unusual patterns and color schemes should be avoided.

f.

Color and finishes on building exteriors of all elevations of a building should be coordinated to provide a total
continuity of design

8.

Entries. Entries should be protected from the elements and should create a focus and sense of entry for the building by
use of at least two of the following:

9.

a.

Wall recesses.

b.

Roof overhangs.

c.

Canopies and awnings.

d.

Arcades.

Balconies, porches, and patios. The incorporation of balconies, porches, and recessed patios is encouraged for both
practical and aesthetic values. These elements should be integrated into structures to break up large wall masses, offset
floor setbacks, and add human scale to buildings.

10.

Dwelling unit access. The use of long, monotonous access balconies and/or corridors that provide access to 5 or more
units should be avoided. Instead, access points to units should be clustered in groups of 4 or less. The use of distinctive
architectural elements and materials to denote prominent entrances is strongly encouraged.

11.

Exterior stairs. Simple, clean, bold projections of stairways are encouraged to complement the architectural massing and
form of the structure. Thin-looking, open metal, prefabricated stairs are discouraged.

12.

Mechanical and utility equipment. All mechanical equipment, either mounted on the roof, or ground, should be screened
from view. Utility meters and equipment should be placed in locations that are not exposed to view from the street.
Screening devices shall be compatible with the architecture and color of the adjacent structures.

13.

Compatible roof shapes. Rooflines of buildings should be designed to be compatible with surrounding building forms.
Clashes in roof styles should be avoided in multifamily/cluster developments. The objective in determining roof shape is
to establish a visual order to building clusters.

14.

Roofing materials. Roofing materials shall consist of tile or simulated tile with a fire rating of Class A.

15.

Support facilities. Support structures (e.g., laundry facilities, recreation buildings, and sales/lease offices) should be
consistent with the architectural design of the overall complex.

16.

Solid waste bins. Trash bins should be fully enclosed with a masonry enclosure, wood simulated gates and a trellis roof.
The enclosure shall be finished with colors and materials that are consistent with the rest of the structures. Enclosures
should be screened with landscaping on their most visible sides.

17.

Utility and mechanical equipment.
a.

All mechanical equipment (e.g., compressors, air conditioners, heating and ventilating equipment, chillers, stand
pipes, solar collectors, etc.) shall be concealed from view. Screening devices should be compatible with the
architecture and color of the adjacent buildings.

b.

Mechanical equipment should not be located on the roof of a structure unless the equipment can be screened by
building elements that are designed for that purpose and that are an integral part of the building design.

c.

Utility equipment (e.g., electric and gas meters, electrical panels, and junction boxes) should be located in utility
rooms within the structure or utility cabinets with exterior access.

18.

Service areas. Service areas shall be functional, appropriately screened and isolated from living areas and public right of
way.

19.

Laundry facilities. One washer and dryer shall be provided for every 20 dwelling units.

20.

Elevator. For structures 2 stories or more in height, a minimum of one elevator shall be provided. Additional elevators
may be required based on the design of structures. The elevator shall be centrally located and in close proximity to
entries.

21.

Minimum dwelling amenities. At a minimum, each unit shall be provided with the following amenities:
a.

Central heating and air conditioning;

b.

Built-in dishwashers;

c.

Fully enclosed, securable storage closet not less than 100 CF in area;

d.

Clothes washer and dryer electrical and gas hookups for standard washer and dryer appliances, and a
bachelor/studio unit may provide facilities for stackable washer/dryer appliances;

e.
22.

Call system with capability of 24 hour monitoring.

Driveway approaches. Driveway approaches serving senior citizen housing developments shall be delineated with
enhanced paving treatment, such as interlocking pavers, textured and color; pigmented concrete, or stamped concrete.

23.

Parking and circulation.
a.

Project entries. Project entries should provide the resident and visitor with an overview to the project. They should
provide an open window with landscaping, recreational facilities, and/or project directories. Special attention should
be given to hardscape and landscape treatments to enhance the overall image of the project.

b.

The principal vehicular access should be through an entry drive rather than a parking drive. Colored, textured
paving treatment at entry drives together with lush landscaping strongly is encouraged.

c.

If parking attached to the residential structures is not provided, dispersed parking courts are the desired
alternative.
(i)

A parking court should not consist of more than 2 double-loaded parking aisles (bays) adjacent to each other.

(ii)

The length of a parking court should not exceed 14 stalls. Parking courts should be separated from each other
by dwelling units or by a landscaped buffer not less than 20 feet wide.

(iii)
d.

Parking areas should be visible from the residential units, which use them to the greatest degree possible.

Off-Street Parking Accessibility. Parking courts shall be located within 150 from the dwelling unit (front or rear door)
for which the parking space is provided.

24.

Pedestrian access.
a.

Drop-off points (i.e., wider aisles) should be provided near major building entries and plaza areas for projects with
more than 50,000 square feet of building area.

b.

Parking areas should be designed so that pedestrians walk parallel to moving cars in parking aisles. The project
should be designed to minimize the need for the pedestrian to cross parking aisles and landscape islands to reach
building entries.

c.

All projects should provide a clear connection between the on-site pedestrian circulation system and the off-site
public sidewalk.
(i)

Parking lots with over 200 stalls should provide a well-defined pedestrian walkway from the public sidewalk to
the main on-site pedestrian circulation system. The walkway may be painted; however on large projects, a
raised sidewalk may be required.

(ii)

When a pedestrian circulation route crosses a vehicle circulation aisle adjacent to a building entrance, the
pedestrian crossing should be emphasized by extending the sidewalk to the back of the parking spaces (if they
exist) and by painting a crosswalk through the traffic aisle.

25.

Landscaping. Landscaping should serve to frame, soften and embellish the quality of the environment; buffer units from
noise or undesirable views; visually reduce or break up building mass, break up large expanses of parking and hardscape
and provide shading and climatic cooling of adjacent units.
a.

All areas not covered by structures, drive aisles, parking or hardscape should be appropriately landscaped.

b.

Landscape planters minimum 25-feet in width shall be provided adjacent along portions of proposed parcels that
front a public street. Said planter shall consist of turf and also include the following:
(i)

6″ high berms;

(ii)

Mature trees (36″ box or larger) planted 20 foot on center;

(iii)

Accent landscaping at driveway entries including developed trees of a species which is tall in height.

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

c.

Corner lots shall include accent landscaping and a focal point such as waterfalls or other hardscape and perennials wit
landscape area.

26.

Recreational facilities. Recreational facilities shall be provided throughout the facility. The recreational facilities shall
consist of open or enclosed areas for residents of the facility to congregate, for recreation and leisure. The following
standards shall be utilized for recreational facilities:
a.

The design and orientation of these areas should take advantage of available sunlight and should be sheltered from
the noise and traffic of adjacent street or other incompatible uses.

b.

Each recreational facility shall have a focal point. The focal point may consist of, but need not be limited to, water
fountains, landscape planters, monuments, waterways, ponds, artwork, trellises or gazebos. The focal point of all
recreational facilities shall complement one another by maintaining a common theme, consistent furnishing and
signage

c.

Recreational facilities shall be categorized as either "Major Recreational Facilities" or "Minor Recreational Facilities."
Major and Minor recreational facilities shall be designed to complement one another and be physically linked to
one another by pedestrian walkways and directional signage. Major and minor recreational facilities shall be
provided throughout senior citizen projects as stipulated in the following table:
