27.

Private open space. Each dwelling unit within a multiple unit residential development shall be provided a private open
space area, free and clear of any attached or detached accessory structures, as follows:
a.

Ground level units shall be provided a 100 Square feet private yard at grade level, with a minimum interior
dimension of 10 feet.

b.
28.

Upper level units shall be provided a 100 SF balcony, with a minimum interior dimension of 8 Feet.

Pedestrian Paths. Pedestrian paths shall be clearly separated from vehicular traffic and be designed so as to take
advantage of topography, views, and the natural features of the site. Furthermore, the path system should link buildings,
major and minor recreational areas, parking areas, entrances to the development and off-site connections to nearby
public transportation and surrounding commercial establishments.

29.

Lighting. Lighting should provide illumination for the security and safety of on-site areas, such as parking, recreational
facilities, building entries, and pathways. The following standards shall be utilized.
a.

The design of light fixtures and their structural supports should be architecturally compatible with the main,
structures on the site. Light fixtures should be architecturally integrated into the design of a structure.

b.

The location of light fixtures should correspond to anticipated use. Lighting of pedestrian ways should illuminate
changes in grade, path intersections, staging areas and any other uses along the movement path that, if left
unlighted, would create an unsafe situation.

c.

All lighting fixtures must be shielded to confine light spread on-site.

d.

Night lighting of buildings is encouraged, but should be accomplished in a selective manner, avoiding overall
building illumination that produces an undesirable look. Night lighting of buildings may be used to highlight special
building features, emphasize repeated or decorative features, and use the juxtaposition of light and shadow to
articulate the building façade.

30.

Public transportation amenities.
a.

On site—Sheltered bus stop with canopy.

b.

Off site—In cases when a public bus stop is located within the frontage of a proposed property, a bus stop
enclosure or cover shall be provided with architecture consistent with project.

31.

Security considerations.
276/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

a.

Provide clear, unobstructed sightlines from entries to the street or parking lot.

b.

Provide clear sightlines to outdoor open areas from doorways and windows.

c.

Light exterior spaces and internal common spaces with energy-efficient, vandal-proof lamps and fixtures. Light
fixtures that provide warm light should be used. They appear noninstitutional and increase the feeling of ownership
as well as provide for visibility.

d.

Locate laundry facilities in an area where they can be observed and where access can be effectively restricted.

e.

Create privacy for the ground-level units by using landscaping or fencing to buffer them from the street or parking.
Do not place landscaping too close to windows as this may provide a place for an intruder to hide.

f.

Make paths to the entry, the parking, and the trash deposit area well-defined, well-lighted, and free from dense
shrubs.

g.

Eliminate hidden recesses in hallways, entryways, and stairways. Ensure that there are no entrapment areas
between buildings.

h.

Design common spaces to encourage a sense of belonging. Design common open spaces to relate to a discrete
number of units so that these spaces become "their" recreational area.

i.

Define the transition from the public street to the building so that the yard next to the building reads as belonging
to the building. Landscaped gardens and see-through fences create the sense of ownership and boundaries without
compromising visibility.

j.
G.

Provide peepholes, strike plates, and deadbolts in unit doors.

Maintenance.
a.

Continued good appearance depends on the extent and quality of maintenance. Materials and finishes shall be selected
for their durability and wear, as well as for their beauty. Proper measures shall be taken for protection against weather,
neglect, damage, and abuse.

b.

Provision for washing and cleaning buildings and structures, and control of dirt and refuse, shall be included in the
design. Configurations that tend to catch and accumulate leaves, dirt, and trash shall be avoided.

H.

Affordability.
1.

At least 30% of the dwelling units developed shall be available at affordable housing cost to persons and families of low
and moderate income.

2.

At least 40% of the 30% described above shall be available at affordable housing cost to very low-income households.

3.

The restrictions must remain available for the longer of 30 years or the period of land use controls established in the
redevelopment plan for the project area where the development is located, if within a project area. The City and/or the
Redevelopment Agency of the City of Pomona shall be named specifically in the Covenants, Conditions, & Restrictions
(CC&R's) having the right to enforce the affordability restrictions.

4.

The City reserves the right to require more stringent low-moderate income requirements under circumstances where the
City or the Redevelopment Agency deems that the City/Agency has participated in financially assisting the development.

5.

The City Manager's office and Planning Division shall agree to the selected management firm based on experience and
services provided.

(Ord. No. 3919, § 5.)

Sec. .5809-19. - Cyber cafes.
A.

Applicability.

Cyber cafes, as defined in Subsection B, are permitted in the C-3 (General Commercial), C-C (Community Shopping Center
Commercial), and C-4 (Highway Commercial) zones. Cyber cafes shall not be permitted in a specific plan area unless explicitly listed as a
permissible use. All cyber cafes shall comply with the development and operational standards outlined in Subsections C and D of this
section.
B.

Definitions.

277/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

"Cyber cafe" is defined as an establishment whose primary purpose is to provide computer access including, but not limited to,
access to the Internet, e-mail, video games, or computer software programs that are networked (via LAN or WAN, which functions as a
client/server program, or via other electronic devices) in exchange for money or other compensation. "Cyber cafe" is synonymous with
"PC cafe," "Internet cafe," "cyber center," and similar terms, but does not include "cyber learning center."
"Cyber learning center" is defined as an establishment that provides computer access and is operated by the City of Pomona, a
school district, a college district, or a university, or is operated by a non-profit organization without monetary charge.
C.

Development Standards.
1.

Each cyber cafe shall conform to all property development standards of the zoning district in which it is located.

2.

Each cyber cafe shall provide vehicle parking as required by Section .503-H (Off-Street Parking) of the Zoning Ordinance.

3.

Each cyber cafe shall provide bicycle parking at the rate of one (1) space for every four (4) computers. Bicycle parking
facilities shall consist of sturdy metal racks to which bicycles can be secured in a manner that will deter theft. Bicycle
parking facilities shall be provided near the main entrance of the building in a location that does not block pedestrian or
vehicle circulation and that is highly visible from public areas.

D.

Operating Standards.
1.

Cyber cafes shall be closed to the public between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.

2.

A waiting area with a minimum of one (1) seat for every four (4) computer workstations shall be provided inside a cyber
cafe for customers waiting to use a computer. Outside waiting and seating areas are prohibited.

3.

Minors (under 18 years of age) shall not be permitted to enter or remain in a cyber cafe from 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m.,
Monday through Friday, or after 10:00 p.m., Monday through Sunday. Notice of these hours of restriction shall be posted
at the building entrance in lettering at least two (2) inches high.

Exception: The above daytime hours of restriction shall not apply to minors during school vacations or holidays established by
any public school district or private school operating in the City of Pomona, or to minors who are accompanied by a parent or
guardian (when the guardian is able to show proof of guardianship).
4.

There shall be a minimum of one (1) employee over the age of twenty-one (21) managing a cyber cafe whenever it is
open to the public. If a cyber cafe has more than thirty (30) computers, an additional employee over the age of eighteen
(18) must be on the premises. During working hours, each employee must wear a badge providing the business name
and the employee's first and last name.

Exception: The above requirement for an additional employee shall not apply to periods that public schools are in session,
generally, Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m.
5.

The Chief of Police is authorized to require the owner/operator to provide a California licensed, uniformed security guard
on the business premises during specified hours of operation in the event that the number of calls for service related to
homicide, assault, gang activity, weapons offences, and/or juvenile crime exceed an average of two (2) calls per month for
any three (3) month period.

In addition to the foregoing, in the event that the Chief of Police determines that public safety at any particular cyber cafe, or
within one-mile therefrom, necessitates greater security at that cyber cafe, then the Chief of Police is authorized to require a security
guard at such cyber cafes as described immediately above. In so authorizing, the Chief of Police shall produce written findings
concerning the public safety concerns necessitating the need for a security guard (whether gang activity, criminal activity, or other
public safety concerns) and describing how requiring a security guard will address these concerns.
A decision of the Chief of Police regarding a security guard may be appealed to the City Council within ten (10) calendar days
following the date of the decision. All appeals shall be filed in writing with the Planning Division and the City Clerk, and shall specify
in what respect the Chief of Police committed an error of decision. Upon receipt of the written appeal, the Planning Division shall set
the matter for hearing by the City Council. The City Council may, after a public hearing, affirm, reverse, or modify the original
decision within the limits imposed by this section of the Zoning Ordinance.
Any decision of the Chief of Police to require a security guard as provided herein shall not be stayed pending appeal to the City
Council, except as may be voluntarily stayed by the Chief of Police.

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

6.

There shall be a camera/video surveillance system capable of delineating upon playback of the system the activity and phys
people within a cyber cafe. The system shall cover all entrances, exits, and interior spaces, except for restrooms and private
times, the system shall be maintained in good working order so as to provide for the continuous recording of video images.
recordings shall be maintained for a minimum period of seventy-two (72) hours. The system shall be subject to inspection b
time during the hours of operation for the cyber cafe.

7.

"No loitering" signs shall be posted at the front and rear of a cyber cafe.

8.

Interior lighting shall be maintained at a minimum of thirty (30) footcandles. Exterior lighting within sixty (60) feet of the
cyber cafe and within all required parking areas for the use shall be maintained at a minimum of one (1) footcandle.

9.

The owner/operator shall receive approval for an exit plan from the Fire Department. The plan shall address all
requirements of the Uniform Building Code and Uniform Fire Code.

10.

The maximum occupancy shall not exceed that specified by the Uniform Building Code and Uniform Fire Code. The
occupancy limit shall be prominently posted within the cyber cafe and monitored at all times.

11.

Windows shall not be tinted or covered in any way that obstructs a clear view of the interior of the premises from the
exterior. Window blinds and/or other coverings will be allowed as needed to provide shade from direct sunlight during
daylight hours only.

12.

There shall be no pay telephones equipped to receive incoming calls installed within the enclosed portion of a cyber cafe
or any outdoor area under the control of the owner/operator.

13.

Consumption of alcohol is prohibited within the enclosed portion of a cyber cafe or any area under the control of the
owner/operator.

14.

Pool tables and skill game machines, as defined in Section .5809.5 of the Zoning Ordinance, are prohibited.

15.

Any adult entertainment is prohibited unless specifically approved pursuant to the requirements of Zoning Ordinance
Section .5809-5 and Pomona City Code Section 14.5-9.

Sec. .5809-21. - Retail tobacco stores (smoke shops).
A.

Applicability.

Retail tobacco stores, as defined in Subsection B, are conditionally permitted in the C-1 (Neighborhood Commercial), C-2
(Neighborhood Shopping Center Commercial), C-3 (General Commercial) C-C Community Commercial, C-4 (Highway Commercial) zones.
Retail tobacco stores shall not be permitted in a specific plan area unless explicitly listed as a permissible use. All retail tobacco stores
shall comply with the development and operational standards outlined in Subsections C and D of this section.
B.

Definitions.

Retail tobacco stores for the purposes of this ordinance shall be defined as follows:
"Retail tobacco store" means a retail store where at least twenty percent of the annual gross receipts are from the sale of tobacco
products and smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental.
As used in the definition above, the term "tobacco product" will be defined as follows:
"Tobacco product" means any substance containing any tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco,
snuff, chewing tobacco and smokeless tobacco.
C.

Development Standards.
1.

Each retail tobacco store shall conform to all property development standards of the zoning district in which it is located.

2.

Each retail tobacco store shall provide vehicle parking as required by Section .503-H (Off-Street Parking) of the Zoning
Ordinance.

3.

Each retail tobacco store shall not be located within 1,500-feet from other such businesses, residential areas, as well as
from public or private schools and parks.

4.

Any proposed retail tobacco stores shall be subject to a Conditional Use Permit in the C-1, C-2, C-3, C-C, and C-4.

279/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

D.

Operating Standards.
1.

Retail tobacco stores shall only operate between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

2.

No on sale or off sale of alcohol shall be permitted.

(Ord. No. 4025, § 2.)

Sec. .5809-22. - Tattoo establishments.
A.

Purpose and Intent: The general purpose and intent of the tattoo establishment regulations are to protect the public health,
safety, and general welfare by requiring that all tattoo establishments conform to Los Angeles County health and safety
regulations pertaining to tattoo parlors and to City regulations that will minimize impacts to surrounding properties.

B.

Applicability.

Tattoo parlors and facilities, as defined in Subsection C, are permitted in the C-4 (Highway Commercial) zone with approval of a
conditional use permit and subject to the development and operational standards contained in Section .5809-22 D.
The requirement for a conditional use permit shall not be applicable to exhibitions and/or trade shows involving tattoo parlors and
facilities, as defined in Section .5809-22, located in the F (Fair) Zone.
C.

Definitions.

Tattoo parlors and facilities:
Tattoo parlors and facilities shall mean any establishment at which tattooing is conducted or occurs, whether on a temporary,
interim, regular, or long-term basis.
Tattooing:
Means to insert pigment under the surface of the skin of a human being, by pricking with a needle or otherwise, to produce an
indelible mark or figure visible through the skin.
D.

Development and operational standards.
(1)

Business operating hours shall be limited to the hours 9:00 am and 10:00 pm.

(2)

The consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages on the premises is prohibited.

(3)

No tattoo parlor or facility shall be located within 500 feet of another tattoo parlor or facility, church, school, public park,
day care center, or community center.

(4)

All tattoo parlors and facilities, as defined in Section .5809-22C, are subject to the provisions of Los Angeles County Code
Chapter 11.36—Body Art Establishments as currently written, or as may from time to time be amended, and Los Angeles
County Code Environmental Health Regulations Part 1, Chapter 36—Body Art Regulations as currently written or as may,
from time to time, be amended.

(5)

Before issuance of a zoning clearance/business license from the City of Pomona, each person proposing to establish a
tattoo parlor or tattoo facility shall provide proof to the Planning Division that they have obtained a public health facility
permit from the County of Los Angeles.

(Ord. No. 4052, § 3.)

Sec. .5809-23. - Oak tree preservation.
A.

Purpose and Intent. The purpose of this Section is to promote the public health, safety and welfare by providing for the
preservation of mature Oak trees located within the City. Such Oak trees enhance neighborhood aesthetics, provide shade, aid
in erosion control and generally enhance the quality of life.

It is the intent of this Section to establish regulations for the protection of mature Oak trees located on public and private property
that are not currently protected under existing regulations so as to retain as many of these trees as possible consistent with the
reasonable enjoyment of such property.
B.

Definitions.

280/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Deadwood - means any limbs, branches or portion of a tree that contains no green leaves during a period of the year when they
should be present.
Historic District - means any area that has been designated as a historic district pursuant to Section .5809-13 of the Zoning
Ordinance and placed on the historic register.
Historic Landmark - means any improvement or natural feature that has been designated a single historic landmark of the City of
Pomona pursuant to Section .5809-13 and placed on the historic register.
Specimen Tree - means any tree designated as a "specimen tree" pursuant to City Council Resolutions No. 62-65 and No. 73-68.
Table 1: Oaks Currently Designated as Specimen Trees

Common Name

1837 Berkshire

C.

Applicability. The provisions of this Section shall apply to Oak trees of all species that have a diameter greater than eight (8)
inches as measured 4.5 feet above the mean natural grade, are located outside of designated Historic Districts and Historic
Landmarks and have not been designated as Specimen Trees. Such Oak trees may be located on either public or private
property.

D.

Permit Process. No person shall trim, prune, cut, relocate or remove any Oak tree subject to the provisions of this Section
unless a valid Major or Minor Oak Tree Permit has been issued by the City pursuant to provisions of this Section.
1.

Major and Minor Oak Tree Permits. Minor Oak Tree Permits are subject to administrative review by the Planning
Manager and City Arborist. Major Oak Tree Permits are subject to a public hearing before the Planning Commission. Not
less than ten (10) days before the date set for the Planning Commission hearing, notice of the hearing shall be published
in a daily newspaper of general circulation and mailed to owners and occupants of property located within a radius of
four hundred (400) feet from the external boundaries of the property described in the OTP application.

281/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

2.

Review and Recommendation by City Arborist. All applications for Major and Minor Oak Tree Permits are subject to review a
recommendation by the City Arborist before final approval of an Oak Tree Permit by the Planning Commission or Planning M

3.

Trimming. All Oak trees subject to the provisions of this Section shall be trimmed under the direction of a certified
arborist in a manner that is consistent with the adopted trimming policies outlined in the City of Pomona Street Tree
Policy Manual and ISA standards.

4.

Application Requirements for Minor Oak Tree Permits. On forms available in the Planning Division, an application for a
Minor Oak Tree Permit for trimming shall be submitted, together with any required fee, to the Planning Division. The
application shall include recent photos of each Oak tree proposed to be trimmed.

5.

Application Requirements for Major Oak Tree Permits. An application for a Major Oak Tree Permit for relocation or
removal shall be submitted, together with any required fee, to the Planning Division. The application shall contain the
following information and items:
a.

A statement as to the reasons for the proposed relocation or removal;

b.

The number, species and size (diameter measured 4.5 feet above the mean natural grade) of the Oak tree(s)
proposed to be relocated or removed;

c.

A site plan showing the location of all trees on the subject property in relation to existing and proposed structures
and improvements such as buildings, streets, sidewalks, fences, slopes, retaining walls, public right-of-way or
improvement, etc.;

6.

d.

Photographs of the Oak tree(s) proposed to be relocated or removed;

e.

Proposed method of removal or relocation;

f.

Identification of the relocation site and methods of site preparation; and

g.

Verification by the City Arborist of the health of any Oak tree declared diseased, infested or dying.

Findings for Major Oak Tree Permits. A Major Oak Tree Permit for relocation or removal may only be approved based on
the following findings:
a.

The proposed relocation or removal of the Oak tree(s) will not result in soil erosion through the diversion or
increased flow of surface waters which cannot be satisfactorily mitigated;

b.

The proposed relocation or removal of the Oak tree(s) is necessary as continued existence at the present location
impedes the planned improvement or proposed use of the subject property to such an extent that:
i.)

Alternative development plans cannot achieve the same permitted density or the cost of such alternative
would be prohibitive, or

ii.)

Placement of the Oak tree(s) precludes the reasonable and efficient use of such property for a use otherwise
authorized;

c.

The proposed trimming, cutting and pruning will be limited to the minimum necessary to promote the health of the
tree and protect the public safety, and whenever possible trees should remain in place or be moved only the
minimum distance necessary to preserve the health of the tree and protect the public safety.

d.

The Oak tree(s) proposed for relocation or removal interferes with utility services or streets and highways, either
within or outside of the subject property, and no reasonable alternative to such interference exists other than the
relocation or removal of the Oak tree(s);

e.

The condition of the Oak tree(s) proposed for removal with reference to seriously debilitating disease or danger of
falling is such that it cannot be remedied through reasonable preservation procedures and practices; and

f.

The proposed relocation or removal of the Oak tree(s) will not be contrary to or in substantial conflict with the
purpose and intent of the Oak Tree Permit process.

7.

Appeals. Within ten (10) calendar days of a determination on a Minor Oak Tree Permit by the Planning Manager or a
determination on a Major Oak Tree Permit by the Planning Commission, the application for an Oak Tree Permit may be
appealed to the Planning Commission in the case of the Planning Manager's decision or to the City Council in the case of
the Planning Commission's decision. The appeal shall be submitted to the Planning Division on forms available in the
Planning Division.

282/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

E.

Exemptions. The following activities are exempt from the requirements of the Oak Tree Permit process:
1.

City Arborist initiated trimming of Oak trees located on City property only when the minimum amount of trimming
needed will be carried out to foster and preserve the health and aesthetics of the tree, or to correct or prevent a
potentially dangerous or hazardous condition posing an immediate threat to public health, safety and welfare subject to
all provisions of Section .5809-23 D 6. Findings for Major Oak Tree Permits;

2.

Removing the dead wood from Oak trees located on private and City property without damaging any living portions of
the trees;

3.

Trimming, relocation or removal of Oak trees planted, grown or held for sale by a licensed nursery or tree farm;

4.

Trimming, relocation or removal of Oak trees located on property within a rail road right-of-way;

5.

Trimming, relocation or removal of Oak trees located on property owned by Caltrans or the Los Angeles County Flood
Control District; and

6.

Trimming, relocation or removal of Oak trees that the City Arborist determines are dangerous or hazardous and pose an
immediate threat to the public health, safety and welfare.

7.

Utility company or utility service trimming, relocating or removal of an Oak tree(s) when the City Arborist or a State
licensed, City approved arborist provides documentation that the trimming, relocation or removal is needed to correct or
prevent a potentially dangerous or hazardous condition posing an immediate threat to the public health, safety and
welfare. Said trimming, relocating or removal shall be proposed and completed in a manner to preserve, to the fullest
extent possible, the tree in place, with the minimum physical alteration needed to preserve the health of the tree and
protect public safety.

Within ten (10) days of completing said trimming, the City Arborist or the State licensed, City approved arborist shall perform a
field inspection of the completed work on the tree(s) in question and shall provide written documentation that the work was
completed in conformance with all standards and requirements contained within Section .5809-23 "Oak Tree Preservation."
F.

Permit Expiration. An approved Major or Minor Oak Tree Permit shall be valid for not more than thirty (30) calendar days from
the date of Permit approval. One (1) thirty (30) day extension may be granted by the Planning Manager without fee.

G.

Final Oak Tree Permit Inspection. Within seventy-two (72) hours of the completion of any trimming, cutting, pruning, relocation
or removal of an Oak tree(s) under an approved Major or Minor Oak Tree Permit, the permittee shall contact the Planning
Division to request a final inspection. Said inspection shall be completed by the City Arborist within seventy-two (72) hours of
the Planning Division's having received the inspection request to verify that all work was performed in conformance with the
approved Oak Tree Permit and this Ordinance.

Unless a final inspection is requested and completed within thirty (30) calendar days following the approval of a Major or Minor Oak
Tree Permit, or an extension thereof, the City Arborist shall perform a field inspection to verify that all work was completed in
conformance with the approved Oak Tree Permit and this Ordinance.
If the final inspection determines that the work performed was not completed in conformance with the approved Oak Tree Permit or
the Ordinance, then the work shall be corrected within seven (7) calendar days following written notice from the Planning Manager of
said nonconformance, or within a time period approved by the Planning Manager. Failure of the permittee to complete the required
corrections shall be deemed to constitute a misdemeanor as noted in Subsection "I" herein for each tree identified within the Oak Tree
Permit which was not altered in compliance with said Permit and this Ordinance. Further, upon conviction of a misdemeanor for violation
of this section, if any Oak tree identified within the approved Oak Tree Permit dies within three (3) years of the date of conviction, then
the person so convicted shall be required to pay to the City the dollar amount for a replacement tree of equal size, including installation
costs. The dollar replacement value shall be determined by the criteria set forth by the International Society of Arboriculture (ISA). Said
dollar value shall be remitted to the City and used only to install a new Oak tree(s) within the same City Council district where the dead
tree(s) was originally located.
H.

Oak Tree Replacement and Mitigation. The planting of replacement trees or other mitigation measures shall be included as
conditions of permit approval for the removal of Oak trees subject to the provisions of this Section.

For residential property, the removal of each Oak tree will require replacement with a minimum twenty-four (24)-inch-box Oak tree
on a one-to-one basis. For institutional, commercial or industrial property, the removal of each Oak tree will require replacement with a
minimum thirty-six (36)-inch-box Oak tree on a one-to-one basis. Additional or larger trees and other vegetation may be required as
283/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

conditions of permit approval, if they are determined to be necessary to compensate for the loss of the original Oak tree(s) and/or to aid
in erosion control or to otherwise protect the environment from the effects of the tree removal.
Replacement Oak trees must be planted on the property where the Oak trees were removed. However, if an appropriate replanting
location does not exist, the replacement trees may be donated to the City or their monetary value may be paid to the City to the
satisfaction of the City Arborist. Any monies paid shall be used to purchase an Oak tree(s) for planting within the City in a location(s)
recommended by the City Arborist.
I.

Penalties. Any person who trims, prunes, cuts, relocates or removes an Oak tree(s) tree with a diameter greater than eight (8)
inches as measured 4.5 feet above the mean natural grade in violation of this Section shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, may be punished as set forth in Section 1-7 (c) of the Pomona City Code. Further, if any
Oak tree(s) so trimmed, pruned, cut, relocated or removed dies within three (3) years of the date of conviction, then the
person so convicted shall be required to pay to the City the dollar amount for a replacement tree of equal size, including
installation costs. The dollar replacement value shall be determined by the criteria set forth by the International Society of
Arboriculture (ISA). Said dollar value shall be remitted to the City and used only to install a new Oak tree(s) within the same
City Council district where the dead tree(s) was originally located.

(Ord. No. 4076, § 2.)

Sec. .58010. - Development for hillside property.
A.

PURPOSE.

The purpose of this section is to encourage the orderly development of hillside areas by relating the number and distribution of
dwelling units and other buildings to the topography, so that the terrain will suffer minimum disfigurement by scarring from extensive
cut and fill. These regulations are also designed to minimize danger to life and property due to the hazards of fire, flood, soil erosion,
seepage and destruction of the natural topography and plant material of the area and in addition to those having to do with excavations
and fills generally in other regulations and ordinances.
B.

DEFINITION OF HILLSIDE AND APPLICATION OF THIS SECTION.

"Hillside areas" mean areas which in general have a median slope before grading of ten percent or more on fifty percent or more of
the site, or less steep lands which are strongly related to areas of greater slope.
Areas defined as hillside based on the above description shall be designated on the zoning map as an "H" overlay zone.
Before such "H" overlay zone is applied to such map, however, a hearing shall be held before the planning commission and evidence
presented to establish if such area qualifies as a hillside area under the definition set forth in this ordinance. Notice of such hearing shall
be given in the same manner as provided for a change of zoning district map, and final decision shall be made by the city council upon
further hearing after recommendation is made by the planning commission. The initiation of such hearings may only be by motion of the
planning commission or the city council.
The provisions of the base zone shall apply except for those regulations contained in the "H" zone, which shall have those in the base
zone. These additional requirements shall be those set forth in this section.
C.

DESIGNATION OF NATURAL SCENIC AREAS TO BE PRESERVED AS OPEN SPACES.

The city council, upon recommendation of the planning commission, may designate within a hillside area "natural and scenic areas."
No such areas shall be so designated until notice has been given and hearings held before the planning commission and the city council
in the same manner as that provided for a change of the zoning district map. Before such designation is made, however, evidence must
be presented, and upon such evidence, a finding must be made that the land is unusual in its natural state and will, if preserved,
enhance the surrounding property. Whenever an area has been so designated as a natural scenic area, such area shall not be considered
part of the required setback for any development of any lot and shall not be calculated as part of the minimum area for lot requirement
for any subdivided lot, and no building or structure may be constructed in such area. To compensate the owner of the land being
developed when part of such land being developed is designated as a natural scenic area, the loss of density may be made up through
application to the advisory review board. The advisory review board may designate the change in density to compensate for the loss of
the use of the natural scenic area for building purposes by reducing the lot size or density requirements in the remaining part of the
284/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

subdivision then being subdivided, and it may designate credits toward future subdivisions in an area designated by it. The
recommendations of the advisory review board in this regard shall be guided in such a manner as to spread the allowable density as
evenly as possible over the remaining property not consumed by the natural scenic areas. The recommendation of the advisory review
board on this subject shall be reported to the planning commission and the planning commission's decision shall, within ten days after
the announcement of its decision, be appealable to the city council.
D.

TENTATIVE SITE PLAN AND CERTAIN ASPECTS OF BUILDING DESIGN APPROVAL.

Plot plans and building designs for structures proposed to be erected within a hillside area shall be submitted to the planning
director who may at his discretion submit them for review by the advisory review board. However, such plot plans and building designs
shall be reviewed by the planning commission and the city council. The planning director or the advisory review board, if submitted to it,
may make recommendations concerning such plot plans and building designs to the planning commission, and it in turn shall make its
recommendations concerning them to the city council. The city council shall make the final decision in approving or disapproving such
plans or reuire for approval certain modifications or conditions. The purpose of such review and approval of such plans and designs shall
be for determining if, because of the plan or building design, the view of neighboring property will be severely curtailed or blocked, and if
by any reason of the site plan or building design, problems detrimental to the health, safety or general welfare of the surrounding
territory may be caused. It shall comply with:
1.

Minimum lot sizes based on the grade of slope prior to grading in the following manner:

Minimum Lot Size

Grade of Slope

0—10%

10,000 sq. ft.

a.

In the 10-30% grade of slope classification, 90% of the lots shall have 10,000 square feet or more and the average of
all lots shall be 10,000 square feet or over.

b.

In the 30-40% grade of slope classification, 90% of the lots shall have a minimum of 20,000 square feet or more and
the average of all lots shall be 20,000 square feet or more.

c.

In the 40% grade or more of slope classification, 90% of the lots shall be one acre or more and the average of all lots
shall be one acre or more.

d.

In all cases, where deviations from the minimum lot size are permitted, no lot shall be less than 7,200 square feet.

e.

In the consideration of planned unit or cluster type housing development, the planning commission can provide for
modification from the preceding lot size minimum standards.

f.

Grade of Slope Map. In order to determine the areas to which the various grade of slope classifications shall apply,
a hearing shall be held before the planning commission and city council in the same manner as for a change of
zoning district map, and final decision shall be made by the city council after recommendation is made by the
planning commission. The initiation of such proceedings may be by the planning commission, city council or the
property owner. The grade of slope map shall, when adopted, be made a part of the "H" overlay zone district and
shall dictate by zoning district designation the minimum lot sizes as contained in subsection D-l.

g.

Preparation of Grade of Slope Map T he classifications on the grade of slope map shall be determined by calculating
the change in elevation of the natural grade per one hundred feet of horizontal distance.

2.

Saving of natural rock features, when designated as a natural scenic area.

3.

The outside corners or edges of all cut and fill slopes except at the tops of slopes shall be required to be rounded to
eliminate the sharp corners and shall have a minimum curvature of radius of at least five feet.

Building design shall accommodate to the hillside and to the specific site in question. The use of supporting stilts shall be

E.

In any land division in a hillside area, all downhill slopes shall be made part of the lot at the lower elevation.

LANDSCAPING.

The following criteria shall apply to all hillside areas where planting is required under E., "Landscaping."
1.

Design.

As a condition to the approval of and prior to the recordation of a final map or issuance of a building or grading permit,
whichever is first, landscaping plans including planting design and an irrigation system, all of which are prepared by a licensed
landscape architect, shall be submitted by the applicant and reviewed and approved by the advisory review board and the planning
commission, and may be appealed to and by the city council.
All cut, fill, and natural slopes shall be planted with deep rooted plants or other plants approved by the parks superintendent,
that are able to acclimate to their environment. To promote growth of the plants that protect the slopes against erosion, an
approved irrigation system shall be installed that will uniformly cover all planted areas.
In approving or denying the landscaping plans, the following shall be considered: The screening of parking areas in multiple
residential or non-residential developments, the planting of slopes for stabilization, and the fire resistance ability, durability, size,
and quality of the proposed plant material and the planting design. Proof of the ability of the soil to sustain the proposed plant
material may be required and if so required, the developer shall provide such proof at his own expense.
Slope planting and an irrigation system shall be provided by the owner on all slopes of three feet or more in vertical height. The
subject cut and fill slopes shall be adequately planted with landscaping consisting of one-third shrubs and trees and the other twothirds may be grass or ground cover and/or trees and shrubs. The final plans showing the landscaping and irrigation shall be subject
to the approval of the advisory review board. All irrigation systems and planting shall be complete and operative on an individual lot
basis before final approval of the finished grade and before occupancy of any building pursuant to the building code.
2.

Planting details.
a.

Plants consisting of grass, ground cover, shrubs and trees as recommended on the planting schedule in this
ordinance shall be used. Other plants recommended by landscape architects may be submitted to the parks
superintendent for approval.

b.

In addition to ground cover plants, approved shrubs having a minimum one gallon size at ten feet on center, in both
directions on the slope, or trees at twenty feet on center both ways may be used. A combination of shrubs and
trees may be utilized. This plant and planting pattern may be varied upon the recommendation of a landscape
architect and approval by the park superintendent.

3.

Irrigation details.

The owner shall water the slopes which have been planted at sufficient time intervals to promote growth.
a.

Minimum irrigation requirements for slopes of three feet or more in vertical height shall be as follows:
(1)

A sprinkler system which is operative on an individual lot basis shall be installed to adequately irrigate these
slopes prior to planting of the trees, shrubs, and ground cover.

b.

Special requirements for sprinkler systems.
(1)

Plans for the sprinkler system shall be submitted to and approved by the park superintendent prior to
installation.

(2)

Sprinkler systems shall be designed to provide a uniform water coverage at a rate of precipitation of not less
than one-tenth inch per hour nor more than three-tenths inch per hour on the planted slope. In no event shall
the rate of precipitation duration of sprinkling be permitted to create a saturated condition and cause an
286/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

erosion problem, or allow the discharge of excess water into any public or private street.
(3)

A check valve and balance cock shall be installed in the system where drainage from sprinkler heads will create
an erosion problem.

(4)

A functional test of the sprinkler system shall be performed by the installer for every sprinkler system prior to
approval.

@ 2 lbs. per 1,000 sq. ft.; Approved Native Plant and Wild Flower Seeds, @¼ lbs., per 1,000 sq. ft.

Annual or Italian Rye Grass; Lolium perenne—Perennial Rye Grass.

Maintenance.

It shall be the responsibility of the developer to plant, water and maintain all graded slopes as required by this ordinance until
the properties within the development have been occupied. A landscape maintenance bond for one year's duration from the date of
acceptance of landscaping shall be required to guarantee that all plants shall be maintained, and replaced if necessary, until the
subject property is occupied. The landscape maintenance bonds shall not be released until the above conditions have been
approved by the building and planning officials, but may be reduced proportionately as each parcel is occupied or sold but it shall be
the responsibility of the owner to maintain the planting required in this section.
In order to provide access for proper maintenance of the slope banks, no fences or walls shall be built on property in this zone
which would divide the slope banks from the remainder of the lot or parcel, unless such fence or wall is provided with a gate having
a minimum width of three feet which would give access to said slope banks.
(Ord. No. 2465, § 1.)

F.

INCENTIVES.

In order to encourage developers to build in a manner more suitable to the hillsides, the following incentives are available:
1.

If the topographic or other natural conditions do not lend themselves to hillside development due to the provisions of
this ordinance, the developer may apply for a variance for approval of an alternate plan.

2.

The developer may apply for a variance to increase the density of a hillside development up to twenty-five percent in
consideration of his use of planned unit or cluster housing developments or high-rise buildings which are compatible to
their particular sites and surrounding land use, and where compensating increases in utilities, parks, schools and other
necessary services are provided.

3.

Building heights as permitted in the zoning ordinance may be increased by variance approval above that which is
normally allowed when they are compatible to the surrounding areas. The views from adjacent or neighboring parcels
shall not be adversely affected by such height increase.

G.

STREET DESIGN STANDARDS.
1.

Arterial streets as designated in the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways shall have a maximum grade of eight
percent unless substantiating evidence has been submitted to the city engineer which justifies an increase.

2.

Collector and minor collector streets as designated in the Official Plan of Principle Streets and Highways shall have a
maximum grade of fifteen percent, unless substantiating evidence has been submitted to the city engineer which justifies
an increase.

3.

Local streets shall have a maximum grade of twenty percent, provided all grades over fifteen percent shall be improved
with six inches of Portland cement concrete pavement. Streets with grades in excess of fifteen percent shall be allowed
only for four hundred feet or less. The city engineer may modify the foregoing standards if substantiating evidence is
submitted to him justifying the request. Local street right-of-way width shall be a minimum of sixty feet and the width
between curbs shall be a minimum of thirtysix feet. Where exceptional grading and/or topographical conditions exist, the
right-of-way width may be reduced to fifty feet upon approval of the city engineer. Where the right-of-way has been
reduced to fifty feet in width, a five foot street tree easement shall be required on each side of the street. A local street
improvement width of thirty-two feet between curbs may be allowed where lots exist on only one side of the street.

4.

Design criteria shall be based on state highway standards for speed and sight distance, unless substantiating evidence is
submitted to the city engineer justifying a change.
288/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

5.

In all culs-de-sac more than six hundred feet in length, driveway aprons in the public right-of-way of cul-de-sac
turnarounds shall be of Portland cement concrete and designed to standards approved by the city engineer.

6.

Curbs and gutters.
a.

Minimum curb height shall be six inches. However, a higher curb shall be required when deemed necessary by the
city engineer.

7.

b.

Minimum gutter width shall be in accordance with the standards and specifications of the city engineer.

c.

All curbs and gutters shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete.

Slope grading.
a.

All roadway cuts and embankments shall be required to be rounded at the top to the approval of the city engineer
in order to eliminate sharp corners.

H.

DRAINAGE.

No building permits shall be issued for construction on any site which does not have provisions for conducting water drainage from
the site to a natural drainage course, a drainage channel, or a public street in an approved manner.
I.

SEWERAGE TREATMENT.

Sewers for all dwelling units and other buildings which contain plumbing facilities shall connect to public sanitary sewer systems.
J.

EXCAVATIONS AND GRADING.

The following requirements shall be in addition to all other requirements which may from time to time be adopted by the city in
various building and engineering regulations, unless such regulations specifically repeal or state they supersede this ordinance.
1.

When required by the building code, a grading plan based on an accompanying report from a soils engineer and a
geologist who is licensed by the state of California shall be submitted for approval as part of the application for site plan
approval for a hillside development and said plan shall be approved by the advisory review board.

2.

No excavation shall be permitted on any hillside area prior to the approval of a site plan and a grading plan excepting to
drill holes and exploratory trenches for purposes of collecting geological and soils data.

3.

No hillside development shall be approved if a geology report prepared by a geologist who is licensed by the state of
California states that construction should be prohibited.

K.

FIRE PROTECTION.
1.

In fire hazardous areas, unobstructed fire protection equipment access easements shall be required to all parts of the
development and to adjacent areas which are potential fire hazards. The fire chief shall recommend to the planning
commission where such easements are needed.

2.

No ridge which is presently usable for fire fighting shall be graded in relation to hillside development unless an access
way is provided around the cut to the top of the ridge for fire fighting equipment.

3.

Water mains and water systems shall be sized to provide sufficient flow and pressure to meet the fire fighting
requirements of the area involved The, manager of the municipal water company and the fire chief shall review proposed
systems in relation to the American Insurance Association's standards for water systems and make recommendations to
the city council.

L.

BUILDING STANDARDS.

The following standards shall apply to those areas within two hundred feet of a high fire hazard zone:
1.

Any construction including stairs, balconies, porches and open structures under buildings which are not of incombustible
materials or materials approved by the building official as fire-retardant treated wood shall be protected with a surface
of one-hour fire resistive construction.

2.

All eaves shall be fully boxed in with exterior stucco or its equivalent fire resistive construction. Any necessary vents shall
be covered with one-fourth mesh or its equivalent.

In lieu of the above, sprinkler systems approved by the building official may be permitted.
M.

UTILITIES.
289/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

All utilities shall be provided as underground utilities. Transmission lines may not be required to be installed underground where the
public works director has determined that this is not economically feasible.
N.

HILLSIDE ADVISORY REVIEW COMMITTEE.

There is hereby created a five-member hillside advisory review committee to serve in an advisory capacity to the planning
commission. This is not a board or commission and may consist of members who reside in the Southern California area.
1.

Appointment. Members of this committee shall be nominated by the chairman of the planning commission and
approved by a majority vote of the commission.

2.

Qualifications. Four of the members shall possess special qualifications as follows: One shall be a certified engineering
geologist selected from the latest list approved by the Los Angeles County Engineering Geologist Qualification Board; one
shall be a landscape architect; one shall be a civil engineer who practices in soil mechanics and is familiar with the
methods of slope stability analysis; and one shall be an architect. The fifth member may be selected from any
background. Other members may be appointed by the planning commission as they deem necessary.

3.

Terms of office. The terms of office for members of the committee shall be four years, expiring on December thirty-first
of the fourth year of their terms, or until their successors are appointed and qualified. If vacancies should occur other
than by expiration of terms, appointment shall be for such unexpired terms.

4.

Quorum. A majority of the qualified members of the committee shall constitute a quorum to conduct business. Any
action must be by a majority affirmative vote of those members in attendance at a regular, special, or adjourned
meeting.

5.

Meetings. Meetings of the committee shall be open to the public, and notice of the time and place of the meeting at
which his application will be reviewed shall be given to any applicant whose application may be subject to review of the
committee. Such notice shall be in writing and may be delivered personally or by mail, but in any event, must be given at
least twenty-four hours before such meeting. Regular meetings need not be held; however, when special meetings are
called, they shall be called as prescribed by the California Government Code, Section 54950, et seq., by giving at least
twenty-four hours prior written notice by mail to each member of the committee and to all news media requesting such
notice, setting forth the items of the agenda which will be considered and the time and place of such meeting.

6.

Duties. The committee shall review all tentative subdivision maps, applications for variances, conditional use permits,
building permits, zone changes, and other matters in connection with land development within any land designated as
part of the "H" (hillside) overlay zone. The purpose of such review shall be to determine if the provisions of this section
are met. After reviewing the application and all other relevant evidence available to it, the committee shall make findings
and recommendations to the planning commission that such application be approved, approved with conditions or
changes, or denied, together with the reasons for such findings and recommendations. In any event, however, the
decision of the committee shall not be binding or conclusive on any matter until acted upon by the planning commission.
In reviewing any application, the committee shall pay particular attention to the following matters contained within the
following subsections of this section: subsection D-5 (minimizing loss of view); subsection E (landscaping, and screening
of parking areas); and subsection G (street design and traffic circulation).

7.

Appeals. Appeals may be made by any applicant to the city council from the decision of the planning commission based
in whole or in part upon any recommendation made by the committee. Such appeal, however, must be made in the
same manner upon the payment of the same fees as prescribed by this ordinance for an appeal from the decision
concerning a variance.

(Ord. No. 2202, § 1; Ord. No. 2395, § 1-5: Ord. No. 2547, § 1.)

granted unless the following general conditions are found to exist:

planning and land use regulations and the General Plan;

2.

Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, and other necessary facilities have been or will be provided;

The proposed co-operative multiple dwelling will not under the circumstances of the particular case, be a nuisance or be
detrimental to the health, safety, peace, morals, comfort and general welfare of persons residing in the neighborhood;

4.

The proposed co-operative multiple dwelling is not detrimental or injurious to property and improvements in the
neighborhood and is appropriate to the location, the lot and the neighborhood; and

The co-operative multiple dwelling project meets or exceeds all building and zoning standards currently applicable to
new construction of such project.

PUBLIC HEARING

Upon receipt of an application for a public use permit, the commission shall fix a time and place of public hearing thereon
not less than fifteen (15) days, nor more than forty (40) days thereafter. The commission shall hold one public hearing upon the
matters referred to in the application, and thereupon within forty (40) days of the hearing shall make a determination and report
thereon to the council. The council, after receipt of the report and recommendations, shall either approve, modify or reject the
same.

The decision of the planning commission or the city council when an appeal has been heard on any application, shall be final and

same variance, amendment and/or change of zone, conditional use permit, or public use permit relating to the same matter, or for
reclassification of such premises shall be again filed during such period.
(Ord. No. 1821, § 5.)

Sec. .583. - Temporary Uses.
A.

PURPOSE AND INTENT

The purpose of this section is to control and regulate land use activities of a temporary nature which may adversely affect the public
health, safety, and welfare. The intent is to ensure that temporary uses will be compatible with surrounding land uses, to protect the
rights of adjacent residents and land owners, and to minimize any adverse effects on surrounding properties and the environment.
B.

AUTHORITY

The community development director is authorized to approve, conditionally approve or to deny such request. The community
development director may establish conditions and limitations to minimize detrimental effects on surrounding properties, including but
not limited to hours of operation, provision of parking areas, signing, lighting, and traffic circulation access only.
The community development director also may require a cash deposit or cash bond to defray the costs of cleanup of a site by the
city in the event the applicant fails to leave the property in a presentable and satisfactory condition, or to guarantee removal and/or reconversion of any temporary use to a permanent use allowed in the subject zoning district. A business license shall also be obtained.
C.

APPLICATION

292/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

The property owner or the owner's authorized representative shall file an application for a temporary use permit with the planning
division at least ten days prior to the date the proposed use takes place. Circus carnivals, fairs or similar amusement enterprises must
submit application thirty days prior to date the proposed use takes place in a residential zone.
The application form shall be filed along with any data and information deemed necessary to evaluate and process the application as
may be required by the community development director.
D.

REQUIRED FINDINGS

The application shall not be approved as submitted or in modified form unless the community development director may make the
following findings:
1.

The proposed temporary use will be located, operated, and maintained in a manner consistent with the policies of the
General Plan and the provisions of the zoning ordinance.

2.

Approval of the application will not be detrimental to property or improvements in the surrounding area or to the public
health, safety or general welfare.

E.

3.

The proposed temporary use complies with the various provisions of this ordinance.

4.

All building, electric, plumbing, fire, encroachment or other permits required by city ordinances shall be obtained.

PERMITTED USES

The following uses may be allowed in the various zones, subject to the issuance of a temporary use permit.
1.

Christmas tree lots or pumpkin sale lots. A maximum of thirty days is allowed per calendar year per event.

2.

Circuses, carnivals, fairs, or similar amusement enterprises. A maximum ten day period is allowed and safety certification
of rides and equipment is required. In residential zones notice shall be mailed to all property owners within four hundred
feet twenty-one days prior to date of event.

3.

Outdoor meetings, outdoor art and craft shows, group activities, or sales within parking areas. Time limit of seven
consecutive days in each ninety day period.

4.

Sales, bazaars, dinners, parties or other outdoor events (other than uses as listed in 1 and 2 above) held by and on the
property of a religious facility shall not be restricted as to number of occasions or duration. (Ord. No. 4114, § 3.)

5.

Outdoor display and sale of merchandise such as sidewalk sales shall be allowed only for merchandise regularly sold on
premises and located immediately adjacent to the building for a period not to exceed three consecutive days in a ninety
day period.

6.

Single uses in buildings with a minimum of sixty-five thousand square feet of gross floor area may apply for a temporary
use permit to allow the outdoor sales and display of new merchandise in the C-3, C-4 zoning districts and commercial
designated areas of the SP (specific plan) area. The temporary use permit shall be subject to the following conditions:
a.

The sales and display area shall be located immediately adjacent to the building at the main entrance along
walkways adjacent to the street elevation.

b.

The sales and display area shall not encroach into the city right-of-way or required parking and subject to the
following criteria:
i.

Merchandise shall be displayed in a manner that allows free access from all doorways to a separate
pedestrian walkway.

ii.

Merchandise shall be displayed in a manner that allows a minimum designated four-foot walkway for
pedestrians.

iii.

Except at specified access points, designated pedestrian walkways shall be physically separated from vehicular
traffic by a change in elevation, bollards, a fence, hedge, temporary merchandise displays or other physical
barrier.

iv.

Merchandise displays shall not block designated fire lanes.

v.

Merchandise displays shall be subject to the review and approval of the planning manager.

c.

The temporary use permit for outdoor sales and display of merchandise shall be valid for no more than one year.

d.

Outdoor sales and display of merchandise shall not exceed one hundred eighty days in a year.
