Sec. .584. - Speci c plans.
A.

PURPOSE AND INTENT

The intent of this section is to establish uniform procedures for the preparation, processing, adoption and amendment of specific
plans. Specific plans are to provide for the classification and regulation of land use and development with specific project boundaries and
shall implement the goals and objectives of the general plan. Unless otherwise specified within the specific plan itself, it is intended that
the specific plan will replace the base zoning district, and that the development standards contained in the specific plan will take
precedence over this code, where applicable. Where the specific plan is silent regarding a development or improvement standard
contained within this code, this code's standard of the zoning district which most closely resembles the use and intensity of the proposed
development shall apply.
Specific plans shall achieve the following purposes:
1.

To promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare;

2.

To minimize the intrusion of new development into environmentally sensitive areas;

3.

To ensure the timely provision of essential public services and facilities consistent with the demand for such services;

4.

To promote a harmonious variety of housing choices and commercial and industrial activities; to attain a desirable
balance of residential and employment opportunities, a high level of urban amenities, and preservation of natural and
scenic qualities of open space; and

5.

To facilitate quality development within the city by permitting greater flexibility and encouraging more creative and
aesthetically pleasing designs for major urban development projects subject to large scale community planning.

B.

APPLICABILITY

294/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

The provisions of this section shall apply to all parcels of land designated as specific plan areas in the city's general plan and on the
official zoning map. Once a specific plan is noticed for public hearing, no building or grading permit, planned development permit,
conditional use permit, variance, tentative map, or any other entitlement shall be granted for any parcel within any area so designated.
A minimum project area of fifteen acres, as a separate parcel or in combination with adjoining parcels, is required for the filing of a
specific plan application. Such minimum requirement shall not be waived via variance or modification. A specific plan area shall be under
single ownership or otherwise subject to unified planning and development, with the concurrence of all property owners. In cases where
the city is the applicant, said unified ownership or concurrence of owners shall not be required. A specific plan shall be subject to
development review.
C.

ADOPTED SPECIFIC PLANS/MAP DESIGNATION

Areas with an adopted specific plan shall be designated "specific plan" on the general plan map and on the official zoning map as
follows:
In all cases, the "SP" symbol shall be followed by an abbreviation to designate the specific plan (e.g., SP-DT for specific plan
downtown). All development shall be subject to provisions of the designated specific plan, associated documents and the regulations
of this chapter.
The following areas are adopted and designated on the zoning map as specific plan (SP) areas. A copy of the text of these specific
plans shall be kept in the office of the community development department.
1.

Downtown Pomona specific plan (SP-DT).

(Ord. No. 3723, § 5.)

D.

SPECIFIC PLAN CONTENTS

A specific plan may include, but not be limited to, a text and diagram(s) which specify all of the following in detail:
1.

The distribution, location and extent of the land, including open space, within the area covered by the plan;

2.

The proposed distribution, location, extent and intensity of major components of public and private transportation,
sewage, water, drainage, solid waste disposal, energy, parks and other essential facilities proposed to be located within
the area covered by the plan and needed to support the land uses described in the plan;

3.

Standards and criteria by which development will proceed and standards for the conservation, development and
utilization of natural resources, where applicable;

4.

A program of implementation measures including regulations, programs, public works projects, financing measures and
a statement of consistency with any existing master/capital improvements plan necessary to carry out subdivisions 1, 2
and 3 listed above; and

5.

The specific plan shall include a statement of its relationship to the general plan including a statement of how the specific
plan implements the goals and policies of the general plan.

E.

DEVELOPMENT AND DESIGN STANDARDS

The text of the specific plan shall describe the basic land use regulations, site development regulations and performance standards
designed to govern each use identified by the land use plan. The text shall be as comprehensive as necessary to establish basic
provisions and regulations which shall govern subsequent approval of specific tracts or developments within the specific plan. The text
may include, but not be limited to, the following provisions:
1.

A listing of allowable uses within each use area, including such qualifying descriptions or definitions and requirements
for conditional use permits, as may be applicable;

2.

Regulations governing residential density, site coverage, lot size and dimensions, yard requirements, usable open space,
landscaping and performance standards;

3.

Required yards, landscaping or other site development regulations applicable to adjacent other zoning districts at the
perimeter of the specific plan and boundaries;

4.

Supplemental illustrations establishing the basic community architectural character, environmental character and
environmental design qualities to be attained throughout the specific plan and within particular portions of the district;
295/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

5.

A discussion of the architectural, landscaping, streetscape and other urban design features for development within the spec
discussion of standards and concepts shall be specific in nature. Streetscape design concepts shall include, but not be limite
palette, landscaped lots and medians, fence and wall material and placement, lighting, street furniture and equipment scree

6.

For properties having natural slope areas prior to grading of fifteen percent or more, and which propose development in
these areas, hillside development standards shall be prepared and included in the document. The standards shall
include, but not be limited to, measures to minimize grading impacts, erosion control landscaping, modified street
standards, drainage structures compatible with the land form, fencing details, and maximum height or percent of slope
in yard areas.

F.

NOTICING FOR PUBLIC HEARING
1.

Legal notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than ten days
before the date of the hearing. The notice shall contain data pertinent to the case, including date, time, place of hearing
and location of documents for review.

2.

In addition to the item No. 1 of this subsection, written notice shall be mailed in the United States mail not less than ten
days prior to the date of the hearing, to the affected property owners and owners of property within a radius of four
hundred feet from the external boundaries of the property described in the application, using for this purpose of the last
known name and address of such owners as are shown on the tax roll of the county of Los Angeles. Such written notice
shall contain pertinent data related to the case.

3.

If the properties in a project area exceeds one thousand in number, written notice shall be mailed in the United States
mail not less than ten days prior to the date of the hearing, to only those property owners in the area affected by the
proposed specific plan amendment. Such written notice shall contain pertinent data related to the case. In addition,
notice of hearing shall be published in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city, as described in item No. 1 of
this subsection.

(Ord. 3766, § 3.)

G.

COMMISSION ACTION ON SPECIFIC PLANS

The commission shall make a written recommendation via resolution on the proposed specific plan whether to approve, approve in
modified form or disapprove, based upon the findings contained in subsection I of this section. Commission action recommending that
the proposed specific plan be approved, approved in modified form or disapproved shall be considered by the council following
commission action.
H.

COUNCIL ACTION ON SPECIFIC PLANS

Upon receipt of the commission's recommendations, the council shall approve, approve with modifications, or disapprove the
proposed specific plan based upon the findings contained in subsection I of this section.
I.

FINDINGS

A specific plan may be adopted only if all of the following findings are made:
1.

The proposed plan systematically implements and is consistent with the general plan;

2.

The proposed plan will not be detrimental to the public interest, health, safety, convenience, or welfare of the city;

3.

The subject property is physically suitable for the requested land use designation(s) and the anticipated land use
development(s);

4.

The plan provides for the development of a comprehensively planned project that is superior to development otherwise
allowed under conventional zoning classifications; and

5.

The proposed plan will contribute to a balance of land uses so that local residents may work and shop in the community
in which they live.

J.

AMENDMENT PROCEDURE

A specific plan text and map may be amended in the same manner as when adopted except that the specific plan may be amended
as often as deemed necessary by the city council. Amendment of a specific plan text shall be subject to the same findings as prescribed
for initial enactment of a specific plan, pursuant to subsection I of this section. An amendment to a specific plan text and map may be
initiated in the same manner as in subsection B of this section.
296/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

K.

MODIFICATION PROCEDURE
The development and design standards set forth in the text of a specific plan may under certain unique situations be

difficult to integrate into a project which otherwise complies with all other specific plan standards and regulations. In such situations, an
application for a modification of specific plan may be made by the developer of such project. Such application shall be made and
processed in the same manner as are applications for variances, pursuant to Section .560 of this code. Such application may be granted
upon the planning commission finding that:
1.

The modification is necessary to accomplish a physically and economically viable project; and

2.

The modification will effectuate the general purpose and intent of the specific plan.

Specific plan standards and regulations other than those subject to modification, as set forth above, may be changed only by an
amendment to the specific plan. Any modification pursuant to this section shall be specific to the site in question and shall not be
deemed to be an amendment to a specific plan or of any zoning ordinance, subordinate or related to the specific plan.
L.

SPECIFIC PLAN CONSISTENCY

No public works project, tract map, parcel map, conditional use permit, variance, or other land use entitlement may be approved,
adopted or amended within an area covered by a specific plan, unless found consistent with the adopted specific plan.
(Ord. No. 3688, § 4.)

Sec. .590. - Moving of buildings procedure.
No permit shall be issued for the moving of any residential, commercial, or industrial building or structures from one lot to another lot in
the city or from a lot outside of the city to one within the city without the filing of an application for a conditional use permit for a moving of
building permit under the conditional use permit procedures (Sec. .580), except for a single manufactured house where the intended use is
for a single-family dwelling on a single residentially zoned lot.
A.

The following information shall be filed with the planning division at the time the application is made:
1.

Location and address of the old and new site.

2.

Plot plan of the new location, including the showing of adjacent lots on all sides of the property, and an indication of
all structures and improvements on said lots.

3.

Plans and specifications for the proposed improvements at the new location, including landscape treatment of
front, side and rear yards.

B.

4.

Definition of the route of travel for the house to be moved.

5.

Photographs to be furnished by the applicant:
(a)

All elevations of the structure proposed to be moved.

(b)

The site onto which the building is proposed to be moved.

(c)

The buildings adjacent to the proposed site.

Before the planning commission may approve the application for a conditional use permit for moving of building or
structure, there shall be a finding that said moving shall have no detrimental effect on the living environment and
property values in the area into which the structure is to be moved. Conditions shall be set forth as are deemed
necessary and reasonable to protect the best interests of the surrounding property or neighborhood and the master
plan for the intent thereof.

C.

A licensed contractor shall apply for and be responsible for any and all applications for moving of buildings and all
phases of each project.

D.

Plot plans, landscaping plans and irrigation plans shall be submitted for signatures per Public Works Department
requirements prior to issuance of building permits.

E.

CASH BONDS
(1)

Before a building permit may be granted there shall be the posting of a cash bond as determined by the supervising
building official and city engineer to cover costs of the activities involving the city and the expenditures involved in
complying with conditions related to improvements of the property which may have been established in the
297/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

granting of the permit.
(2)

The bond shall also cover the costs involved in cleaning up the vacated site and restoring it to a safe and sightly
condition if said site is within the city.

(3)

The bond shall also insure the completion of the project within a reasonable, specified time limit, which is to be
established by the planning commission at the public hearing.

F.

BASIS FOR FINDINGS

In approving an application for a conditional use permit to move a building into an area, the planning commission shall find:
(1)

That the building is in conformity with the type and quality of buildings existing in the area into which it is proposed
to be moved.

(2)

That said building is not more than two stories in height.

(3)

That its location on the lot does not in any way adversely affect buildings or uses on abutting properties.

(4)

That the percentage of lot coverage by all buildings and structures be not greater than that permitted by the district
into which the house is proposed to be moved.

(5)

That all yard and setback provisions be observed.

(6)

Prior to occupancy the building shall be brought up to standards of a new building, and shall be painted and
refurbished.

(7)

That all dedications and improvements required for streets and alleys necessary for access to the property upon
which the house is to be located be provided in conformity with the standards of the city.

G.

APPEAL

The decision of the planning commission may be appealed to the city council as set forth in Section .580-C.
H.

FILING FEE AND PROPERTY OWNERS LIST

The filing fee and list of owners required to be notified for a conditional use permit for moving a building shall be as required in
Section .580-B.
(Ord. No. 1821, § 6; Ord. No. 2641, § 1; Ord. No. 3070, § 33.)

Sec. .600 - Exterior property maintenance.
All buildings and the land upon which said buildings are located and all vacant land in the city which is maintained in a condition which is
detrimental to the property of others, or which is maintained so as to result in an unsightly, hazardous or inappropriate condition, or which
reduces the value of neighboring properties, are public nuisances and a violation of the comprehensive zoning ordinance. No person who
owns, maintains or possesses a building or land shall permit or allow such nuisance condition to exist on his building or land. A violation of
any provisions of Section .600 shall be an infraction or misdemeanor pursuant to Section .670.
Such conditions include but are not limited to keeping or depositing on, scattering over, or allowing to exist on the premises, any of the
following: (Ord. No. 4118, § 20.)
A.

Residential Buildings and Premises.
1.

Lumber, junk, trash, debris or salvaged materials visible at ground level from a public street, alley or adjoining
property;

2.

Weeds or dead, diseased, damaged or overgrown vegetation of any type including trees, shrubs, hedges, grass and
ground covers;

3.

Trash, garbage or refuse cans, bins, boxes or other such containers stored for more than twenty-four (24) hours on
the public right-of-way or within the required front yard or side yard abutting the street;

(Ord. No. 3959, § 5.)

4.

Abandoned, discarded or unused furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, sinks, toilets, cabinets, or other
household fixtures or equipment stored so as to be visible at ground level from a public street or alley, or from
adjoining property;
298/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

5.

Construction equipment or machinery of any type or description, parked or stored on residential premises when it
is readily visible to the general public, except while excavation, construction or demolition operations covered by an
active building permit are in progress on the subject premises or on adjoining property;

6.

Other conditions related to buildings, structures, or landscaping which are in need of correction, repair or adequate
and proper maintenance, including but not limited to the existence of broken windows, surfaces in need of
repainting, physical damage or general dilapidation, and graffiti; (Ord. No. 4118, § 20.)

(Ord. No. 3651, § 11.)

9.

Residential premises which are abandoned and unoccupied for thirty days or more must be secured from
vandalism and dumping by fencing the perimeter of the lot, where it is not already fenced, with a six-foot-high fence
of chain link or similar wire mesh fencing material, or wrought iron or tubular steel fencing . For regulations
pertaining to the design and construction of chain link and wire mesh fences around abandoned and unoccupied
residential premises, see Sec. .503-I 4(e). (Ord. No. 3651, § 12; Ord. No. 4118, § 20.)

Fences and walls partially or wholly constructed of, or assembled from, junk material, debris, tarps or other types of
fabric (except for mesh fabric specifically designed as windscreens to be used for tennis courts), rolled plaster,
sheet metal, plywood, or other waste materials (unless such waste materials have been reprocessed into building
materials marketed to the general public as fencing and/or wall materials and resembling new building materials).
For additional regulations pertaining to walls and fences, see Sec. .503-I of the Zoning Ordinance. (Ord. No. 4118, §
20.)

B.

Occupied Nonresidential Buildings or Premises.
1.

Discarded lumber, junk, trash, construction debris, salvaged materials or waste materials of any description located
anywhere on the premises, except in approved trash-storage or pick-up areas, or in junkyards as allowed under this
section or Section .6001;

2.

Damaged, dilapidated, inadequately or improperly maintained buildings or structures, or buildings or structures left
in a state of partial completion and not covered by an active building permit;

3.

Damaged, dilapidated, or inadequately or improperly maintained signs or other identification or advertising devices
or signs related to uses no longer conducted at the site;

4.

Neglected or improperly maintained landscaping: This shall include weed infested, dead or overgrown vegetation,
or vegetation dying as a result of physical damage, disease, insect infestation or lack of water, and any required
landscaping removed without city approval;

5.

Trash, garbage or refuse cans, bins, boxes or other such containers stored for more than twenty-four hours on the
public right-of-way or within the required front yard or required side yard abutting a street;

6.

Business activities, including sales, storage of merchandise or materials, and manufacturing not conducted entirely
within a totally enclosed building, except as specifically permitted by other provisions of this section or Section
.6001.

7.

Other conditions related to buildings, structures, walls, fences or landscaping which are in need of correction, repair
or adequate and proper maintenance, including but not limited to the existence of broken windows, surfaces in
need of repainting, physical damage or general dilapidation, and graffiti.

C.

Vacant Nonresidential Buildings or Premises.
1.

Property maintenance requirements for vacant commercial, industrial or professional buildings or premises shall
be the same as for occupied buildings, where applicable, along with additional requirements applicable to vacant
buildings or premises only;

2.

Damaged, dilapidated, or inadequately or improperly maintained signs or other identification or advertising devices
or signs related to uses no longer conducted at the site.

a.

That rental, sale or lease signs not exceeding one-half square foot for each linear foot of building fronting the stre
the building.

Sec. .6001. - Abatement of nuisance by administrative action, alternative to criminal action.
An owner of real property, or a bona fide agent thereof, who has received an order from the city to correct any condition existing on the
subject property pursuant to a violation of Section .600 may request within fifteen days after such order has been sent by first-class mail. or
delivered by personal service, a hearing before a hearing officer appointed by the city administrator. The order of the city to correct a
violation of Section .600, shall inform the property owner of his hearing rights as set forth hereinabove and shall state that the failure for a
property owner to exercise his hearing rights shall be deemed a waiver thereof.
A.

Request for Hearing and Hearing Officer Action.
1.

Upon receipt of a written request to appeal an order to correct any condition existing on real property pursuant to
the provisions of Section .600, which request shall include a statement of the alleged misinterpretation or incorrect
application of the ordinance, the hearing officer shall fix a time and place of public hearing thereon, not less than
fifteen days nor more than forty days thereafter.

2.

The hearing officer shall hold one hearing upon the matters referred to in the application for appeal, and thereupon
within fifteen days of such hearing shall render his decision. The decision shall determine the validity of the order to
correct the conditions in question and shall determine whether the city staff has interpreted the ordinance correctly
and applied the law fairly and equitably in the handling of this case. In the event that the order to correct is upheld,
upon the finding that the conditions of property set forth in Section .600 exist, the hearing officer shall conclude
that the condition on the property is a nuisance.

3.

The decision shall be filed with the city administrator within twenty days, and a copy thereof shall be mailed to the
applicant by the hearing officer at the address shown on the application for appeal. The decision of the hearing
officer shall be final forthwith.
300/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

4.

In the event the hearing officer does not sustain the objection of the property owner or the property owner does
not object to the order to correct within the time prescribed above, the city shall abate the nuisance. The city shall
keep an itemized account of the expense involved in such abatement. This itemized statement shall be submitted to
the city clerk who shall send, by first-class mail, a copy of the statement to the person owning the land along with
the notice of the time and place when and where the statement shall be submitted to the city council for approval
and confirmation. At said time, the city council shall consider any objections or protests, if any, which may be raised
by the property owner liable to be assessed for the cost of such work, after which, by resolution, the report as
submitted, or as ordered revised, corrected or modified by the city council shall be confirmed. If the statement is
not paid within fifteen days after the passing of the resolution, it shall constitute a lien on the real property upon
which the nuisance exists, and shall be collected as a special assessment against the real property. The resolution
shall further direct that the city clerk shall file with the auditor of Los Angeles County, and the county assessor and
tax collector, certified copies of the resolution and the statement adopted therein. The clerk shall direct the auditor
to enter the amount of the charges against the real property described in the statement and resolution as it
appears on the current assessment roll. The tax collector shall include the amount of the charges on the bills for
taxes levied against the real property. Thereafter, the amount of the charge shall be collected at the same time and
in the same manner and by the same person as, together with and not separately from, the general taxes for the
city and shall be subject to the same penalties and interest upon delinquent payment.

(Ord. No. 2773, § 1 (part): Ord. No. 3386, § 4.)

Sec. .610. - Compliance.
All departments, officials, or public employees, vested with the duty or authority to issue permits, licenses or certificates of occupancy,
where required by law, shall conform to provisions of this ordinance. No such permit, license or certificate for buildings, uses, or purposes
where the same would be in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance shall be issued. Any such permit, license or certificate, if issued in
conflict with the provisions hereof, shall be null and void.
Sec. .640. - Enforcement.
A.

PLANNING COMMISSION

The planning commission shall administer the regulations as provided for in this ordinance and amendments thereto: the planning
commission shall hear and recommend to the council matters involving changes of zones, suspensions and modification of setback
ordinances, and decide matters involving variances, conditional use permits, public use permits, determinations of similarity, and
perform such other duties as are requested by the council by resolution.
(Ord. No. 1821, § 7: Ord. No. 3223, § 1 (part).)

B.

SUPERVISING BUILDING OFFICIAL

It shall be the duty of the supervising building official to enforce the provisions of this ordinance pertaining to the erecting,
construction, reconstruction, moving, conversion, alteration of, or addition to, any building: and to enforce the requirements of
occupancy in any dwelling, apartment house, or other building not otherwise regulated by the license officer as herein stated.
Sec. .650. - Form of applications, petitions and appeals.
The commission shall, in its rules of procedure, prescribe the form and scope of all petitions and applications provided for in this
ordinance, and of the accompanying data to be furnished, so as to assure the fullest practicable presentation of facts for proper
consideration of the matter involved in each case and for a permanent record thereof. Any petition as provided for in this ordinance shall
include a verification by at least one (1) of the petitioners, attested to before a notary public or before the city clerk.
Sec. .660. - Legal procedure.

301/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Any building or structure set up, erected, constructed, altered, enlarged, converted, moved or maintained contrary to the provisions of
this ordinance, and any use of land, building or premises established, conducted or operated or maintained contrary to the provisions of this
ordinance, shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance; and the city attorney of the city upon order of the
council, shall immediately commence action or proceedings for the abatement and removal and the enjoining thereof in the manner
prescribed by law, and shall take such other steps and shall apply to such courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate
and remove the structure or building, and enjoin any person, firm or corporation from setting up, erecting, building, maintaining or use of
any such building or structure or using property contrary to the provisions of this ordinance. The remedies provided herein shall be
cumulative and not exclusive.
Sec. .670. - Penalties for violation.
Any person violating or causing the violation of any of the provisions of the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor or an infraction at the discretion of the city attorney or the district attorney of Los Angeles County. Any such violation, if a
misdemeanor, shall upon conviction be punishable by a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment for a term of not
exceeding six months or by both such fine and imprisonment: and if an infraction, shall upon conviction be punishable by a fine of not
exceeding two hundred fifty dollars. Such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of
which the violation of this code is committed by such person and shall he punishable as herein provided.
(Ord. No. 3188, § 1: Ord. No. 3386, § 3.)

Sec. .680. - Validity.
If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such
decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. The council of the city hereby declares that it would have
passed and does hereby pass this ordinance and each section, sentence, clause and phrase hereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or
more sections, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared invalid, or unconstitutional.
Sec. .690. - Amendment and repeal.
All other ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
Sec. .700. - E ective date.
This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage as provided by law.
Sec. .710. - Certi cation of passage, etc.

PART IV. - APARTMENT OWNERSHIP.
Sec. .800. - Apartment ownership part.
This part shall be known as the "Apartment Ownership Part."
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .801. - De nitions.
As used in this part, unless the context otherwise requires:
(a)

"Apartment" means a part of the property intended for any type of independent use, including one or more rooms or
enclosed spaces or open balconies or patios located on one or more floors (or part or parts thereof) in a building, and
with a direct exit to a public street or highway or to a common area leading to such street or highway.

(b)

"Apartment owner" means the person or persons owning an apartment in fee simple absolute and an undivided interest
in the fee simple estate of the common areas and facilities in the percentage specified and established in the declaration.

(c)

"Apartment number" means the number, letter, or combination thereof, designating the apartment in the Declaration.

(d)

"Association of apartment owners" means all of the apartment owners acting as a group in accordance with the by-laws
and declaration.

(e)

"Building" means a building, containing four or more apartments, or two or more buildings, each containing two or more
apartments, with a total of four or more apartments for all such buildings, and comprising a part of the property.

(f)

"Common areas and facilities," unless otherwise provided in the declaration or lawful amendments thereto, means and
includes:
(1)

The land on which the building is located.

(2)

The foundations, columns, girders, beams, supports, main walls, roofs, halls, corridors, lobbies, stairs, stairways, fire
escapes, and entrances and exits of the building;

(3)

The basements, yards, gardens, parking areas and storage spaces;

(4)

The premises for the lodging of janitors or persons in charge of the property;

(5)

Installations of central services such as power, light, gas, hot and cold water, heating, refrigeration, air conditioning
and incinerating;

(6)

for use in connection therewith, which have been or are intended to be submitted to the provisions of this part.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .802. - Application of this part.
This part shall be applicable only to property, the sole owner or all of the owners of which submit the same to the provisions hereof by
duly executing and recording a declaration as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .803. - Status of the apartments.
Each apartment, together with its undivided interest in the coinmon areas and facilities, shall for all purposes in applying this part be
considered as real property.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .804. - Ownership of apartments.
Each apartment owner shall be entitled to the exclusive ownership and possession of his apartment for this part to apply.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .805. - Common areas and facilities.
The declaration shall provide for the following among other matters:
(a)

Each apartment owner shall be entitled to an undivided interest in the common areas and facilities in the percentage
expressed in the declaration.

(b)

The percentage of the undivided interest of each apartment owner in the common areas and facilities as expressed in
the declaration shall have a permanent character and shall not be altered without the consent of all of the apartment
owners and approved by the City of Pomona expressed in an amended declaration duly recorded. The percentage of the
undivided interest in the common areas and facilities shall not be separated from the apartment to which it appertains
and shall be deemed to be conveyed or encumbered with the apartment even though such interest is not expressly
mentioned or described in the conveyance or other instrument.
304/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

(c)

The common areas and facilities shall remain undivided and no apartment owner or any other person shall bring any action
division of any part thereof. Any covenant to the contrary shall not be approved.

(d)

Each apartment owner may use the common areas and facilities in accordance with the purpose for which they were
intended without hindering or encroaching upon the lawful rights of the other apartment owners.

(e)

The necessary work of maintenance, repair and replacement of the common areas and facilities and the making of any
additions or improvements thereto shall be carried out only as provided herein and in the by-laws or declaration.

(f)

The association of apartment owners shall have the irrevocable right, to be exercised by the manager or board of
directors, to have access to each apartment from time to time during reasonable hours as may be necessary for the
maintenance, repair or replacement of any of the common areas and facilities therein or accessible therefrom, or for
making emergency repairs therein necessary to prevent damage to the common areas and facilities or to another
apartment or apartments.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .806. - Compliance with covenants, by-laws and administrative provisions.
The declaration shall provide that each apartment owner shall comply strictly with the by-laws and with the administrative rule and
regulations adopted pursuant thereto, as either of the same may be lawfully amended from time to time, and with the covenants, conditions
and restrictions set forth in the declaration or in the deed to his apartment. Failure to comply with any of the same shall be ground for an
action to recover sums due, for damages or injunctive relief or both maintainable by the manager or board of directors on behalf of the
association of apartment owners, or, in a proper case, by an aggrieved apartment owner.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .807. - Certain work prohibited.
The declaration shall provide that no apartment owner shall do any work which would jeopardize the soundness or safety of the
property, reduce the value thereof, or impair any easement or hereditament without in every such case the consent of the association of
apartment owners being first obtained.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .808. - Common pro ts and expenses.
The declaration shall provide that the common profits of the property shall be distributed among, and the common expenses shall be
charged to, the apartment owners according to the percentage of the undivided interest in the common areas and facilities.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .809. - Contents of declaration.
The declaration shall contain the following particulars:
1.

Description of the land on which the building and improvements are or are to be located.

2 Description of the building, stating the number of stories and basements, the number of apartments and the principal materials of
which it is or is to be constructed.
3.

The apartment number of each apartment, and a statement of its location, and immediate common area to which it has
access, and any other data necessary for its proper identification.

4.

Description of the common areas.

5.

Description of the limited common areas and facilities, if any, stating to which apartments their use is reserved.

6.

The percentage of undivided interest held by each apartment in the common areas and facilities appertaining to each
apartment and its owner for all purposes, including voting.

7.

Statement of the purposes for which the building amid each of the apartments are intended and restricted as to use.
305/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

8.

The name of a person to receive service of process together with the residence or place of business of such person which sh
City of Pomona until the association of apartment owners designates a person to receive service of process which name and
the City of Pomona shall be filed from time to time with the city clerk of the City of Pomona within 30 days of the designatio

9.

Provision as to the percentage of votes by the apartment owners which shall be determinative of whether to rebuild,
repair, restore, or sell the property in the event of damage or destruction of all or part of the property.

10.

Any further details in connection with the property which the person executing the declaration may deem desirable to
set forth consistent with the part.

11.

The method by which the declaration may be amended, consistent with the provisions of this part.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .810. - Contents of deeds of apartments.
Deeds of apartments shall include the following particulars:
1.

Description of the subdivision and the portion thereof being conveyed, including the liber, page and date of recording of
the declaration.

2.

The apartment number of the apartment in the declaration and any other data necessary for its proper identification.

3.

The percentage of undivided interest appertaining to the apartment in the common areas and facilities.

4.

Any further details which the grantor and grantee may deem desirable to set forth consistent with the declaration and
this part.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .811. - Copy of the oor plans to be led.
Simultaneously with the recording of the subdivision map, the declaration shall be recorded and there shall be filed in the office of the
building department of the City of Pomona a set of the floor plans of the building showing the layout, location, apartment numbers and
dimensions of the apartments as they affect the common area stating the name of the building or that it has no name, and bearing the
verified statement of a registered architect or licensed professional engineer certifying that it is an accurate copy of portions of the plans of
the building as filed with and approved by the council of the City of Pomona. If such plans do not include a verified statement by such
architect or engineer that such plans fully and accurately depict the layout, location, apartment numbers and dimensions of the apartments
as built, there shall be recorded prior to the first conveyance of any apartment an amendment to the declaration to which shall be attached a
verified statement of a registered architect or licensed professional engineer certifying that the plans theretofore filed, or being filed
simultaneously with such amendment, fully and accurately depict the layout, location, apartment numbers and dimensions of the
apartments as built. Such plans shall be kept by the building department in a separate file for each building, indexed in the same manner as
a conveyance entitled to record, numbered serially in the order of receipt, each designated "apartment ownership," with the name of the
building, if any, and each containing a reference to the liber page and date of recording of the subdivision map and the declaration.
Correspondingly, the record of the declaration shall contain a reference to the file number of the floor plans of the building affected thereby.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .812. - Recording.
(a)

The declaration, any amendment or amendments thereof, any instrument by which the provisions of this part may be waived,
and every instrument affecting the property or any apartmnent shall be executed properly to be recorded. The declaration
and any amendment thereof shall be duly recorded.

(Ord, No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .813. - By-laws.
The administration of every property shall be governed by by-laws, a true copy of which shall be filed with the City of Pomona before
recording.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Sec. .814. - Contents of by-laws.
The by-laws may provide for the following:
(a)

The election from among the apartment owners of a board of directors, the number of persons constituting the same,
and that the terms of at least one-third of the directors shall expire annually; the powers and duties of the board; the
compensation, if any, of the directors; the method of removal from office of directors; and whether or not the board may
engage the services of a manager or managing agent.

(b)

Method of calling meetings of the apartment owners; what percentage, if other than a majority of apartment owners
shall constitute a quorum.

(c)

Election of a president from among the board of directors who shall preside over the meetings of the board of directors
and of the association of apartment owners.

(d)

Election of a secretary who shall keep the minute book wherein resolution shall be recorded.

(e)

Election of a treasurer who shall keep the financial records and books of account.

(f)

Maintenance, repair and replacement of the common areas and facilities and payments thereof, including the method of
approving payment vouchers.

(g)

Manner of collecting from the apartment owners their share of the common expenses.

(h)

Designation and removal of personnel necessary for the maintenance, repair and replacement of the common areas and
facilities.

(i)

Method of adopting and of amending administrative rules and regulations governing the details of the operation and use
of the common areas and facilities.

(j)

Such restrictions on and requirements respecting the use and maintenance of the apartments and the use of the
common areas and facilities, not set forth in the declaration, as are designed to prevent unreasonable interference with
the use of their respective apartments and of the common areas and facilities by the several apartment owners.

(k)

The percentage of votes required to amend the by-laws.

(l)

Other provisions as may be deemed necessary for the administration of the property consistent with this part.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .815. - Books of receipts and expenditures; availability for examination.
The declaration shall provide that the manager or board of directors, as the case may be, shall keep detailed, accurate records in
chronological order, of the receipts and expenditures affecting the common areas and facilities, specifying and itemizing the maintenance
and repair expenses of the common areas and facilities and any other expenses incurred. Such records and the vouchers authorizing the
payments shall be available for examination by the apartment owners at convenient hours of week days.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .816. - Separate taxation.
Insofar as the State of California law shall provide each apartment and its percentage of undivided interest in the common areas and
facilities shall be deemed to be a parcel and shall be subject to separate assessment and taxation by each assessment unit and special
district for all types of taxes authorized by law including but not limited to special ad valorem levies and special assessments.
(Ord. No. 1886, § 3.)

Sec. .817. - Priority of lien.
The declaration shall provide all sums assessed by the association of apartment owners but unpaid for the share of the common
expenses chargeable to any apartment shall constitute a lien on such apartment. Such lien may be foreclosed by suit by the manager or
board of directors, acting on behalf of the apartment owners, in like manner as a mortgage of real property. In any such foreclosure the
apartment owner shall be required to pay a reasonable rental for the apartment, if so provided in the by-laws, and the plaintiff in such
307/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

foreclosure shall be entitled to the appointment of a receiver to collect the same. The manager or board of directors, acting on behalf of the
apartment owners, shall have power, unless prohibited by the declaration to bid in the apartment at foreclosure sale, and to acquire and
hold, lease, mortgage and convey the same. Suit to recover a money judgment for unpaid common expenses shall be maintainable without
foreclosing or waiving the lien securing the same.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .818. - Joint and several liability of grantor and grantee for unpaid common expenses.
The declaration shall provide that in a voluntary conveyance the grantee of an apartment shall be jointly and severally liable with the
grantor for all unpaid assessments against the latter for his share of the common expenses up to the time of the grant or conveyance,
without prejudice to the grantee's right to recover from the grantor the amounts paid by the grantee therefor. However, any such grantee
shall be entitled to a statement from the manager or board of directors, as the case may be, setting forth the amount of the unpaid
assessments against the grantor and such grantee shall not be liable for, nor shall the apartment conveyed by subject to a lien for, any
unpaid assessments against the grantor in excess of the amount therein set forth.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .819. - Disposition of property; destruction or damage.
The declaration shall provide that if, within 360 days or less as determined by the association of apartment owners of the date of the
damage or destruction to all or part of the property, it is not determined by the association of apartment owners to repair, re-construct or
rebuild, them and in that event:
(a)

The property shall be deemed to be owned in common by the apartment owners;

(b)

The undivided interest in the property owned in common which shall appertain to each apartment owner shall be the
percentage of undivided interest previously owned by such owner in the common areas and facilities;

(c)

Any liens affecting any of the apartments shall be deemed to be transferred in accordance with the existing priorities to
the percentage of the undivided interest of the apartment owner in the property as provided herein; and

(d)

The property shall he subject to an action for partition at the suit of any apartment owner, in which event the net
proceeds of sale, together with the net proceeds of the insurance on the property if any, shall be considered as one fund
and shall be divided among all the apartment owners in a percentage equal to the percentage of undivided interest
owned by each owner in the property, after first paying out of the respective shares of the apartment owners, to the
extent sufficient for the purpose, all liens on the undivided interest in the property owned by each apartment owner.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .820. - Personal application.
The declaration shall provide:
(a)

All apartment owners, tenants of such owners, employees of owners and tenants, or any other persons that may in any
manner use property or any part thereof submitted to the provisions of this part shall be subject to this part and to the
declaration and by-laws of the association of apartment owners adopted pursuant to the provisions of this part.

(b)

All agreements, decisions and determinations lawfully made by the association of apartment owners in accordance with
the voting percentages established in the declaration or by-laws, shall be deemed to be binding on all apartment owners.

(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

Sec. .821. - Severability.
If any provision of this part or any section, sentence, clause, phrase or word, or the application thereof in any circumstance is held
invalid, the validity of the remainder of the part and of the application of any such provision, section, sentence, clause, phrase or word in any
other circumstances shall not be affected thereby.
(Ord. No. 1866, § 3.)

APPENDIX II - MASTER PLAN OF PRINCIPAL STREETS AND HIGHWAYS, ORDINANCE NO. 1199, CITY OF POMONA
Sec. 1. - Purposes.
The aforesaid Principal Street and Highway Plan is adopted to protect and promote the public health, safety, convenience and general
welfare and for the accomplishment thereof is adopted for the purposes more particularly set forth as follows:
(1)

To assist in providing a definite plan of development for the City of Pomona, and to guide, control and regulate the future
growth of said city in accordance with the Master Plan.

(2)

To provide a guide for the intelligent use of the capital expenditures of said city for street and highway improvements.

(3)

To provide an authentic source of information as to the development of the city for present and prospective residents
and investors therein.

(4)

To provide a pattern for such future subdivision of land as may take place in said city.

(5)

To obviate the menace to the public safety resulting from inadequate provisions of traffic thoroughfares in connection
with and as a result of the development of the city.

(6)

To prevent deterioration of property values and the impairment of conditions making for desirable residential,
commercial or industrial development, as the case may be, which would result from a lack of plans designed to assure
the orderly, harmonious and beneficial development of the city.

(7)

To provide for precise lines for boundaries of streets which are either existing or planned along which building set-backs
for structures are to be determined, and which shall be used for determining dedications for public rights of way. (Ord.
No. 2089, § 1.)

Sec. 2. - De nitions.
For the purpose of this ordinance certain words and terms are defined as follows: Words used in the present tense include the future ;
words in the singular number include the plural; and words in the plural number include the singular; the word "shall" is mandatory.

Buildings. Any structure built for the purpose, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or property of any kind.
City. The City of Pomona, County of Los Angeles, State of California.
Council. The City Council of the City of Pomona.
Official plan of principal streets and highways. An official map of the City of Pomona indicating the present and future alignment of
principal streets and highways within the limits of said city and their proposed relocation, widening and extension.

Book of official plan lines. A book of maps of planned streets in die City of Pomona showing precise plan measurements of said streets
kept in the office of the city engineer and which have been adopted pursuant to this ordinance as additions to section 8 hereof.

Planning commission. The city planning commission of the City of Pomona.
Precise plan measurements. The exact plans and measurements as set forth in the engineering department showing the official precise
center-lines and other measurements of existing and proposed streets as shown on the official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways.

Street. A dedicated public thoroughfare which affords principal means of access to abutting property.
Precise alignment. Precise engineered lines showing the boundaries of an existing or proposed street as shown on the Official Plan of
Principal Streets and Highways, and reduced to precise plan measurements or official plan lines in the Book of Official Plan Lines.

Non-precise alignment. Proposed location of streets which have not had their boundaries specifically engineered to precise alignments
but which are shown as a part of the circulation element of the Master Plan of the City of Pomona for information only.

Freeways. A divided highway for through traffic with full control of accesses leaving no intersecting streets at grade level as indicated on
the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways having varying widths.

309/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Arterial. A street indicated by legend as an arterial on the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways having a designated right of way
width of 100 feet.

Collector. A street indicated by legend as a collector on the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways having a designated width of
SO feet.

Minor collector. A street indicated by legend as a minor collector on the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways having a
designated right of way of 60 feet used primarily for direct access to residences, commercial, industrial or other abutting property carrying
through traffic to arterial and collector streets.

Structure. Anything constructed or erected which requires location on the ground or attached to something having a location on ground,
but not including fences or walls used as fence less than 6 feet in height.

Structure, non-permanent. Any structure so designed and built as to be of a temporary status or construction.
(Ord. no. 2089, § 2.)

Sec. 3. - O cial plan of principal streets and highways.
There is hereby adopted an Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways as part of the Precise Plan of Traffic Circulation of the City of
Pomona. Said Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways was originally enacted by a map designated as an exhibit to the enacting
ordinance. However, because of numerous amendments of this ordinance, it has become necessary to redraw this map to include in one
map all the amendments and changes and to further add to said map further new precise alignments and non-precise alignments, and
establish minimum widths for rights of way. Said new map, therefore, is hereby enacted and adopted and made a part of this ordinance
marked Exhibit "A-l" 1 and is officially designated as "Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways", and is attached hereto and by reference
made a part hereof. Such map is also on file in the offices of the city clerk, city engineer and planning director of the City of Pomona. The
former map insofar as it is consistent with the new map is reenacted, hut any portions of the former map inconsistent with the new map is
hereby repealed. This new map designated as the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways shall serve as a basic guide map for future
development of streets and highways in the City of Pomona. For the accomplishment of the purposes of this ordinance, precise plan
measurements of planned streets as shown on the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways are on file in the office of the city engineer
of the City of Pomona. Such precise? plan measurements shall govern the specific precise alignments as indicated existing by the Official Plan
of Principal Streets and Highways.
Editor's note—
1. Editor's Note.—The map here referred to is not carried in this Appendix, but a copy thereof if filed in the office of the city clerk.
(Ord. No. 20S9, ;S; 3.)

Sec. 4. - Book of o cial plan lines generally,
For the further accomplishment of the purposes of this ordinance, precise alignment of planned streets are also set forth in the office of
the city engineer, known as the Book of Official Plan Lines, These Official Plan Lines are precise alignments of streets within the City of
Pomona which may or may not he in existence or which may or may not be actually shown as part of the Official Plan of Principal Streets and
Highways Map. However, for the purposes of this ordinance all regulations having to do with building setbacks from precise alignments and
for dedication of street rights of way-shall apply equally to streets shown in the Book of Official Plan Lines and the Official Plan of Principal
Streets and Highways.
The council hereby declares it has from time to time amended this ordinance, and intends in the future from time to time to amend this
ordinance, and such amendments to the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways, and to the Book of Official Plan Lines and shall
become continuations of section 8 of this ordinance.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 4.)

Sec. 5. - Subdivision of land.

310/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

The streets and highways layout of any subdivision of land falling under the provisions of chapter 29 of Ordinance No, 1673 of the City of
Pomona as amended shall be in accordance with the aforesaid Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways and Official Plan Lines as
adopted by this ordinance and amendments thereto. Subdivisions shall be deemed to include any division of land into two or more lots. The
approval of such divisions shall not be given until, and unless, the necessary dedication for street rights of way have been given to the City of
Pomona as shown by precise alignments, precise plan measurements, Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways, and/or Book of Official
Plan Lines.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 5.)

Sec. 6. - Land within street alignment.
The making or adoption of said Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways, or any other provision of this ordinance, shall not in and
of itself constitute or be deemed to constitute the opening or establishment of any street or the taking or acceptance of any land for street
purposes. Nor shall anything in this ordinance be deemed a condition precedent to the acquisition of rights of way by purchase or by
proceedings in eminent domain.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 6.)

Sec. 7. - Building within street alignment.
No building, structure or expansion or enlargement thereof, or addition thereto, shall be erected or placed in the boundaries of any
planned street as shown on the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways, or any precise alignment thereof, or precise measurements
thereof, or of any precise alignments established by enactment of additions to the Book of Official Plan Lines as provided for in this
ordinance. This provision shall not apply to garden and agricultural crop, planting, and non-permanent structures as in the opinion of the
planning commission will not defeat the purpose of this ordinance.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 7.)

Sec. 7.1. - O cial plan lines reducing size of lot to less than minimum area to build a structure—Removal of restrictions thirty days after building
permit is sought if land not purchased by the city.
The restrictions imposed by Section 7 of this ordinance shall not apply to any land which has been reduced in size for building purposes
by the adoption of an official plan line as described in Section 8 of this ordinance to less than the minimum size lot permitted in the zoning
district permitted by the uniform zoning ordinance in which such land is located after thirty days after a building permit for such land has
been applied for unless the city has purchased such land.
(Ord. No. 2321, § 1.)

Sec. 7.5. - Precise plans and regulations—Preparation by commission.
From time to time, the planning commission may, or if so directed by the city council, shall prepare or cause to be prepared plans based
on the master plan and drafts of such regulations, programs and legislation as may in its judgment be required to insure the systematic
execution of the master plan and the planning commission may recommend such plans and measures to the city council for adoption.
The precise plans and regulations may include:
(a)

Proposed regulations limiting the use of land and buildings, the height and bulk of buildings, and the open spaces about
buildings.

(b)

Proposed regulations limiting the locations of buildings and other improvements with respect to existing or planned
rights-of-way.

(c)

Such other matters that will accomplish the purpose of this chapter including procedure for the administration of such
regulations. A precise plan may include street and highway naming and numbering plans, in order to establish the official
names of streets and highways, and to remove conflicts, duplications and uncertainty among such names and to provide
an orderly system for the numbering of buildings and properties.

(Ord. No. 1579, § 15; Ord. No. 3449, § 2 (part).)

311/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

Sec. 7.6. - Same—Procedure for adoption.
(a)

Hearing by planning commission. Before recommending a precise plan or regulation to the city council or any amendment to
it, for adoption, the planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing, after giving notice of the time and place of the
hearing at least ten days before the hearing by at least one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and by
such other means as the planning commission may deem necessary.

(b)

Recommendation by the planning commission. The recommendation of any precise plan or regulation or any amendment to it
shall be made to the city council by resolution of the planning commission carried by the majority vote of the planning
commission members present at that planning commission meeting.

A copy of any precise plan, regulation or amendment recommended pursuant to this section shall be submitted to the city council
and shall be accompanied by a report of findings, summaries of hearings and recommendations of the planning commission.
(c)

Hearing by city council. Before adopting the proposed precise plan or regulation the city council shall hold at least one public
hearing, after giving notice of the time and place of the hearing at least ten days before the hearing by at least one publication
in a newspaper of general circulation in the city.

(d)

Adoption by the city council. The plan or regulation, as adopted shall be designated as a precise plan or regulation.

(e)

Proposed change prior to adoption of precise plan. In adopting a precise plan or regulation, the city council shall make no
change in any proposed precise plan, regulation, or amendment thereto recommended by the planning commission, until the
proposed change has been referred back to the planning commission for a report and a copy of the report has been filed with
the city council.

(Ord. No. 1579, § 16; Ord. No. 2066, § 1; Ord. No. 3449, § 2 (part).)

Sec. 7.7. - Same—Procedure for council to initiate, adopt or change.
When the city council deems it to be in the public interest, the city council may initiate, adopt or change an ordinance or resolution
establishing any precise plans or regulations specified in section 20-18 of this Code, in the following manner:
(a)

Refer to the planning commission for report. The city council shall first refer such proposal to establish or change such
precise plan or regulation to the planning commission for a report. Before making a report the planning commission
shall hold at least one public hearing in the same manner as heretofore prescribed in the preceding section.

(b)

Failure to report deemed approval. The failure of the planning commission to report within forty days after the reference
or such period as may be designated by the city council, shall be deemed to be approval of the proposed adoption of the
change, ordinance or resolution.

Nothing in this chapter applies to the adoption or amending of any ordinance by the city council, whether or not it may relate to the
subjects mentioned in section 20-18 of this Code, except ordinances expressly adopting or amending a precise plan initiated pursuant to this
section. (Ord. No. 1579, § 17; Ord. No. 3449, § 2 (part).)
Sec. 7.8. - Same—Administration.
(A)

Administrative rules and procedures to enforce. The city council may determine and establish such administrative rules and
procedures as may be required for the application and enforcement of precise plans and regulations, and may assign or
delegate such administrative functions, powers and duties to the planning department provided for in section 20-14 of this
Code.

(B)

Subdivision map approval by planning commission. The city council may designate the planning commission as the advisory
agency with respect to the approval of subdivision maps.

(C)

Conditions prerequisite to street improvements:
1.

Improvements Prohibited without Report. The city shall not improve any street or authorize sewers or connections or
other improvements to be laid in any street within any territory for which the city council has adopted a precise street or
highway plan until the matter has been referred to the planning commission for a report and a copy of the report has
been filed with the city council unless one of the following conditions applies.
312/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

2.

Exceptions:
(a)

The street has been accepted, opened, or has otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to the
adoption of the plan.

(b)

It corresponds with streets shown on the plan.

(c)

It corresponds with streets, highways and freeways shown on a subdivision map or record of survey approved by
the city council.

(d)

It corresponds with streets, highways and freeways shown on a subdivision map previously approved by the
planning commission.

3.

Failure to Report Deemed Approval Failure of the planning commission to report on the matter within forty days after
the reference or such longer period as may be designated by the city council shall be deemed to be approval of such
matter.

(D)

Streets with same or conflicting names. Whether a master plan or any portion of it have been adopted or not, whenever the
planning commission finds that there are two or more streets within the city having the same name or names so similar as to
confuse the public, the planning commission may make any recommendation it deems appropriate to the city council which
shall thereupon take any action it considers proper. When any street is known by two or more names or when portions of the
same street have names that conflict, the planning commission may recommend to the city council a name for it.

(Ord. No. 1579, § 18; Ord. No. 3449, § 2 (part).)

Sec. 8. - Setback requirements.
Buildings, structures or expansions thereof, shall conform with the established setback regulations of the city as they apply to this
Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways as set forth in this ordinance, and in accordance with precise alignments established by precise
plan measurements and official plan lines contained in the Book of Official Plan Lines. Additions have been made to this ordinance
heretofore by designation of such additions as "official plan lines" of certain named streets. These have begun with Section "8.1." and have
continued thereafter. These additions are hereby reenacted; however, any reference hereafter made in this ordinance to Master Plan of
Principal Streets and Highways of the city means the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways as defined and set forth in Section 3 of
this ordinance, and any reference to "official plan lines" of certain streets shall mean those official plan lines and precise alignments as kept
in a Book of Official Plan Lines in the office of the city engineer as set forth in Section 4 of this ordinance and defined in Section 2 of this
ordinance. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to repeal any official plan lines which have heretofore been enacted prior to
the amendment of this section.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 8.)

Sec. 9. - Building permits.
No building permit shall be issued contrary to the provisions of the ordinance codified in this section.
Sec. 10. - Building permit appeal.
Any person aggrieved by the refusal of a building permit under the provisions of the ordinance codified in this section may file an
application for appeal requesting a hearing on the matter before the planning commission.
Sec. 11. - Appeals for building permits-to be granted.
In the matter of an appeal for a building permit the planning commission and/or the council shall authorize the issuance of such permit if
any of the following are true:
(a)

That the property of which the planned street location is a part is of such nature that the owner of the land will be
substantially damaged by the refusal to grant the permit.

(b)

That the property will not earn a fair return on the owner's investment unless the construction involved is authorized.

(c)

That balancing the interests of the public in preserving the integrity of the official planned street against the interest of
319/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

the owner of the land in using his property, the granting of the permit is required by considerations of justice and equity.
Sec. 12. - Appeals for building permits—Not to be granted.
The planning commission and/or the council shall not authorize the issuance of an appealed building permit if any of the following are
true:
(a)

That the owner of the land will not be substantially damaged by locating the proposed structure on his land outside of
the lines of the planned street.

(b)

That, balancing the interests of the public in preserving the integrity of the planned street against the interest of the
landowner in using his property as proposed to be used, the resulting disadvantages to the city would be unreasonably
disproportionate to the advantages the owner would derive from so using the property.

Sec. 13. - Appeal to planning commission—Procedure,
The planning commission shall cause to be made such investigations of facts bearing upon such application set for hearing, including an
analysis of precedent cases as will serve to provide all necessary information to assure action on each case consistent with the purpose of
this ordinance.
Summary of all pertinent testimony offered at a public hearing and the names of persons so testifying shall be recorded and made a part
of the permanent files of the case.
If, for any reason, testimony on any case set for public hearing cannot be completed on the day set for such hearing, the planning
commission may before the adjournment or recess thereof, publicly announce the time and place to and at which said hearings will be
continued, and such announcement shall serve as sufficient notice of such continuance. This continuance shall not be for more than thirty
(30) days.
Upon the completion of one public hearing the planning commission shall, not later than ten (10) days thereafter, render its decision on
the matter so heard. In the event the planning commission fails to render its decision within said ten ( 10) day period the matter may be
appealed to the city council by any person aggrieved, in the same manner as though the commission had refused a building permit. In the
event of such failure on the part of the planning commission to act, and there is an appeal to the council, the secretary of the planning
commission shall immediately deliver to the city council all the records on the matter involved.
The planning commission shall announce and record its action by formal resolution, and such resolution shall recite the findings of the
planning commission upon which it bases its decision.
Not later than ten (10) days after final action by the planning commission on an application for the granting of the issuance of such
building permits, notice of the decision in the matter shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown upon the application.
The decision of the planning commission in administrative matters of granting or denying issuance of such building permits which do not
alter or seem to alter the alignment of said Principal Street and Highway Plan shall be final, except that :
(a)

Not later than twenty (20) days after the final action by the planning commission on an application an appeal may be
filed, in writing, with the city council ;

(b)

If an appeal from the action of the planning commission is filed with the city council within the time prescribed, the city
council shall set the matter for hearing. The secretary of the planning commission shall also be notified of the filing of
such appeal, and upon the receipt of such notices shall transmit to the city council the complete file in the case;

(c)

Not later than ten (10) days after the final action on such appeal by the city council, notice of the decision in the matter
shall be mailed to the applicant. The decision of the city council on such matters appealed shall be final;

In the case of an application for the granting of the issuance of a building permit which would alter or seem to alter the alignment of said
Principal Street and Highway Plan, the following procedures shall govern:
(a)

Not later than ten (10) days after final action by the planning commission on an application for the granting of the
issuance of a building permit upon which the action of the planning commission can only be advisory, the secretary of
320/322

7/11/2019

Pomona, CA Zoning

the planning commission shall forward to the city council a copy of the resolution setting forth the findings and the
recommendations of the planning commission.
(b)

The council shall within not more than fifteen (15) days following receipt of the resolution and recommendation from the
planning commission, consider the matters therein and render a decision. The action of the council on any such
application shall be final.

Sec. 14. - Speci cations regulating building permits.
In the event that the planning commission and/or the council authorizes a building permit, it/they shall have the power to impose such
reasonable conditions as may be consistent with the purpose and intent of this ordinance.
Sec. 15. - Amendments.
The planning commission, upon its own initiative or upon instigation of the council or a petitioner, may recommend additions or
modification to the Official Plan of Principal Streets and Highways, precise alignments, precise plan measurements, and official plan lines
contained in the Book of Official Plan Lines. Upon receipt of such recommendations from the planning commission, the council may make
these additions or modifications in the form of amendments, to said plan or plans; provided, however, that before taking any such action the
provisions contained in chapter 20 of Ordinance No. 1673 of the City of Pomona, California, also known as the Code of the City of Pomona,
California, having to do with the adoption of precise plans, have been complied with.
(Ord. No. 2089, § 9.)

Sec. 16. - Violations and penalties.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall
be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred ($500.00) dollars, and in case said fine is not paid the said person may be imprisoned in the
city jail until the fine be duly satisfied which must not exceed one (1) day for every two ($2.00) dollars of the fine, or by imprisonment in the
city jail for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment; and each such person as principal agent or
otherwise, shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each day during any portion of which the violation of or failure, neglect or refusal
to comply with any of the provisions of this ordinance is committed, continued, or permitted by such person.
Sec. 17. - Validity.
If any provisions of this ordinance, or the application thereof, to any persons or circumstances is held invalid, the remainder of the
ordinance, and the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances, shall not be affected thereby.
Sec. 18. - E ect of passage.
The passage of this ordinance shall not serve to terminate or validate any violations existing under terms of any other ordinance
amended or repealed thereby, nor shall any permits, variances or other authority extended under any previous or existing ordinance be
terminated or nullified hereby.
Sec. 19. - Certi cation.
That the city clerk shall certify to the adoption of this ordinance, and shall cause this ordinance to be published in a newspaper of general
circulation published in the City of Pomona.
Sec. 20. - E ective date.
This ordinance shall take effect thirty (30) days from the time of final passage.
Adopted, approved and signed, this 26th day of December, 1950.

Pomona, CA Zoning

ALAN G. ORSBORN

Mayor of the City of Pomona.
Attest:
C. HARRY DOREMUS

City Clerk.
Approved as to form, this 26th day of December, 1950.
ARLO E. RICKETT, JR.

City Attorney.
I, C. HARRY DOREMUS, City Clerk of the City of Pomona, California, do hereby certify that the foregoing Ordinance was introduced at an
adjourned regular meeting of the Council of said City, duly held on the 19th day of December, 1950, and thereafter at an adjourned regular
meeting of said Council duly held on the 27th day of December, 1950, was reread, duly passed and adopted by said Council and signed and
approved by the Mayor of said City, and that such Ordinance was so passed and adopted by the following vote, to-wit:
Ayes: Councilmen WRIGHT, HANDLEY, HITE, MAY.
Noes: Councilmen NONE.
Absent: Councilmen (MAYOR) ORSBORN.
C. HARRY DOREMUS

City Clerk of the City of Pomona.
Pub. Jan. 2, 1951.
